Following the acquisition of our business by KKR in 2018, we began a journey to separate, transform and reinvent our business, building on our existing strong foundations: a global platform with iconic power brands and world-class knowledge. Our journey took more than four years, with the wholescale transformational part of our journey completed in 2022. To become an independent business, we focused on separating and stabilizing our business, simplifying, renovating and innovating our product portfolio, expanding into new product categories, investing in R&D through the opening of a new Food Science Centre, optimizing our supply chain, building an end-to-end globally scaled and digitally-enabled platform and building a new IT infrastructure. See “Business—History” for a detailed description of our transformation journey. Building on our existing strong foundations and as a result of the significant industrial, digital and cultural transformation undertaken since 2018, we believe we are well positioned to advance the future of food. 1 -----

We are a global leader in plant-based food, established in 2018, as a purpose-driven company with a clear vision: “To make people healthier and happier with nutritious and delicious, natural, plant-based food that is good for you and good for our planet.” We develop, produce, distribute and market plant-based dairy alternative products in over 100 countries across four core categories: Butters and Spreads, Creams, Liquids and Cheeses. Backed by a rich heritage and a global scale, we are highly differentiated in the plant-based sector. Our reinvigorated iconic power brands reflect over 150 years of product expertise and brand heritage and are trusted by consumers globally. Our scale, culture and capabilities, including extensive food technology and innovation expertise, our community of dedicated “Upfielders,” consisting of our management team and employees, and our 14 manufacturing facilities across five continents, provide a strong value proposition for our customers and consumers, and ensure we are well positioned to advance the future of food. Our products are marketed under a family of historic and iconic brands with strong recognition in their target markets. Our products are made with natural and sustainably sourced ingredients. Our carefully selected ingredients come from a diversified supply chain to minimize risk and environmental impact and maximize taste, functionality, health, affordability and sustainability for our consumers. Our operations are diversified across three regions, namely Europe, the Americas and AMEA. We hold leadership positions in the global butter and spreads, and plant cheese segments, with leadership positions in creams in Germany and the United Kingdom, our key creams markets. We sell our products across these regions primarily through retail channels, such as supermarkets, hypermarkets, convenience stores and other outlets. In addition, through our professional foodservice channel, we sell our products to commercial outlets, such as quick service restaurants, bakeries, pizza and pasta outlets, hotels, catering and industrial kitchens, and to the social sector, such as educational institutions, workplaces and hospitals. During the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, our net sales were €2,793 million, €3,375 million and €3,275 million, respectively. During the same periods, our operating profit was €288 million, €453 million and €570 million, and our Normalized EBITDA was €666 million, €749 million and €831 million, respectively. During the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our net sales were €3,209 million, our operating profit was €604 million and Normalized EBITDA was €862 million.

Subsubsection Title: We are well positioned to advance the Future of Food in a large and growing TAM
Subsubsection Text: We believe that the future of food lies in tasty, high-quality, responsibly made, plant-based food. Transforming the food system by increasing the consumption of plant-based foods in our diets is the key to address the impact of what we eat on climate, nature and health. As a global leader in plant-based food, offering our products in four large and growing categories and selling into over 100 countries worldwide, we are well positioned to advance the future of food and to meet the growing shift in consumer preferences to plant-based eating. To inspire more people to eat plant-based alternatives, we focus on delivering tasty, high performing, healthy, sustainable and affordable products. We believe that there should be no compromise for consumers when they change to plant-based products as compared to dairy alternatives. We benefit from a senior management team with significant experience in the consumer-packaged goods industry. A majority of our current senior management team has been with us since our acquisition by KKR in 2018, and has been critical in our successful transformation. Under their leadership, we have separated, transformed and reinvented our business as a global leader in plant-based food and strongly positioned our business to drive conversion to plant-based alternatives. We believe that our senior management team has also been instrumental in developing a strong and motivated organization with a purpose- and performance-driven culture, which is carried by a passionate and engaged community of “Upfielders.” We believe that our community of “Upfielders” are aligned with our purpose, and are highly motivated to make an impact, deliver sustainable, purposeful long-term growth and advance the transition to a plant-based food future. Our ability to advance the future of food is further strengthened by our portfolio of Plant Butter and Spreads, Plant Creams, Liquids and Plant Cheeses products, sold through our reinvigorated and iconic brands, our global scale and manufacturing footprint, our food technology and innovation expertise which together provide a strong value proposition for our customers and consumers. We offer these plant-based products in our four core categories: Butters and Spreads, Creams, Liquids and Cheeses, which provide us access to a large and growing TAM (across both dairy and non-dairy) of approximately €151 billion as of 2022, which is 15 times larger than our TAM of approximately €11 billion in 2017 under our previous ownership (which was focused on plant-based spreads (margarines)). Our expansion into the Butter, Creams, Liquids and Cheeses categories, in addition to Spreads, resulted in an expansion of our TAM. While currently the penetration of plant-based products in the Butters, Creams and Cheeses categories is low, and estimated at less than 1%, there is a potential opportunity of approximately €23 billion (based on an incremental €7 billion opportunity in the above categories when assuming a 5% plant-based penetration) or €38 billion (based on an incremental €22 billion opportunity in the above categories when assuming a 16% plant-based penetration) (see also “Industry—Upfield’s TAM”). We believe that our global footprint and renovated and innovative product portfolio provide a significant growth opportunity in our TAM. Within our TAM (which covers both dairy and non-dairy products), given the growing consumer preference for plant-based diets in the backdrop of environmental, sustainability and health concerns, there is potential for increased rate of conversion to plant-based products, which we are well positioned to leverage, especially given our strong position globally and in the key markets in which we operate. For instance, according to NielsenIQ measurement data, within our Plant Butter and Spreads core category, which contributed 81% of our net sales for the year ended December 31, 2023, we are the largest producer globally in terms of market share and hold leading positions across some of the largest butter and spreads markets globally, including North America, Germany and the United Kingdom. In addition, according to NielsenIQ measurement data, we are the global leader in the plant cheese segment, and have leadership positions in creams in Germany and the United Kingdom, our key creams markets.

Subsubsection Title: A reinvigorated portfolio of brands reshaping the future of food
Subsubsection Text: With our portfolio of trusted brands we believe we can drive conversion to plant-based food and leverage our strong market positions going forward. Our brand platforms are led by our power brands, our most iconic brands, which have a long history and heritage. We believe that our power brands are deeply rooted and trusted by our consumers and customers across a number of our markets and have high brand awareness in their respective markets. These brands include, for example, Flora (launched in 1964), Country Crock (launched in 1954), Becel +ProActiv (Becel launched in 1962 and ProActiv launched in 2000), Rama (launched in 1924), BlueBand (launched in 1916) and Violife (acquired in 2020). In addition to our power brands, we also have a number of country or region specific brands with a strong local heritage and brand awareness, such as Lätta in Sweden, Stork in the United Kingdom and Tulipan in Spain. 2 ----- Following our acquisition by KKR, we have also reorganized and reinvigorated our brand portfolio since 2018. We refreshed our brands around our end-to-end brand platforms, so as to provide for better harmonization and efficiencies across our R&D and innovation pipeline, sales and marketing and supply chain activities. Our brand platforms are founded upon key prerequisites of taste and affordability, but each platform serves a distinct consumer need and is mapped against the key usage occasions and growth opportunities across our categories and markets. We also organize our brands across three different price tiers: “good,” (targeting price sensitive customers) “better” (targeting customers looking for additional product benefits at a more affordable price than a dairy alternative) and “best” (targeting customers seeking premium products with multiple features, such as lowering cholesterol). We assign our brands and products across these tiers which are each designed to meet distinct consumer needs and cater for certain price sensitivities, thereby catering to various social demographic needs. We believe that such categorization simplifies consumer decision-making and helps us strategically position each tier to appeal to a different array of consumers.

We operate an end-to-end globally scaled and digitally-enabled platform, in which we have made significant investment in recent years, and through which we produce and sell our products to retail and foodservice partners in over 100 countries globally. We operate a global network of manufacturing facilities and regional cold chain distribution centers with capabilities to support growth. Our historic strong cash generation has enabled us to invest significantly in our global operations, ensuring we have the latest manufacturing innovations at our disposal. We own a total of 14 manufacturing facilities, comprising seven in Europe, four in the Americas and three in AMEA. These facilities produced approximately 91% of our total production volume for the year ended December 31, 2023. Our comprehensive manufacturing network with a globally scaled and digitally-enabled supply chain, is well positioned for future growth. Our end-to-end platform is supported by our general ERP system and our SAP4Hana ERP system, which enable us to make data-driven operational decisions. Our robust in-house manufacturing capabilities allow for complete control and flexibility in the manufacturing process, through which we can (i) maintain a closer level of control over our robust quality and safety standards, (ii) better establish and control cost savings, (iii) limit and control manufacturing disruptions, (iv) reduce our carbon footprint and (v) manage the manufacturing process more efficiently. Our products and customers further benefit from our internal centralized procurement function designed to leverage our purchasing expertise and maximize scale efficiencies across the regions where we operate. Our procurement function has a deep understanding of commodity cycles and risk management, and many years of experience in the oils market. See “Business—Procurement” for a detailed description of our procurement function.

Subsubsection Title: An industry leading R&D expertise delivering innovation and driving conversion to plant-based food
Subsubsection Text: Our strong innovation pipeline underpins our mission to revolutionize the plant-based ecosystem by delivering tastier, high-quality products with natural ingredients. That pipeline is driven by our investment in R&D, oils & fats and plant-based proteins amongst other enabling technologies, with food science at its core. We believe that we have an industry leading R&D expertise that enables us to produce new and innovative products using key ingredient know-how, technically sophisticated equipment and processes across our core categories and products. As an insights-driven organization we seek to continually enhance consumer experience with respect to taste, functionality, health and nutrition, sustainability and affordability by developing relevant product and packaging innovation. We continuously invest in food innovation and food technology expertise from our new state-of-the-art food science centre in Wageningen, the Netherlands (“Food Science Centre”), which we have developed with an investment capital of approximately €38 million. Our Food Science Centre focuses on plant-based food innovation and it aims to pioneer the development of plant-based foods, enabling technologies including oils and fats as well as proteins, and sustainable packaging solutions. Our team of more than 150 food scientists, food and packaging technologists and specialists focus on the development of plant-based foods and sustainable packaging solutions. We are also a leading filer of plant-based patents, and hold 656 patents and patent applications. In 2023, we applied for a further ten patents across our categories and core technologies. With our deep expertise in plant-based and natural ingredients and proprietary knowledge of plant-based food manufacturing, we have implemented a significant product portfolio overhaul since 2018, focused on taste, 3 ----- clean label and naturalness, where possible. For instance, we developed our first-generation Plant Butter product between 2018 and 2020, which we have since then further evolved, offering products we aim to achieve taste parity as compared to dairy butter. We have also developed new recipes and ingredients for our products, for example to provide consumers with palm oil-free options through our patented technology. In 2023, we successfully launched our paper tub packaging technology in Austria under our Flora Plant brand, with similar launches in the United Kingdom and the Netherlands in early 2024. Our R&D and innovation roadmap is centered on continuous improvement and innovation within our core categories, to attract more and more consumers and broaden the appeal of our products. Key areas of focus include further improving our Plant Cheese product range, in particular in cold applications to further improve our Plant Cheese offering and applying some of our developing technology to further improve our Plant Butters and Plant Creams products. In addition, we continue to develop our packaging technology to create sustainable packaging and achieve our goal to reduce the environmental impact of our packaging through reduced plastic usage and increased recyclability of our packaging. As well as innovating internally to achieve these goals, we partner with academia, established ingredients and packaging players, startups and scale-ups whose differentiated propositions we believe can complement our R&D capabilities and our ability to scale through our distribution channels, platform and growth levers.

Subsubsection Title: Growth levers underpinned by a resilient, attractive financial profile with high cash generation
Subsubsection Text: Our growth levers are centered around driving conversion from dairy products to our plant-based products and involve: - Creating the best-ever products made by us: delivering tastier, high-quality products with natural ingredients in our four core categories, underpinned by a strong innovation pipeline; - Deploying our power brands: leveraging our iconic power brands, recognized and trusted across markets, with clear propositions; - Executing in multiple channels: reaching as many people as possible by executing well within our channels: retail and foodservice; and - Driving and leveraging our scale: leveraging our digitally enabled end-to-end platform and scale. Our transformation journey since 2018 has taken place against a turbulent and volatile backdrop of events including a global pandemic, associated supply chain challenges, commodity inflation and the ongoing cost-ofliving crisis. However, during this period, by leveraging our growth levers, we have demonstrated a track record of stable financial performance, in particular delivered strong growth in organic net sales, gross profit and Normalized EBITDA. Between the year ended December 31, 2021 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our reported net sales increased at a CAGR of 6.4%, our gross profit increased at a CAGR of 11.4% and our Normalized EBITDA increased at a CAGR of 12.1%. We have also demonstrated strong cash generation, and generated a normalized free cash flow and normalized free cash conversion ratio of €702 million and 81.4%, respectively, in each case, for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. We believe this compares favorably with our peers and is supported by, among other things: - our flexible cost base, which allows for a sustainable gross margin. We have clear, consistent and well-established supply chain, and hedging policies with respect to our major inputs and foreign exchange exposures, which has allowed us to maintain strong levels of profitability in periods of fluctuations and under high inflationary conditions; - our sustained profitability, with a Normalized EBITDA margin of 23.8%, 22.2%, 25.4% and 26.9%, in the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, respectively, largely attributable to our flexible cost structure, our powerful brands, our revenue growth management capabilities and our track record of operational cost savings; - a favorable working capital position, as we benefit from a negative cash conversion cycle. This largely is a structural feature of the payment terms customarily available in the raw material and finished product markets in which we operate and our operational efficiency with respect to our inventory management; and 4 ----- - our comprehensive manufacturing network with a globally scaled and digitally-enabled supply chain and significant spare capacity. This allows for increased net sales volumes without incremental capital expenditure resulting in strong cash generation. Our strong cash generation and resulting Normalized EBITDA growth has helped us to progressively deleverage. For the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our historical leverage ratio was 8.4x, 7.2x, 6.5x and 6.5x, respectively. Our historical leverage ratio represents the ratio of our (i) net debt, which is defined as our financial liabilities gross of unamortized financing fees less cash and cash equivalents, excluding lease liabilities and derivative financial instruments to (ii) Normalized EBITDA.

_Creating the best-ever products made by us: delivering tastier, high-quality products with natural ingredients in our four core categories, underpinned by a strong innovation pipeline_ Since 2018, we have reinvented our product portfolio, investing significant resources to create the bestever products made by us, including by harmonizing and simplifying our ingredients list and moving towards fewer, natural and fully plant-based ingredients. We are focused on delivering our best-ever products that are designed to have the same or superior taste, versatility and performance (cooking, baking, and spreading) as dairy products. We believe that there should be no compromise for consumers when they change to a plant-based butter or spread, liquid, plant-based cream or plant-based cheese, as compared to dairy alternatives. For example, our Plant Butter is specifically formulated with the aim to match the performance and taste of dairy butter. Based on more than 50 taste profiles, we created a series of plant butters which we strive to taste and perform just like dairy butter and that match the specific taste preferences of different consumer profiles in key markets. Also, our knowhow and expertise of natural ingredients has enabled us to simplify our Plant Butter to contain just six or seven natural ingredients (including certain Plant Oils, water, plant protein and, in some cases, salt) and enable consumers to swap it directly for dairy butter in any recipe. Consumers are also increasingly focused on clean label and naturalness, and 99% of all our ingredients by volume are natural in origin. We continue to invest in R&D to deliver products using recipes made from natural ingredients or products that are free from artificial colors, flavors and preservatives, and without compromising on food safety, quality and performance. In addition, as part of our commitment to be 100% plant-based by the end of 2030, we are continuously reviewing our use of dairy ingredients where there is no compromise in taste or performance. Aside from taste and performance, we focus on the nutritional benefits of our products, as well as their positive contribution to health. Health is a high priority for consumers and a key reason why people choose our products. In 2022, our team of nutritionists and product developers created the Upfield nutritional benchmarking program, based on what science tells us is required for each different product proposition and which introduced saturated fat and trans-fat targets for plant creams and plant cheeses. This helps us ensure that we meet nutritional targets in our products and are aligned with international dietary guidelines and regulations. Our plant-based products contain zero trans-fats and lower saturated fats compared to dairy alternatives. So, whether consumers are looking for a product to bake a cake, help lower their cholesterol or containing the nutrients to support a growing family, our products strive to provide a “no compromise” choice, that is better for consumers and better for the planet. _Deploying our power brands: leveraging our iconic power brands, recognized, trusted and loved over the world with clear propositions_ Our business traces its origin and heritage back over 150 years and, as a result, many of our reinvigorated iconic power brands, including BlueBand and Rama, have a brand heritage spanning over 100 years. Our power 5 ----- brands, including as an example, Flora, Country Crock, Becel +ProActiv, Rama, BlueBand and Violife, are trusted in their key markets globally and are at the heart of our future growth strategy and success. Our power brands are well-known and have a high brand awareness amongst consumers in our markets. They represent the platform from which we have successfully launched our product innovations and portfolio renovation. Through our power brands we engage with both loyal and new consumers, offering people a positive choice, both as a plant-based alternative to dairy and also for less competitive brands and private label. Based on independent brand research, many of our power brands are among the best-performing FMCG/packaged grocery brands across our key markets in terms of brand awareness. We believe that the high score of our power brands indicate that consumers are more likely to choose our brands over others, which is a strong indicator of increasing brand influence and share. To further support our power brands, we complemented the ongoing innovation across our portfolio with an increase in strategic advertising and promotion investment. For the year ended December 31, 2023, our advertising and promotion expenses amounted to €173 million (equalling 5.3% of our net sales for the year ended December 31, 2023 and an increase of 22.7% compared to the year ended December 31, 2022). For example, in 2023, we launched our “Skip the Cow” campaign aimed at informing and driving consumers towards more plant-based products. Our “Skip the Cow” campaign pushed the uptake of Flora Plant and has proved to be a valuable resource in boosting consumer awareness of our Plant Butter offering and also contributed to a strong positive consumer net sentiment of 86% towards our overall Flora brand. Furthermore, following the “Skip the Cow” campaign, Flora Plant Butter experienced growth in household penetration and share of segment in the United Kingdom. Following the success of the “Skip the Cow” campaign in the United Kingdom, we launched similar campaigns across European markets, such as Germany and Austria, and intend to also roll it out to other key markets such as the Netherlands, Poland or Spain, and also across other brands. To further leverage the strength of our brands, we have from time to time considered, and continue to consider and evaluate, modifications to our corporate branding and identity to more closely align with our key brands. _Executing in multiple channels: reaching as many people as possible through our channels: retail and foodservice_ We also differentiate ourselves through our retail and professional foodservice channels, which enable us to reach consumers directly through both industry channels. We sell our products to retail outlets, including to many of the world’s largest retailers, as well as to wholesalers. We also enhanced our e-commerce capabilities by developing relationships with various online retailers and e-commerce platforms, such as Ocado, Tesco, Amazon and Carrefour online, which have seen an increase in retail market share in recent years and which we believe represent a significant growth opportunity in the regions in which we operate, especially in Europe and the Americas. In addition, in emerging markets in which we operate across our regions, we have established a strong market channel based on deep relationships with well-known and reputable distributors. Through our foodservice channel, we also supply the professional channel, including restaurants, hotels and industrial kitchens. This multichannel approach gives us access to a broad and diverse customer base, which enhances our position as a leader in many of our core categories. Because of our strong relationships with leading global and regional retailers, we operate as the supplier of choice and/or “category captain” for certain strategic retailers, providing in-depth knowledge and consumer insight for particular product categories to our retailer customers. Moreover, we believe there is considerable potential to introduce and expand our core product categories in the foodservice channel given our current portfolio’s appeal across high-end clients who lead and influence the menu adoption cycle to large quick-service restaurants, bakery chains and other national accounts where mass adoption occurs. Our growth strategy in foodservice is focused on selling value-added branded products with high-demand applications to commercial customers and driving customer acquisition through our chef-led sales approach (see also “—Sales and Marketing”). _Driving and leveraging our scale: leveraging our digitally enabled end-to-end platform and scale_ Through our end-to-end globally scaled and digitally-enabled platform we produce and sell our products to retail and foodservice partners in over 100 countries globally. Our global footprint, scale and expertise along the value chain allow us to leverage efficiencies through which we can derive significant advantages compared to other plant-based competitors and dairy players. Since 2018, we have demonstrated a track record in driving efficiencies for example by establishing product portfolio efficiencies (through the retirement of SKUs that are less profitable or of low productivity and the simplification of our recipes), procurement efficiencies (by sourcing most of our ingredients and packaging materials from global suppliers who can deliver locally), supply chain efficiencies (through our established local retail and distribution network) and by maintaining a continued focus on operational efficiencies in line with our value creation program. Establishing such efficiencies allows us to offer affordable products. 6 -----

Our purpose is “to make people healthier and happier with nutritious and delicious, natural, plant-based food that is good for you and for our planet” and it shapes how we approach the sourcing of our ingredients, the development of our recipes, our relationships with retailers and how we communicate with consumers. We intend to continue fulfilling our purpose with our commitment and initiatives across our four pillars: (i) plant-based, (ii) healthier lives, (iii) happier people and (iv) better planet, which are at the heart of our business with tangible programs and milestones. _Plant-Based_ Actively helping the food transition and building a better, plant-based future is at the heart of what we do. Our plant-based commitment pillar seeks to help inspire and encourage consumers to switch from dairy to plant-based options. As we continue to improve our product portfolio, we aim to reach one billion consumers with our products by 2030. We believe we can achieve that goal by offering consumers a range of products that meet their needs, which also includes making sure our products taste great, perform well, and are made with simple, natural ingredients. We believe we are in a strong position to support the transition to a plant-based diet by offering tasty, affordable, nutritious and more sustainable products. From our Food Science Centre, we continuously invest in high performance product formulations and reformulations to keep up with consumer needs and trends. For example, in 2023, we launched the Violife cream cheese block in the United States which has been developed specifically to compete with leading dairy cream cheeses on the market, following a completely new formulation and format. To spread awareness around our plant-based products, we frequently launch retail consumer advertising campaigns with slogans aimed at informing and driving consumers and professionals towards more plant-based products. Other efforts to boost our brands’ and products’ visibility include, for example, sponsorship of sporting events and partnerships with celebrities and influencers. In addition, we are also working to support the industry moving forward in terms of plant-based innovation, which includes establishing standard parameters for plant-based products. For example, we are currently leading the development of a new ISO standard that we expect will specify technical definitions of, and criteria for, plant-based foods. We believe that this new ISO standard will help align the global food industry around a single terminology approach. _Healthier Lives_ The second pillar focuses on the nutritional benefits of our products as well as their positive contribution to health. Health is a high priority for consumers and we believe is a key reason why people choose our products. We aim for our products to outperform their dairy counterparts with respect to levels of saturated and trans-fats. We take a science-based approach to establishing criteria and targets for each product type we sell, considering who uses them, how frequently and in which applications. These targets are based on recognized external international standards and official dietary recommendations, including those from the World Health Organization. Moreover, we have set additional targets that ensure we can deliver the desired nutritional composition. These include considerations on how we can limit nutrients of concern and provide essential nutrients that target some of the greatest public health areas of concern, such as heart health and children’s growth and development. Our brands BlueBand and Becel +ProActiv are our global brands focused on positively impacting lives across the world by offering healthy, affordable and nutritious options. In 2023, approximately 30% of our net sales came from products providing health and nutrition benefits and that can be labelled as such, in compliance with regulation. Additionally, we believe the future of food lies in quality, responsibly made, plant-based foods. To realize this future and provide consumers with healthier options, we intend to continue implementing rigorous quality and safety standards at both our and third-party facilities, including for product design, formulation, raw material sourcing, packing, manufacturing, storage, transport, display, marketing, communication, sales and product disposal. Moreover, we intend to continue ensuring that our products are accessible to as many people as possible, which includes ensuring our products come in at affordable price points. In this regard we intend to maintain a portfolio of products designed for budgetary brackets across the market spectrum and which are more affordable than dairy alternatives, without compromising on quality. 7 ----- _Happier People_ We believe that people are happier when they are engaged and we actively promote a culture of active support. We are committed to our community of dedicated “Upfielders.” Our approach to employee engagement is driven by three core values: performance, care and passion. To nurture an engaged workforce, we complete an annual survey to gauge employee sentiment and opportunities for progress. In addition, diverse businesses are likely to be more successful and we are committed to creating a diverse and inclusive working environment. Across our supply chains, we are connected to thousands of farmers and plant-based entrepreneurs who grow our ingredients and chefs who create and prepare millions of meals every day. In support of farmers and plant-based entrepreneurs, we maintain several partnerships, enabling and encouraging them to improve agricultural practices and access to markets. In addition, we seek to reach as many chefs and food service professionals as possible to encourage the adoption of our products into their cooking, thereby engaging chefs in the plant-based revolution. We do this by, for example, hosting cooking workshops for chefs or participating in trade fairs where we can reach out and educate professionals on the advantages of plant-based cooking. _Better Planet_ With an environmental footprint significantly smaller than that of dairy products, our products can help consumers reduce their impact, and we ensure our operations do so as well. We are committed to responsibly sourcing ingredients, developing sustainable packaging and addressing our carbon emissions to enhance sustainability. Our better planet commitments include our environmental targets to address our material environmental impacts on the climate, on packaging and on responsible sourcing. For the year ended December 31, 2023, we committed to Science Based Target Initiative (“SBTi”) and have worked on redefining our targets in line with the newly published Forest, Land and Agriculture (“FLAG”) guidance to align with limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels. In this respect, we are making multiple efforts towards reducing our emissions and reducing environmental impact through waste and water management at our manufacturing facilities. In addition, we are committed to providing packaging that protects products and the planet. We delivered a milestone packaging achievement with the launch of the world’s first paper-based tub for plant-based butters and spreads, our Flora Plant paper tub at the end of 2023, starting our journey towards our target of reducing plastic across our portfolio by 80% by 2030 (compared to a 2020 baseline). In addition, we are committed to responsible and sustainable sourcing of our ingredients (including our Plant Oils) and packaging materials (including paper and pulp) and our “Responsible Sourcing Policy” and “Business Partner Code of Conduct” applies to all our suppliers. Where key ingredients are identified as potentially high risk, we maintain strong individual policies designed to address the potential risks inherent in these supply chains, particularly focussing on deforestation and exploitation. See also “Business— Environmental, Social, Governance (“ESG”).”

Our strategies are focused on the continued implementation of our growth levers to capture the key opportunities across our core categories and markets. Our clear mission and purpose forms the cornerstone of our strategy to deliver long term sustainable, profitable and purposeful growth by bringing tasty plant-based foods to people all over the world, and achieve our purpose “to make people healthier and happier with nutritious and delicious, natural, plant-based food that is good for you and for our planet.”

The Issuer is a private company with limited liability incorporated under the laws of the Netherlands (besloten vennootschap met beperkte aansprakelijkheid) on December 13, 2017, having its official seat (statutaire _zetel) in Amsterdam, the Netherlands and its office at Beethovenstraat 551, 7[th] floor, 1083 HK Amsterdam, the_ Netherlands. The Issuer is registered with the Dutch Trade Register of the Chamber of Commerce under number the number 70298807. The Issuer is an indirect subsidiary of the Company.

The Transactions consist of the following: - the issuance by the Issuer of the Senior Secured Notes offered hereby; - the redemption of $180,760,000 in aggregate principal amount of the Senior Dollar Notes, pursuant to which $306,640,000 in aggregate principal amount of the Senior Dollar Notes shall remain outstanding; - the redemption of €232,575,000 in aggregate principal amount of the Senior Euro Notes, pursuant to which €444,485,000 in aggregate principal amount of the Senior Euro Notes shall remain outstanding; and 8 ----- - the payment of fees and expenses incurred in connection with the foregoing transactions, including the fees and expenses to be incurred in connection with the Offering, which we expect to fund from our cash on balance sheet as of March 31, 2024. See “Use of Proceeds.” For descriptions of our anticipated indebtedness following the completion of the Transactions, see “Capitalization.”

Entities advised by affiliates of Kohlberg, Kravis & Roberts & Co. L.P. (“KKR”) indirectly hold 100% of the shareholding of the Issuer. KKR is a leading global investment firm with a long history of investing in Europe. Founded in 1976 by Henry Kravis and George Roberts and led by Scott Nuttall and Joe Bae, KKR manages approximately $578 billion of assets and has over 2,500 employees across offices in 25 cities and four continents as of March 31, 2024. With offices around the world, KKR manages assets through a variety of investment funds and accounts covering multiple asset classes, including private equity, energy, infrastructure, real estate, capital markets and credit strategies. KKR seeks to create value by bringing operational expertise to its portfolio companies and through active oversight and monitoring of its investments. It complements its investment expertise and strengthens interactions with investors through its client relationships and capital markets platforms. 9 -----

The Senior Secured Notes will: - be senior obligations of the Issuer, secured as set forth below under “—Security”; - be senior in right of payment to any Subordinated Indebtedness (as defined herein) of the Issuer, including its guarantee of the Senior Notes (defined below); - rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the Issuer’s existing and future debt that is not subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Secured Notes, including debt outstanding under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement; - be effectively senior in right of payment to any existing or future unsecured debt of the Issuer, or debt that is secured on a basis junior to the Senior Secured Notes, including the guarantees of the Senior Notes, to the extent of the value of the Collateral that is available to satisfy the obligations under the Senior Secured Notes and debt outstanding under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement; - be effectively subordinated to any existing and future debt of the Issuer that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Senior Secured Notes to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such debt; - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future debt of subsidiaries of the Issuer that do not guarantee the Senior Secured Notes, including obligations to trade creditors; and - be unconditionally guaranteed on a senior secured basis by the Guarantors as set forth under “—Ranking of the Guarantees.” 12 ----- Guarantors ....................................** Subject to the Agreed Security Principles, on the Issue Date, the obligations of the Issuer pursuant to the Senior Secured Notes, will be guaranteed, jointly and severally on a senior secured basis, by the Company and certain of its subsidiaries: Upfield Group B.V., Upfield Holdings B.V., Upfield Nederland B.V., Upfield Research and Development B.V., Upfield Europe B.V., Upfield NL Holdings Two B.V., Upfield Treasury B.V., Upfield Real Estate B.V., Upfield US Inc., Upfield Sourcing US, Inc., Upfield USA Corp., Upfield UK Services Limited, Upfield Foods UK Limited, Upfield Spreads UK Limited, Upfield Deutschland GmbH, Upfield Sourcing Deutschland GmbH & Co. In addition, pursuant to the Security Documents, and subject to the Intercreditor Agreement, the Agreed Security Principles, Permitted Collateral Liens and certain perfection requirements, as soon as reasonably practicable after the Issue Date and in any event within 10 days from the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes and the Guarantees will be secured on a subsequent-ranking basis (in each case treated as first ranking in accordance with the provisions of the Intercreditor Agreement) by: - Dutch law governed security interests over certain (i) material operating bank accounts of the Issuer and the Guarantors incorporated in the Netherlands, (ii) material structural intercompany receivables owing to Guarantors incorporated in the Netherlands and (iii) shares or capital stock (or partnership interests, as applicable) held in respect of the Issuer and the Subsidiary Guarantors incorporated in the Netherlands, - German law governed security interests over certain (i) material operating bank accounts of the Guarantors incorporated in Germany and (ii) shares or capital stock (or 14 ----- partnership interests, as applicable) held in respect of such Guarantors; and (collectively, the “ **Additional Collateral,” together with the Initial Collateral, and any and all assets from time to time in which a security interest has been or will be granted pursuant to any Security Document to secure the obligations under the Indenture or the Senior Secured Notes or any Guarantee, in each case, as may be in existence from time to time, the “Collateral”). See also “Description of the Senior Secured _Notes—Security—Collateral.”_ The Collateral will also secure the liabilities under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement and hedging agreements on a pari passu basis and may secure additional Indebtedness permitted to be secured on the Collateral. In addition, a portion of the Collateral, as further described under “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Security—Collateral” (the “Shared Collateral”) also secures, on a senior subordinated basis, the obligations of the Issuer and the Guarantors under the Senior Notes. Pursuant to the Intercreditor Agreement, any liabilities in respect of obligations under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement and any hedging obligations and certain future Indebtedness secured on the Collateral will rank pari passu with the holders of the Senior Secured Notes with respect to any proceeds received upon any enforcement action over any Collateral. In addition, the obligations under the Senior Secured Notes, the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement, hedging obligations and such permitted or other future senior secured Indebtedness will receive priority over the Senior Notes with respect to any proceeds received upon any enforcement action over any Shared Collateral, which secures the Senior Notes, on a senior subordinated basis, and also forms part of the Collateral securing the Senior Secured Notes. The Collateral will, in each case, be limited and subject to certain statutory defenses under the laws of the Netherlands, England and Wales, Germany and New York, as applicable, as described under “Risk _Factors—Risks Relating to the Senior Secured Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral—The Guarantees and the security interests in the Collateral will be subject to certain limitations on enforcement and may be limited by applicable laws or subject to certain defenses that may limit their validity and enforceability” and “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Collateral and Certain insolvency Law Considerations.”_ The security interests over the Collateral may be released under certain circumstances. At any time prior to       , 2026, the Issuer may, during each twelve month period commencing on the Issue Date, redeem up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of the Senior Secured Notes (calculated after giving effect to the issuance of any additional Senior Secured Notes) at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount thereof plus accrued and unpaid interest. At any time following the occurrence of any Initial Public Offering, the Issuer may, at its option, redeem the Senior Secured Notes, in whole or in part, with funds in an aggregate amount not exceeding the Net Cash Proceeds of such Initial Public Offering received by the Company or any Restricted Subsidiary at a redemption price equal to 102% of the principal amount of the Senior Secured Notes so redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any, to (but excluding) the redemption date.

Reasons ..........................................** In the event of certain developments affecting taxation, the Issuer may redeem the Senior Secured Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes— _Redemption for Taxation Reasons.”_ Change of Control ........................** Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a change of control, the Issuer may be required to offer to repurchase the Senior Secured Notes at a purchase price in cash equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof on the date of purchase plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to the date of purchase. However, a change of control will not be deemed to have occurred if a specified consolidated leverage ratio is not exceeded in connection with such event. See “Description of the Senior _Secured Notes—Change of Control.”_ 16 ----- Certain Covenants ........................** The Indenture contains covenants that limit the ability of the Company and its restricted subsidiaries to, among other things: - incur or guarantee additional debt and issue certain preferred stock; - pay dividends or make other distributions or investments or purchase or reduce or redeem the Issuer’s stock; - make investments or other restricted payments; - enter into agreements that restrict the Issuer’s restricted subsidiaries’ ability to pay dividends; - transfer or sell assets; - engage in certain transactions with affiliates; - create liens on assets to secure indebtedness; - impair security interests; or - merge or consolidate with other entities or transfer all or substantially all of the Issuer’s or a Guarantor’s assets. Each of these covenants is subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Certain _Covenants.”_ Use of Proceeds .............................** The Issuer will use the gross proceeds of the Senior Secured Notes as set forth in “Use of Proceeds.” Transfer Restrictions ....................** The Issuer has not registered the Senior Secured Notes or the Guarantees under the U.S. Securities Act and has not agreed, or otherwise undertaken, to do so. You may only offer or sell Senior Secured Notes in a transaction exempt from or not subject to the registration requirements of the U.S. Securities Act. See “Notice to _Investors.”_ No Prior Market ...........................** The Senior Secured Notes will be new securities for which there is currently no market. Although the Initial Purchasers have informed us that they intend to make a market in the Senior Secured Notes, they are not obligated to do so and they may discontinue market-making at any time without notice. Accordingly, we cannot assure you that a liquid market for the Senior Secured Notes will develop or be maintained. Listing ............................................** Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited (the “Authority”) for the listing of the Senior Secured Notes on the Official List of The International Stock Exchange (the “Exchange”) and admission to trade on the Exchange. There can be no assurances that the Senior Secured Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange.

Ratio of adjusted net total debt to Normalized EBITDA ....................................................... 6.5x Ratio of adjusted net total senior secured debt to Normalized EBITDA ................................ 5.6x Ratio of adjusted total interest expense to Normalized EBITDA........................................... x (1) As we are a geographically diversified business with global operations, we undertake transactions in various currencies. As a result, a number of our subsidiaries report their financial results in currencies other than the euro, which is the reporting currency of our consolidated financial statements. So as to enhance comparability of some of key financial metrics, including net sales growth, gross profit growth, gross margin growth, Normalized EBITDA growth and Normalized EBITDA margin growth, we present such metrics on a constant currency basis. The exchange rates used for the calculation of such constant currency exchange rate metrics for a particular 21 ----- period represent the average exchange rates of the relevant currency for the prior period. By presenting such metrics on a constant currency basis, we exclude the impact of foreign currency fluctuations such that both the current and prior period local currency values are translated into euro using prior year average exchange rates. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Non IFRS _Financial Measures—Constant Currency Exchange Rate Measures” for the exchange rates used by us to calculate constant currency_ exchange rate measures in respect of our principal currencies for the relevant periods. For each such period, the exchange rates mentioned under “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Non IFRS Financial Measures—Constant Currency Exchange Rate _Measures” represent the average exchange rates of the relevant currency for the prior period._ (2) Organic net sales growth/(decrease) presents a “like–for-like” comparative growth rate, and represents the change in net sales for the current period compared to the comparable prior period, calculated on a constant currency basis and by eliminating any change in scope between the relevant periods. Such change in scope between periods may result from: (i) an acquisition, divestiture or disposal of our business in a country or a major market or that of a business unit; (ii) changes to the business model under which we operate in a specific market, or with respect to the manner in which a particular product is (or particular products are) sold by us in that market (for example, if we change our local operating model from a distributor model to a royalty model, or if we change from third-party manufacturing (wherein such third-party manufacturer typically sources raw materials) to toll manufacturing (wherein we typically supply raw materials to a third party manufacturer) or (iii) the adoption of an accounting standard or a change in the application of an accounting principle, if applicable. We commenced calculating organic net sales growth/(decrease) beginning for the year ended December 31, 2023. Accordingly, we present organic net sales growth/(decrease) for the year ended December 31, 2023, the three months ended March 31, 2023 and March 31, 2024 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024 only. See also “Management’s Discussion and _Analysis of Financial Condition and Our Results of Operation—Results of Operations” for a discussion on the reasons for the change_ in organic net sales growth/(decrease) and/or constant currency net sales growth (as described below), including in our operating segments, for the periods presented in this Offering Memorandum. (3) Constant currency net sales growth presents the change in net sales for the relevant period compared to the prior period, calculated on a constant currency basis. We present constant currency net sales growth for the years ended December 31, 2021 and December 31, 2022 only. (4) Represents the growth rate of our reported gross profit (which is our net sales minus cost of sales) calculated on a constant currency basis. (5) Represents our reported gross margin (calculated as our net sales minus cost of sales divided by net sales, and expressed as a percentage). (6) Represents the growth rate of our reported gross margin calculated on a constant currency basis. (7) Normalized EBITDA is a non-IFRS metric which is defined as net profit/(loss) before income tax expense, net finance costs, depreciation of property, plant and equipment (including right of use assets) and amortization of intangible assets, as adjusted for sharebased payment expenses and certain non-underlying items that we do not consider to be part of the Group’s daily business operations, due to the nature, frequency, and predictability of their occurrence. While the amounts included in Normalized EBITDA have been derived from our consolidated financial statements or management accounts, they are not financial measures calculated in accordance with IFRS. Accordingly, they should not be considered as alternatives to net profit/(loss) or operating profit/(loss) as indicators of our performance, or as alternatives to operating cash flows as a measure of our liquidity. Our management uses Normalized EBITDA to assess our operating performance. In addition, we believe that Normalized EBITDA is a measure commonly used by investors. Normalized EBITDA, as presented in this Offering Memorandum, may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other companies due to differences in the way these measures are calculated. The following table sets forth a reconciliation of reported net profit/(loss) to Normalized EBITDA:

Subsubsection Text: (a) Net capital expenditure includes investment in property, plant and equipment and investment in other intangible assets offset by proceeds from disposal of property, plant and equipment and other intangible assets, and are derived from our consolidated statement of cash flow data for the relevant periods. (b) Represents net cash outflows for non-underlying operating and capital items, and includes cash outflow relating to remaining separation, restructuring and business transformation initiatives (for the year ended December 31, 2021); net cash outflow relating to transformation and supply chain restructuring initiatives, offset by cash inflow related to the sale of our manufacturing facilities in Rexdale, Canada and Nassaukade, the Netherlands (for the year ended December 31, 2022); cash outflow relating to supply chain activities in LatAm and IT integration initiatives in relation to our acquisition of Arivia S.A. (for the year ended December 31, 2023); cash outflow relating to supply chain activities (for the three months ended March 31, 2023); and cash outflow relating to supply chain activities in Mexico and remaining IT integration initiatives in relation to our acquisition of Arivia S.A. (for the three months ended March 31, 2024). (10) Normalized free cash conversion ratio represents normalized free cash flow divided by Normalized EBITDA for that period, expressed as a percentage. (11) Normalized EBITDA margin represents our Normalized EBITDA divided by net sales, expressed as a percentage. (12) Represents the growth rate of our Normalized EBITDA margin calculated on a constant currency basis. 23 ----- (13) Pricing contribution represents the relative contribution to organic net sales growth/(decrease) and/or constant currency net sales growth of changes in product prices for the current period compared to the prior period. (14) Volume/mix contribution represents the relative contribution to organic net sales growth/(decrease) and/or constant currency net sales growth of changes in volume/mix for the current period compared to the prior period. In addition, we have also presented underlying volume/mix contribution, which is calculated as volume/mix contribution adjusted for the impact of the product portfolio upgrade, rationalization, renovation and other self-directed initiatives for the current period compared to the prior period. We have calculated underlying volume/mix contribution for the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2023, and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024 only, which was (6.5%), (2.6%) and (1.8%), respectively. See also Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and _Results of Operation—Results of Operations.”_ (15) Adjusted cash and cash equivalents is calculated as cash and cash equivalents as of March 31, 2024, adjusted to give effect to our estimated cash position after giving effect to the Transactions and the use of proceeds therefrom as contemplated under “Use of Proceeds,” as if they had occurred on March 31, 2024. Adjusted cash and cash equivalents is not adjusted for ordinary course movements in our cash and cash equivalents after March 31, 2024. See also “Capitalization.” (16) Adjusted total debt is total debt adjusted to give effect to the Transactions and the use of proceeds therefrom as contemplated under “Use of Proceeds” as if they had occurred on March 31, 2024. Adjusted total debt consists of the Senior Secured Notes offered hereby, the Revolving Credit Facility, the the Senior Term Facilities, the Senior Notes outstanding following the completion of the Transactions and lease liabilities under IFRS 16 (Leases). Adjusted net total debt represents our adjusted total debt less adjusted cash and cash equivalents. See also “Capitalization.” (17) Adjusted total senior secured debt represents our adjusted total debt that is senior secured debt, consisting of the Senior Secured Notes offered hereby, the Revolving Credit Facility and the Senior Term Facilities. Adjusted net total senior secured debt represents our adjusted total senior secured debt less adjusted cash and cash equivalents. See also “Capitalization.” (18) Adjusted total interest expense is interest expense with respect to our adjusted total debt, excluding any interest expense associated with lease liabilities, as adjusted to give effect to the Transactions, including the issuance of the Senior Secured Notes and the use of proceeds therefrom, as if they had occurred on April 1, 2023. 24 -----

Section Title: SUMMARY HISTORICAL AND OTHER FINANCIAL INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: _The following tables summarize the Company’s historical consolidated financial information as of the dates and for the periods indicated. Unless otherwise indicated, the historical and other consolidated financial information presented below have been derived from (i) the audited consolidated financial statements of the Company as of and for the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, which have been prepared in accordance with IFRS, as well as with the statutory provisions of Part 9, Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code, and (ii) the unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements of the Company as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2024, which contains unaudited comparative information for the three months ended March 31, 2023, and which have been prepared in accordance with IAS 34 Interim Financial Reporting as adopted by the European Union, each included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. We have also presented below certain unaudited consolidated income statement information and certain other consolidated financial information for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Such information for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024 has been derived by adding the relevant item for the year ended December 31, 2023 and for the three months ended March 31, 2024, and subtracting the relevant item for the three months ended March 31, 2023. We also present certain non-IFRS measures below that we use to evaluate our operating and financial performance. Such non-IFRS measures include, among others, certain organic and constant currency growth metrics that we use, including, organic net sales growth/(decrease), constant currency net sales growth, constant currency gross profit (decrease)/growth, constant currency gross margin (decrease)/growth, constant currency Normalized EBITDA growth and constant currency Normalized EBITDA margin (decrease)/growth, and other non-IFRS measures, such as Normalized EBITDA, Normalized EBITDA margin, normalized free cash flow, normalized free cash conversion ratio, pricing contribution and volume/mix contribution. These measures are not identified as accounting measures under IFRS and therefore should not be considered as alternative measures to evaluate our performance. In addition, we also present below certain unaudited consolidated financial information of our Group, adjusted to give effect to the Transactions, as if they had occurred on March 31, 2024 for the consolidated statement of financial position data and on April 1, 2023 for the consolidated income statement data, including the impact on our cash position, amount of debt and interest expense. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information.” Any references in these tables to “we,” the “Group” or “Upfield” related to the Company and its consolidated subsidiaries. Rounding adjustments have been made in calculating some of the financial and other information included in this section. As a result, figures shown as totals in some tables and charts may not be exact arithmetic aggregations of the figures that precede them. This summary historical consolidated financial information should be read in conjunction with the sections entitled “Use of Proceeds,” “Capitalization,” “Selected Historical Financial Information,” “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” and the consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum._

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Fluctuations in the price and availability of raw materials, as well as increases of supply chain costs, may have a material adverse effect on our results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: The principal ingredient in our Plant Butter and Spreads, Plant Creams, Liquids and Plant Cheeses are refined Plant Oils. Aside from Plant Oils, additional key inputs used in our production process include other natural ingredients, packaging materials and utility inputs such as water and energy. We obtain substantially all of our raw materials from third-party suppliers, with cost of such materials (which includes Plant Oils, other ingredients, flavors, finished goods from third-party manufacturers and packaging materials) representing 67% and 68% of our total cost of sales, for the year ended December 31, 2023 and the three months ended March 31, 2024, respectively. The availability and cost of Plant Oils and other ingredients used in our products can fluctuate substantially over relatively short periods of time due to a number of factors beyond our control, such as general economic conditions, agricultural policies, government programs, weather conditions such as frosts, drought and floods, and plant diseases, pests and other acts of nature. In particular, price volatility has increased since the outset of the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as due to the ongoing conflicts between Russia and Ukraine and in the Middle East. For example, although we do not source sunflower oil from Ukraine directly, as Ukraine is the world’s biggest exporter of sunflower oil, beginning the first quarter of the year ended December 31, 2022, the war in Ukraine caused a global shortage of sunflower oil, which in turn led to a rise in the price of sunflower oil during the year ended December 31, 2022. Although, in response to possible disruptions in the supply chain, we created a formula that allows us to substitute and swap ingredients within our Butters and Spreads (such as sunflower oil for rapeseed oil), without any impact on the taste, texture or functionality of our products, such substitution of our recipes to prevent any supply chain disruptions may result in a higher cost base as this generally results in incremental R&D costs and a need to adjust packaging. The increase in sunflower oil prices has also had a knock-on effect on the prices of other Plant Oils, including palm, rapeseed and soybean oil, which have seen a further spike in demand as a result of their growing use as biofuel. The price of palm oil has also increased in recent years due to slower production by the main producer nations, and the recently adopted domestic market obligation policy in Indonesia, which is the world’s largest palm oil producer. Pursuant to this policy, palm oil producers in Indonesia had to set aside a certain quantity of palm oil for local buyers, thereby limiting the amount available for export. In addition, the increase in inflation globally since 2022 has further increased our costs of acquiring ingredients and the contributed to general volatility of commodity prices, and this inflationary impact continues. We may not be able to preserve our gross profit margin if such volatility, fluctuations and high inflationary conditions were to persist, as we may have limited ability to flow through our increased commodity cost in our pricing, which in turn could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. The past years’ significant volatility in commodity prices, the significant surge in energy and transportation prices, as well as the supply chain interruptions caused by recent geopolitical and economic events, adversely impacted our inputs suppliers’ cost base which they subsequently passed on to us. For example, because of the energy intensive nature of the refinery process to turn crude oils into refined oils, our Plant Oils suppliers have sought to pass on their heightened energy costs to us. All of this has exposed us in turn to significantly higher Plant Oils, packaging, energy costs, and as a consequence thereof, higher manufacturing, logistics and transportation costs, which we may not be able 25 ----- to effectively hedge or fully pass on to our customers. There can be no assurance that we or our third-party manufacturers will be able to obtain alternative sources of raw materials or packaging materials at reasonable prices, or at all, should there be shortages or other unfavorable conditions. To manage our input costs, we regularly monitor global market prices and enter into hedging arrangements, principally in respect of the major Plant Oils we purchase as well as utilities. We use a combination of fixed contracts and commodity derivatives (futures, over the counter and tradable forward contracts) to hedge against commodity price risk. Our policy is to hedge the majority of the risk within the relevant pricing window, and typically on a three to six months rolling basis. However, there can be no assurance that such hedging transactions will successfully reduce our exposure to price volatility in the long term and, given our limited customer negotiation windows, there may be a time lag between the implementation of our pricing initiatives and the impact of inflation across our key inputs. Our inability to obtain adequate supplies of raw materials for our products or other supply chain inputs at reasonable prices, or at all, as a result of any of the foregoing factors or otherwise, could cause an increase in our cost of sales and a corresponding decrease in our gross profit margin, or cause our net sales to fluctuate from period to period. Such fluctuations may result in a decrease in gross profit margin and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Changes in food trends and consumer preferences may have a material adverse effect on our results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Trends within our industry change often and our failure to anticipate, identify or react to changes in these trends could, among other things, lead to reduced demand and price reductions and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. There are a number of changing consumer trends, demands and preferences which have an effect on both our Group and the industry in which we operate. These include dietary, health and environmental concerns and trends, such as increasing awareness of different nutritional aspects of foods and the health effects and sourcing practices relating to specific ingredients, an increasing preference for dairy-free, vegan and organic food ingredients, trends towards eating outside of home and concerns regarding public health consequences associates with obesity and increasing awareness of the environmental and social effects of production (in particular those related to palm oil, which is a key ingredient in many products across our portfolio). Currently, there is an increasing trend of consumers across markets preferring nondairy, plant-based products as a result of the increasing awareness of lactose-intolerance health issues, high carbon footprint and the environmental impact of dairy consumption. However, this growing trend towards plant-based alternatives may be adversely impacted by a number of factors, such as misconceptions about “highly processed” plantbased foods, perceived “naturalness” of dairy and increased regulatory control of the plant-based sector. In addition, there has been negative press coverage in recent years as regards products made from palm oil due to both health and environmental concerns. For example, among our key markets, Spain and the Netherlands in particular, have seen a greater negative press coverage and perception as regards use of palm oil based products. In response thereto, we created a patented palm oil-free technology and we have shifted our focus on offering alternatives to palm oil in some of our markets. Although we source certified (segregated and mass balance) palm oil and offer palm oil-free options in several markets, there is a risk that additional press coverage and the resulting negative consumer perception of products made from palm oil further escalates. Although we recognize the controversy around palm oil as an ingredient and continue to innovate and create new recipes both with sustainable palm oil and alternatives to palm oil through our patented palm oilfree technology, some of our products contain palm oil and switching to exclusively palm oil-free products may not be currently technically feasible. Following the COVID-19 pandemic, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in February 2022 and the conflict in the Middle East, the global markets and economy have experienced significant uncertainty. There has been a sharp rise in energy and food costs, resulting in inflationary macroeconomic conditions across most major economies and markets where we operate. Given these economic conditions, there has been a significant decline in disposable incomes of many households, creating a cost of living crisis, that has altered the purchasing habits of consumers. In these circumstances, consumers may choose to economize by purchasing non-branded or private–label brands, which may be cheaper than our products. A reduction in consumer disposable income could foster a move by our customers towards discounters and non-branded products, which would impact our market share and adversely affect our net sales. For example, during the year ended December 31, 2023, there has been a slowdown in the growth of our Plant Cheeses driven by the cost-ofliving crisis, higher prices and increased competition in certain key markets, especially in the United Kingdom. The plant cheese segment is a strategic segment for us and we intend to launch a variety of new plant cheese products and continue to further improve the nutritional value and taste of our Plant Cheeses. However, any decrease in demand could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. 26 ----- Our success will be impacted by our ability to anticipate and identify consumer trends and preferences, and to offer a portfolio of relevant products that appeal to consumer needs and preferences on a timely and affordable basis. In doing so, we may also be required to leverage our research and development capabilities, and to utilize management’s ability to launch new or improved products quickly, successfully and on a cost-effective basis. A decrease in demand for our products due to a shift in consumer tastes or preferences to which we are unable to respond in a timely and costeffective manner may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Economic and political instability and/or unfavorable economic and political conditions may have a material adverse effect on our results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Our business may be negatively affected by a number of factors that are beyond our control, such as general macroeconomic conditions, volatility in the global capital and credit markets, geopolitical events, a public health crisis and other general political and economic developments globally and in the markets in which we operate. The years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023 were characterized by macroeconomic, geopolitical and supply chain issues on a global scale, due in part to political turmoil or upheaval in a number of regions and the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite an improvement in global economic conditions in 2021 and 2022 following the sharp global economic downturn in 2020 resulting from the first waves of the COVID-19 pandemic, the outlook for the global economy remains highly uncertain, and certain of our key markets, including Europe and the United States, may not achieve the growth rates that they have forecasted or historically observed. Such uncertainty has been exacerbated by the global turmoil resulting from the ongoing war in Ukraine, which resulted in severe sanctions being imposed on Russia (including certain Russian entities and individuals). Examples of such sanctions include a prohibition on doing business with certain Russian companies, large financial institutions, officials and oligarchs and a commitment by certain countries and the European Union to remove selected Russian banks from SWIFT, the electronic banking network that connects banks globally. The ongoing war in Ukraine has been a driver behind severe market disruptions, including significant volatility in commodity prices, volatility in credit and capital markets, a significant surge in energy and transportation prices, as well as supply chain interruptions, which all have been, and may continue to be, key factors in driving inflationary pressure and which may ultimately adversely affect general economic conditions. Commodities and energy are the two key elements in our input cost base. Therefore, any fluctuation and volatility can have an material adverse impact on our gross profit margin. We shut down our operations in Russia in the first quarter of 2022 before Russia’s invasion of Ukraine due to strategic reasons. In 2022, we experienced minor supply chain disruptions for sunflower oil due to the war in Ukraine. In addition, tensions between China and Taiwan and the conflict in the Middle East have further enhanced the unstable geopolitical environment globally, and particularly in AMEA. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, none of our suppliers are based in Russia or Ukraine. However, further intensification of those geopolitical conflicts or its spread to other parts of the world, including certain parts of Europe, the Americas or other parts of AMEA, could cause supply chain and logistic disruptions and financial market volatility globally. Moreover, market uncertainty and volatility have also been magnified, and may continue to be impacted by, the upcoming 2024 United States presidential and congressional elections, resulting in uncertainties regarding actual and potential shifts in the United States and foreign trade and economic policies. In addition, general elections in numerous EU countries could lead to the exit of one or more other countries from the eurozone or other potential developments, which could be an additional source of instability in international markets. Further, some EU Member States within the eurozone could decide to discontinue their use of the euro as their functional currency. The exit of another country from the EU, or prolonged periods of uncertainty relating to this could result in significant macroeconomic deterioration, including, but not limited to, decreases in global stock exchange indices, increased foreign exchange volatility (in particular a further weakening of the pound sterling and euro against other leading currencies), and decreased GDP in the European Union. Any of these events or market perceptions concerning these and related issues, could undermine confidence in the overall stability of the EU, have adverse consequences for us with respect to our overall performance in the European Union. For example, after the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the EU on January 31, 2020, the EU treaties ceased to apply to the United Kingdom. Following the end of the transition period on December 31, 2020, there were changes in the legal rights and obligations among commercial parties in the United Kingdom and the EU, including (among others) financial institutions, suppliers and service providers and their respective customers.
