Similarly, upon the occurrence of an event of default under the Indenture, unless and until Definitive Registered Notes are issued in respect of all book-entry interests, if investors own book-entry interests, they will be restricted to acting through Euroclear and Clearstream. The procedures to be implemented through Euroclear and Clearstream may not be adequate to ensure the timely exercise of rights under the Senior Secured Notes. See “Book-Entry, Delivery and _Form.”_

Subsection Title: Debt”) obligation created under the Intercreditor Agreement and/or the Indenture in favor of the Security Agent as well
Subsubsection Text: as, or in lieu of, securing the obligations under the Senior Secured Notes directly. This parallel debt structure is used where certain jurisdictions have legal requirements relating to the creation and ongoing valid existence of security interests which are linked with the original secured claims and where certain actions under the finance documents, such as novation, may adversely impact the security interests under local law. The parallel debt is in the same amount and payable at the same time as the obligations of the Issuer and the Guarantors under the Senior Secured Notes and the Guarantees (the “Principal Obligations”), and any payment in respect of the Principal Obligations will discharge the corresponding Parallel Debt and any payment in respect of the Parallel Debt will discharge the corresponding Principal Obligations. _The Netherlands_ Under Dutch law, it is uncertain as to whether security rights can be granted to a party other than the creditor of the claim or claims which are purported to be secured by such security rights. As a consequence, the Intercreditor Agreement provides for the creation of Parallel Debt obligations in favor of the Security Agent mirroring the Principal Obligations of the Issuer and the Guarantors to the holders of the Senior Secured Notes and other secured parties under or in connection with the Intercreditor Agreement. The Dutch law security rights will be granted to the Security Agent as security for the Parallel Debt and will, in principle, not directly secure the Principal Obligations. The Parallel Debt will be at all times in the same amount and payable at the same time as the Principal Obligations. Any payment in respect of the Principal Obligations shall discharge 47 ----- the corresponding Parallel Debt and any payment in respect of the Parallel Debt shall discharge the corresponding Principal Obligations. As a result of the security rights being granted in favor of the Security Agent to secure the Parallel Debt, the holders of the Senior Secured Notes will not have direct security and will not be entitled to take enforcement actions in respect of such security except through the Security Agent. As a result, the holders of the Senior Secured Notes bear some risks associated with a possible insolvency or bankruptcy of the Security Agent. In addition, the Parallel Debt structure has not been tested under Dutch law and, to the extent that the security rights in the collateral created to secure the Parallel Debt are successfully challenged by other parties, holders of the Senior Secured Notes will not (directly) receive any proceeds from an enforcement of the security rights in the Collateral. In addition, the holders of the Notes will bear the risks associated with the possible insolvency or bankruptcy of the Security Agent as the direct beneficiary of the “parallel debt.” _Germany_ Under German law, certain “accessory” security interests (akzessorische Sicherheiten) such as rights of pledges (Pfandrechte) require that the pledgee and the creditor are the same person. Such security interests cannot be held on behalf of third parties who do not hold the secured claim. The holders of the Senior Secured Notes from time to time will not be parties to the Security Documents. In order to permit the holders of the Senior Secured Notes to benefit from a secured claim, the Intercreditor Agreement provides for the creation of Parallel Debt obligations in favor of the Security Agent mirroring the Principal Obligations of the Issuer and the Guarantors (as principal obligors) to the holders of the Senior Secured Notes under or in connection with the Senior Secured Notes and the Guarantees. The “parallel debt” will at all times be in the same amount and payable at the same time as such principal obligations. Any payment in respect of the Principal Obligations shall discharge the corresponding “parallel debt” and any payment in respect of the Parallel Debt shall discharge the corresponding Principal Obligations. The pledges governed by German law will directly secure only the Parallel Debt, and may not directly secure the other obligations under or in connection with the Notes. The “parallel debt” mechanism is not generally recognized by German courts and to the extent that the Notes or the “parallel debt” mechanism in relation to the German law pledges (Pfandrechte) are successfully challenged by other parties, holders of the Senior Secured Notes will not receive any proceeds from an enforcement of the German law pledges (Pfandrechte). Additionally, with respect to pledged assets under German law, German law does not generally permit for an appropriation of pledged assets by the pledgee upon the occurrence of an enforcement event. An enforcement of a pledge governed by German law (such as, in particular, any pledges over shares in any German Guarantor) usually requires the sale of the relevant collateral through a formal disposal process involving a public auction. Certain waiting periods and notice requirements may apply to such disposal process. Thus, the disposal of pledged assets under German law will be subject to statutory restrictions and may be delayed. _England and Wales_ The creditors of the Senior Secured Notes will not have the ability to direct the Security Agent to appoint an administrative receiver or an administrator out of court in an English insolvency proceeding because there will not be a qualifying floating charge (meaning a floating charge over all or substantially all of the Collateral provider’s assets) granted as part of the security for the Senior Secured Notes and the Guarantees. Unless the security for the Senior Secured Notes can be enforced as a “security financial collateral arrangement” under the Financial Collateral Arrangements (No. 2) Regulations 2003 (as amended) (the “FCARs”), the inability of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes to direct the appointment of an administrator out of court could further delay the enforcement of the security interests in the Collateral. In addition, the security interest of the Security Agent will be subject to practical considerations generally associated with the realization of security interests. For example, the Security Agent may need to obtain the consent or approval of a third party or governmental authority to obtain or enforce a security interest in a contract or permit or transfer or sell certain assets. The Security Agent may not be able to obtain any such consent or approval within a reasonable time or at all. In addition, the consents and approval of third parties and governmental authorities may not be given when required to facilitate a foreclosure on such assets. Accordingly, the Security Agent may not have the ability to foreclose upon those assets and the value of the security may significantly decrease.

Subsubsection Title: The interests of the Company’s principal shareholder may conflict with your interests.
Subsubsection Text: The interests of the Company’s principal shareholder, in certain circumstances, may conflict with your interests as holders of the Notes. The Company is indirectly controlled by KKR. See “Principal Shareholders.” KKR is able to appoint its board of directors and to determine corporate strategy, management and policies. In addition, KKR has control over decisions to enter into any corporate transaction and has the ability to prevent any transaction that requires the approval of shareholders regardless of whether holders of the Notes believe that any such transactions are in their own best interests. For example, KKR could vote to cause the Group to incur additional indebtedness, to sell certain material assets or distribute dividends, in each case, so long as the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Senior Notes Indenture, the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement and the Intercreditor Agreement so permit. The incurrence of additional indebtedness would increase the Group’s debt service obligations and the sale of certain assets could reduce its ability to generate net sales or, if the assets distributed or sold are Notes Collateral, could reduce the amount of the asset sale proceeds available to repay the Notes, each of which could adversely affect holders of the Notes. Additionally, KKR is in the business of making investments in companies and may from time to time acquire and hold interests in businesses that compete directly or indirectly with the Group. KKR may also pursue acquisition opportunities that may be complementary to our business and, as a result, those acquisition opportunities may not be available to us. So long as KKR continues to own a significant amount of the Company’s capital stock, even if such amount is less than 50%, KKR will continue to be able to strongly influence or effectively control our decisions. The interests of KKR may not coincide with your interests. 56 -----

_An investment in the Notes involves a high degree of risk. You should carefully consider the following risks, together with other information provided to you in this Offering Memorandum, in deciding whether to invest in the Notes. The risks and uncertainties described below are not the only ones we are facing. The occurrence of any of the events discussed below, whether alone or together with additional risks and uncertainties not currently known to us, could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations or financial condition. If these events occur, the trading prices of the Notes could decline, and we may not be able to pay all or part of the interest or principal on the Notes, and you may lose all or part of your investment. Additional risks not currently known to us or that we now deem immaterial could also adversely affect our business, results of operations, or financial condition or our ability to fulfil our obligations under the Notes and may affect your investment. The order in which the risks are presented is not an indication of the likelihood of the risks actually materializing, or the significance or degree of the risks or the scope of any potential harm to the Group’s business, financial condition, or results of operations. The risks mentioned herein may materialize individually or cumulatively. This Offering Memorandum also contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Our actual results may differ materially from those included in these forward-looking statements as a result of various factors, including the risks described below and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. See “Forward-Looking Statements.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Following the acquisition of our business by KKR in 2018, we began a journey to separate, transform and reinvent our business, building on our existing strong foundations: a global platform with iconic power brands and worldclass knowledge. Our journey took more than four years, with the wholescale transformational part of our journey completed in 2022. To become an independent business, we focused on separating and stabilizing our business, simplifying, renovating and innovating our product portfolio, expanding into new product categories, investing in R&D through the opening of a 62 ----- new Food Science Centre, optimizing our supply chain, building an end-to-end globally scaled and digitally-enabled platform and building a new IT infrastructure. See “Business—History” for a detailed description of our transformation journey. Building on our existing strong foundations and as a result of the significant industrial, digital and cultural transformation undertaken since 2018, we believe we are well positioned to advance the future of food.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are a global leader in plant-based food, established in 2018, as a purpose-driven company with a clear vision: “To make people healthier and happier with nutritious and delicious, natural, plant-based food that is good for you and good for our planet.” We develop, produce, distribute and market plant-based dairy alternative products in over 100 countries across four core categories: Butters and Spreads, Creams, Liquids and Cheeses. Backed by a rich heritage and a global scale, we are highly differentiated in the plant-based sector. Our reinvigorated iconic power brands reflect over 150 years of product expertise and brand heritage and are trusted by consumers globally. Our scale, culture and capabilities, including extensive food technology and innovation expertise, our community of dedicated “Upfielders,” consisting of our management team and employees, and our 14 manufacturing facilities across five continents, provide a strong value proposition for our customers and consumers, and ensure we are well positioned to advance the future of food. Our products are marketed under a family of historic and iconic brands with strong recognition in their target markets. Our products are made with natural and sustainably sourced ingredients. Our carefully selected ingredients come from a diversified supply chain to minimize risk and environmental impact and maximize taste, functionality, health, affordability and sustainability for our consumers. Our operations are diversified across three regions, namely Europe, the Americas and AMEA. We hold leadership positions in the global butter and spreads, and plant cheese segments, with leadership positions in creams in Germany and the United Kingdom, our key creams markets. We sell our products across these regions primarily through retail channels, such as supermarkets, hypermarkets, convenience stores and other outlets. In addition, through our professional foodservice channel, we sell our products to commercial outlets, such as quick service restaurants, bakeries, pizza and pasta outlets, hotels, catering and industrial kitchens, and to the social sector, such as educational institutions, workplaces and hospitals. During the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, our net sales were €2,793 million, €3,375 million and €3,275 million, respectively. During the same periods, our operating profit was €288 million, €453 million and €570 million, and our Normalized EBITDA was €666 million, €749 million and €831 million, respectively. During the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our net sales were €3,209 million, our operating profit was €604 million and Normalized EBITDA was €862 million.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We operate internationally and, as a result, are exposed to changes in various currency exchange rates. We have exchange rate exposure in our key markets particularly in relation to fluctuations of the U.S. dollar, the pound sterling, the Polish zloty, the Canadian dollar, the Mexican peso, the Indonesian rupiah and the Turkish lira, in each case against the euro, which is the Group’s reporting currency. As a consequence, we have considerable cash flow, revenue, costs, assets and liabilities in foreign currencies. Our exposure to changes in exchange rates has affected our results of operations for the periods under presentation, and can mainly be described in terms of translation exposure and transaction exposure affecting the comparability of results. For instance, the significant Turkish lira depreciation was one of the main contributors in the decline of net sales in AMEA, as reported in euro, for the year ended December 31, 2023. In addition, the euro to pound sterling and the euro to U.S. dollar exchange rates have been volatile for the periods under presentation due to various factors including the war in Ukraine, the conflict in the Middle-East, Brexit and partially the COVID-19 pandemic. As a result, we also present certain metrics, such as our net sales growth, gross profit growth, operating profit growth and Normalized EBITDA growth on a constant currency basis, such that these metrics are calculated by excluding the impact of foreign currency fluctuations and both the current and prior periods local currency values are translated into euro using prior year average exchange rates. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information” and “Summary— _Summary Historical and Other Financial Information.” Translation Exposure_ Translation exposure describes the risk of impact that exchange rates could have on the value of sales, costs, assets and liabilities reported in euro on our consolidated income statement and balance sheet. For example, a weakening of the euro against the U.S. dollar will result in an increase in net sales as reported in euro and, conversely, the strengthening of the euro against the U.S. dollar will result in a decrease in net sales as reported in euro. As 25.7% and 25.3% of our net sales for the year ended December 31, 2023 and for the three months ended March 31, 2024, respectively, comes from the United States, these effects may be significant. We are primarily subject to translation effects with respect to non-euro revenues, costs and liabilities, as well as, non-euro goodwill and intangible assets. _Transaction Exposure_ Our exchange rate transaction risks principally relate to purchases of raw materials including Plant Oils, which may have underlying global commodity price indexes denominated in U.S. dollar or may have a degree of correlation with the U.S. dollar (despite underlying indexes being priced in euro or other currencies). We are exposed to a transaction risk since such U.S. dollar denominated raw materials are mainly invoiced to us in euro. Other ingredient and packaging costs (apart from certain commodity inputs) are generally denominated in the functional currencies of the jurisdictions in which our operations (including manufacturing plants and distribution hubs) are located, which in most cases correlate to the markets and currencies in which sales are made. To hedge against foreign currency risk, we use forward foreign currency exchange contracts and cross currency interest rate swaps. We also manage our foreign currency risk by implementing the natural hedge of incurring indebtedness in the various principal currencies in which our turnover is denominated. As a result, we have debt service obligations denominated in U.S. dollars, pound sterling, polish zloty and euro. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We are exposed to foreign exchange rate _risks and such may have a material adverse effect on our results of operations.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: As the cumulative inflation in Turkey over the past three years has exceeded 100%, we applied hyperinflationary accounting under IAS 29 Financial Reporting in Hyperinflationary Economies for the years ended December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2023 and for the three months ended March 31, 2024. IAS 29 requires that the results of our Turkish subsidiary be reported as if these were hyperinflationary as of January 1, 2022. The application of IAS 29 includes: (i) adjustment of historical cost non-monetary assets and liabilities for the change in purchasing power caused by inflation from the date of initial recognition to the balance sheet date, (ii) adjustment of the statement of profit or loss for inflation during the reporting period, (iii) the statement of profit or loss is translated at the period-end foreign exchange rate instead 63 ----- of an average rate and (iv) adjustment of the statement of profit or loss to reflect the impact of inflation and exchange rate movement on holding monetary assets and liabilities in local currency. As a result, a net monetary loss of €4 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024 and of €4 million for the year ended December 31, 2023 (as compared to nil for the three months ended March 31, 2023 and €7 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, respectively) for Turkey has been recognized in net finance costs in our consolidated statement of profit or loss.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The principal ingredient in our Plant Butter and Spreads, Plant Creams, Liquids and Plant Cheeses are refined Plant Oils. Aside from Plant Oils, additional key inputs used in our production process include other natural ingredients, packaging materials and utility inputs such as water and energy. We obtain substantially all of our materials (which includes Plant Oils, other ingredients, flavors, finished goods from third-party manufacturers and packaging materials) from third-party suppliers, with the cost of these materials representing 67% and 68% of our total cost of sales for the year ended December 31, 2023 and the three months ended March 31, 2024, respectively. Plant Oils and other ingredients prices can fluctuate substantially over relatively short periods of time. In particular, price volatility has increased since the outset of the COVID-19 pandemic with prices remaining relatively high compared to pre-pandemic levels, as well as due to the ongoing conflicts between Russia and Ukraine and in the Middle East. Although we do not source sunflower oil from Ukraine directly, as Ukraine is the world’s biggest exporter of sunflower oil, beginning the first quarter of the year ended December 31, 2022, the war in Ukraine caused a global shortage of sunflower oil, which in turn led to a rise in the price of sunflower oil during the year ended December 31, 2022. In response to potential sunflower oil supply chain disruptions, we utilized our “Blendflex” capability, that allows us to substitute and swap ingredients within our Plant Butters and Spreads, such as switching sunflower oil for rapeseed oil, without any impact on the taste, texture or functionality of our products. However, sunflower oil remains an important ingredient for our product portfolio. The increase in sunflower oil prices has also had a knock-on effect on the prices of other Plant Oils, including palm, rapeseed and soybean oil. In addition, palm oil has witnessed significant price swings in recent years, resulting in historically high prices during the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was mainly due to slower production by the main producer nations and the adoption of a domestic market obligation policy by Indonesia, which is the world’s largest palm oil producer, in February 2022. Under the domestic market obligation policy, producers had to set aside 450,000 tonnes a month of their shipments for local buyers. This was followed by an export ban in late April 2022. Although the ban was lifted three weeks later, it created significant uncertainty in the market. Effective from May 2023, Indonesia agreed on lowering its mandatory domestic sales threshold for palm oil producers from 450,000 to 300,000 tonnes a month, allowing for more export, however volatility in the palm oil market has persisted. Other factors which have impacted the prices of Plant Oils, include their growing use as biofuel and the impact of weather patterns, in particular, El Niño (a climate pattern that is declared when sea temperatures in the tropical eastern Pacific rise 0.5 degrees Celsius. El Niño has now returned and is expected to last at least through the first half of 2024, according to the latest United Nations forecasts. Historically, times of El Niño have generally seen a decline in Plant Oils production growth. In addition to significant volatility in Plant Oils prices, recent periods have also seen a significant surge in energy and transportation prices, as well as the supply chain interruptions, caused by recent geopolitical and other events, including the ongoing conflicts between Russia and Ukraine and in the Middle East, and the COVID-19 pandemic. In particular, our inputs suppliers’ cost base has seen an adverse impact in recent periods, which they have subsequently sought to pass on to us. For example, because of the energy intensive nature of the refinery process to turn crude oils into refined oils, our Plant Oils suppliers have sought to pass on their heightened energy costs to us. All of this has exposed us in turn to significantly higher Plant Oils, packaging, energy costs, and as a consequence thereof, higher manufacturing, logistics and transportation costs, which we may not be able to effectively hedge or fully pass on to our customers. To manage our input costs, we regularly monitor global market prices and enter into a combination of fixed contracts and commodity derivatives to protect against volatility. With this approach, through a combination of hedging and fixed price contracts, we generally had price visibility on approximately 77% of our total cost of sales on a rolling six month basis, or 49% of our total cost of sales on a rolling 12 month basis, in each case as of March 31, 2024. We use commodity derivatives (futures, over the counter and tradable forward contracts) to hedge against commodity price risk in respect of the major Plant Oils we purchase, as well as certain packaging materials and utilities. Our policy is to hedge 64 ----- the majority of the risk within the relevant pricing window. The extent of hedging is determined on an ongoing and on a country and/or region basis, depending on hedging volumes and the pricing horizon. Our hedging ratio increases when the exposure/volatility is higher and the pricing window is shorter. All of our commodity derivative contracts hedge future purchases of Plant Oils, certain packaging materials and utilities on a three to six months rolling basis. This hedging policy allows us to weather short term price movements and gives our sales teams time to price accordingly, taking into account the typical cycle of customer negotiation windows (typically, annually and semi-annually in Europe and North America, and less then semi-annually in LatAm and AMEA). Our hedging policy is implemented by our in-house commodity risk management team, and while we do not take speculative views on the market, we monitor our position regularly in line with our in-house team’s assessment. While we generally operate within this policy, in circumstances where it is recommended by our specialist commodity risk management team and approved by our executive risk committee, which consists of senior members of management, we can take longer hedging positions in exceptional circumstances. Due to our Plant Oils inventories and hedging arrangements, a change in the cost of our Plant Oils can take between three to six months to be fully realized in our cost of sales. In response to the significant inflation experienced across our primary inputs in Plant Oils, packaging materials, energy, manufacturing and logistics over the reporting period, particularly in 2021 and 2022, we also increased our pricing through a number of pricing waves, with the last such pricing wave implemented in July 2022. We typically seek to negotiate our pricing with our customers in Europe and North America on an annual basis, and we do so in LatAm and AMEA on a semi-annual or more ad-hoc basis, depending on the increase in cost base and the relationship with retailers and distributors in such market. In addition, with a view to maintaining our profitability and margins, which were impacted as a result of such inflation, we continued other value protection measures such as our value creation program, which focuses on making our business more efficient from an operational perspective and in particular through supply chain areas including, amongst others, procurement, manufacturing and portfolio simplification. Pursuant to the value creation program, we achieved approximately €90 million of savings measured at constant currency, representing 4.4% of our cost of sales for the year ended December 31, 2023. Since the inception of Upfield in July 2018, we have achieved a total of approximately €415 million in savings measured at constant currency through our value creation program and similar initiatives. The continued recovery of our margin throughout 2022 and 2023 reflects the time lag between the implementation of our pricing initiatives (particularly during the year ended December 31, 2022) and the impact of inflation across our key inputs. Inflationary pressures have persisted throughout 2022 and 2023, and we remain exposed to fluctuations in the prices of our key inputs. Our ability to mitigate the impact of such fluctuations through the pricing of our products will need to be balanced against competitive dynamics in our various regions. See also “—Quantitative _and Qualitative Disclosures about Liquidity Risk, Credit Risk and Market Risk—Market Risk.“_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Changes in Food Trends and Consumer Preferences
Subsubsection Text: There are a number of changing consumer trends, demands and preferences which have an effect on both our Group and the industry in which we operate. These include, dietary, health and environmental concerns and trends, such as increasing awareness of different nutritional aspects of foods and the health effects and sourcing practices relating to specific ingredients, an increasing preference for dairy-free, vegan and organic food ingredients, trends towards eating and baking outside of home and concerns regarding public health consequences associated with obesity and increasing awareness of the environmental and social effects of production (in particular those related to palm oil, which is a key ingredient in many products across our portfolio). The food industry, particularly in developed markets and with respect to unhealthier foods and high-fat, sweet and salty options, could also face a softer demand in the coming years because of obesity medicines decreasing appetite and reducing daily calorie intake. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our _Business and Industry—Changes in food trends and consumer preferences may have a material adverse effect on our results of operations.”_ Currently there is an increasing trend of consumers across markets preferring non-dairy plant-based products as a result of the increasing awareness of lactose-intolerance health issues, high carbon footprint and the environmental impact of dairy consumption. Consumers are increasingly prioritizing environmentally friendly product choices due to heightened concerns about climate change, with plant-based options being favored for their lower CO₂ emissions, reduced resource consumption, and longer shelf life. Environmentally friendly packaging is also gaining importance, with a preference for all-paper solutions to reduce plastic usage. With initiatives like the world’s first plastic-free, recyclable tub for our Flora Plant brand and patented palm-oil free products, we believe that our product offering strongly aligns with these consumer trends. In the dairy category, health-conscious consumers are also increasingly turning to low-cholesterol, trans-fat-free options like our plant-based products. For example, our Plant Butter and Spreads have a number of health and environmental advantages over dairy butter, such as higher Omega 3 and 6 fatty acid concentrations, zero trans-fat and lower saturated fat content. See also “Industry—Key Trends.” However, this growing trend towards plant-based alternatives may be adversely impacted by a number of factors, such as misconceptions about “highly processed” plant-based foods, perceived “naturalness” of dairy and increased 65 ----- regulatory control of the plant-based sector. In addition, there has been negative press coverage in recent years as regards products made from palm oil due to both health and environmental concerns. For example, among our key markets, Spain and the Netherlands in particular, have seen a greater negative press coverage and perception as regards use of palm oil based products. In response thereto, we created a patented palm oil-free technology and we have shifted our focus on offering alternatives to palm oil in some of our markets. Although we source certified (segregated and mass balance) palm oil and offer palm oil-free options in a number of markets, there is a risk that additional press coverage and the resulting negative consumer perception of products made from palm oil further escalates. Although we recognize the controversy around palm oil as an ingredient and continue to innovate and create new recipes both with sustainable palm oil and alternatives to palm oil through our patented palm oil-free technology, some of our products contain palm oil and switching to exclusively palm oil-free products may not be currently technically feasible. In addition, following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in February 2022 and the conflict in the Middle East, the global markets and economy have experienced significant uncertainty. There has been a sharp rise in energy and food costs, resulting in inflationary macroeconomic conditions across most major economies and markets where we operate. Given these economic conditions, there has been a significant decline in disposable incomes of many households, creating a cost of living crisis, that has altered the purchasing habits of consumers. In these circumstances, consumers may choose to economize by purchasing non-branded or private–label brands, which may be cheaper than our products. A reduction in consumer disposable income could foster a move by our customers towards discounters and non-branded products, which would impact our market share and adversely affect our net sales. Aside from affecting our net sales, lower sales volumes also reduce the rate of cost absorption, meaning that in periods where key input costs are higher, margins are adversely impacted to a greater degree than would otherwise be the case. We have consistently operated with a clear approach to fluctuations in commodity and packaging costs in regards to procurement and hedging policies and, as a result, have been able to maintain strong levels of profitability after direct costs in changing cost environments. Moreover, our ability to effectively leverage our product development expertise to continually update our portfolio in response to changing consumer tastes, especially with the development of innovative premium products, is a key element of our strategy.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: “Customer pricing” refer to prices that we charge to retailers. We do not set the prices that retailers charge to end-use consumers. The prices paid by our customers for our products are a key driver of our financial results and are affected by a number of external factors. Pricing is mostly driven by the terms we agree with our major retail customers. We typically conduct annual negotiations with most of our large retail customers in key markets in Europe and North America in respect of the supply and pricing of our products in the first quarter of the year. Negotiations in AMEA and LatAm can take place semi-annually or more frequently in some cases. These agreements, often referred to as “joint business plans,” usually encompass pricing, trade terms, support for new innovation, assortment, distribution and shelf space. In some markets, the agreements also include promotional activity for the year, although in most markets it is still possible to change promotional activity and pricing during the year. In 2021 and 2022, on the back of the COVID-19 pandemic and the associated supply chain disruption and the inflationary environment, these discussions took place on a more frequent basis and in some cases pricing negotiations were prolonged. The impact of such prolonged negotiations saw us stop shipments to certain customers during the discussions, which had an impact on financial performance during such period. While there was no material lasting impact on financial performance, there can be no assurance that similar issues will not arise in future years given the competitive dynamics of our industry. In territories where resale price maintenance is not permitted, retailers remain free at all times to set levels of retail pricing, which depends on a number of factors, including retailer margin, demand for our products among consumers and the relative affordability of our products as compared to competing products (which may be particularly relevant given the ongoing cost of living crisis in a number of markets where we offer our products). In particular, the consumer prices of and demand for our Plant Butter and Spreads, Plant Creams, Liquids and Plant Cheeses products may also be influenced by a substitution effect with the market price of competing dairy products including butter, cream and cheese. Butter price increased significantly between 2021 and 2023, driven by factors including higher costs of energy and fertilisers, which we believe has had a positive effect on the relative prices of our products.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our sales have historically been affected by seasonal cyclicality in customer orders in various markets. The extent and impact of such seasonal variations varies among the countries in which we operate. For example, the U.S. business typically experiences a spike in the fourth quarter of the year which is driven by Thanksgiving and Christmas baking. Similarly, there can be some seasonality in sales in Europe and the Americas owing to Easter, which can occur 66 ----- during the first or second quarter of the year. Similarly, in Indonesia there is a peak in butter and spreads usage for cooking and baking during the Ramadan festival season, which can occur in various quarters from year to year. Furthermore, across all the countries in which we operate, the timing of product promotions drives volatility from normal consumption. While our sales are seasonal, many of our costs, such as personnel costs, are incurred more evenly throughout the year, which could affect measures of profitability in the short term and put pressure on our working capital position. In addition, for these reasons, sequential quarterly comparisons may not be a reliable indication of the performance of our business or how we may perform in the future.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our operating results are affected by a combination of economic, regulatory, industry-specific and companyspecific factors. The following is a description of the key factors affecting our results of operations in prior periods and which are expected to affect our results going forward.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Explanation of Certain Income Statement Items
Subsubsection Text: Net sales comprise sales of goods (across our core categories: Butters and Spreads, Creams, Liquids and Cheeses) after the deduction of discounts, sales taxes and estimated returns. It does not include sales between Group companies. Discounts given by the Group include rebates, price reductions and incentives given to customers and promotional couponing. Net sales from contracts with customers is recognized when control of the goods or services is transferred to the customer at an amount that reflects the consideration to which the Group expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services. Transfer of control is generally on delivery to the customer but depending on individual customer terms, this can be at the time of dispatch, delivery or upon formal customer acceptance. Payment of the transaction price is due immediately at the point where control passes to the customer. For the periods under presentation, net sales also included royalty income from external customers.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Explanation of Certain Income Statement Items
Subsubsection Text: Cost of sales includes raw and packaging material costs, cost of conversion (including the depreciation of related fixed assets), logistics and warehousing costs, business waste and other supply chain costs. In particular, other supply chain costs, or supply chain overheads, includes expenses relating to supply chain personnel that are not reported under production, logistics or warehousing expenses, such as demand and supply planning personnel, quality assurance personnel and supply chain leadership.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Explanation of Certain Income Statement Items
Subsubsection Text: Selling, general and administrative expenses include (i) advertising and promotion expenses, (ii) certain research and development costs, which are not capitalized in our statement of financial position data, (iii) indirect central costs and (iv) general corporate expenses, as further discussed below: - advertising and promotion expenses include: (i) advertising expenses (including media spend on traditional and digital media spots, as well as agency fees and production costs for traditional and digital media), (ii) promotional expenses (including the costs of promotion packs and samples, communication material and promotion agency costs) and (iii) point of sale investment (including costs of third-party merchandisers and point of sale materials); - research and development costs primarily relate to the maintenance and expansion of our research and development facilities as well as certain salary and materials expenses. Expenditures for research activities are recognized as an expense in the period in which they are incurred. Expenditures incurred during the development phase of an internal project are capitalized in our statement of financial position data, if the following conditions are met: (i) the technical feasibility of completing the intangible asset so that it will be available for use or sale, (ii) the intention to complete the intangible asset and use or sell it, (iii) the ability to use or the intention to sell the intangible asset, (iv) how the intangible asset will generate probable future economic benefits, (v) the availability of adequate technical, financial and other resources to complete the development and to use or sell the intangible asset and (vi) the ability to measure reliably the expenditure attributable to the intangible asset during its development. - indirect central costs primarily relate to our sales force, merchandising activities, general management, marketing teams and general marketing costs; and - general corporate and local market expenses primarily relate to the finance, legal, IT, HR, communications and internal audit functions. 67 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Explanation of Certain Income Statement Items
Subsubsection Text: Net finance costs are comprised of finance costs and finance income. Finance costs include interest costs in relation to our financial liabilities (including in relation to the Existing Notes, the Senior Term Facilities, the Revolving Credit Facility and the lease liabilities pursuant to the application of IFRS 16 (Leases), bank charges and fees, net monetary loss arising from application of IAS 29 (Financial Reporting in Hyperinflationary Economies) and net foreign currency exchange losses. The costs of issuing borrowings is expensed over the period as they accrue, based on the effective interest method. Finance income includes interest income on cash and cash equivalents, interest income on other financial assets and net foreign currency exchange gain.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Explanation of Certain Income Statement Items
Subsubsection Text: Income tax expense comprises current income tax expense and deferred income tax expense. Income tax expense is recognized in the income statement except to the extent that it relates to items recognized directly in equity or other comprehensive income. Current income tax expense comprises the expected tax receivable/payable on the taxable income or loss for the year, using tax rates enacted or substantively enacted at the balance sheet date and any adjustments to tax receivable/payable in respect of previous years. Current tax assets and current tax liabilities are offset if there is a legally enforceable right to set off the recognized amounts and if we intend to either settle on a net basis or to realize the asset and settle the liability simultaneously. We operate in multiple jurisdictions which are subject to the application of complex tax laws. Application of these complex tax laws may lead to uncertainties on tax positions. Management aims to resolve these uncertainties in discussions with the tax authorities. When there is uncertainty over income tax treatments, management is required to consider the effect of the uncertainty in determining taxable profit (tax loss), tax base, tax losses and tax credits and tax rates.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Operating segments are based on geographical areas, which are Europe, the Americas and AMEA. So as to align with our internal reporting and management structure, beginning the year ended December 31, 2022, we changed our operating segments from “Developed Markets” and “Emerging Markets” to Europe, the Americas and AMEA. We review the performance of segments based on the measures of net sales and Normalized EBIT, and resources are allocated accordingly. Additionally, Normalized EBITDA is used by us within our internal reporting process. Global corporate expenses are proportionately allocated to Europe, the Americas and AMEA based on net sales. The comparative segment information for the year ended December 31, 2021 in our consolidated financial statements of the Company as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022, has been restated as if the operating segments were changed as of January 1, 2021.

Subsubsection Text: Net sales decreased by €66 million, or 7.9%, from €839 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €773 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024. For the three months ended March 31, 2024, our organic net sales declined by 6.3%. Our organic net sales growth/(decrease), which we commenced calculating beginning the year ended December 31, 2023, presents a “like-for-like” comparative growth rate and represents the change in net sales for the current period compared to the prior period, calculated on a constant currency basis and by eliminating any changes in scope between the relevant periods. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information.” Our management believes that the drivers of our organic net sales growth for the relevant periods (which are discussed below) were the key indicators as to the underlying performance of our business. For the periods under discussion, the difference between our organic net sales and reported net sales was primarily due to movements in foreign exchange, especially in the AMEA region, and changes in scope in relation to the sale of our West Africa business in April 2023. Our organic net sales decline of 6.3% was primarily pricing-led, with a negative pricing contribution of 5.1%, and negative volume/mix contribution of 1.2%, in each case, for the three months ended March 31, 2024. Our negative pricing contribution reflects targeted price reductions on certain SKUs, primarily in Europe and the Americas. Our negative volume/mix contribution of 1.2% showed an improving trend compared to the first, second and fourth quarter of the year ended December 31, 2023. Subsubsection Text: Cost of sales decreased by €91 million, or 16.6%, from €548 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €457 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024. The decrease was driven by a decline in the price of Plant Oils, during the three months ended March 31, 2024 as compared to the prior period, and savings of €21 million in relation to our value creation program.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Gross profit increased by €25 million, or 8.6%, from €291 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €316 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024. On a constant currency basis, our gross profit increased by 9.3%, which is mainly attributable to the positive impact of a decrease in the price of Plant Oils, during the three months ended March 31, 2024, and savings of €21 million pursuant to the value creation program, partially offset by targeted price reductions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Selling, general and administrative expenses decreased by €9 million, or 5.3%, from €171 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €162 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024. The decrease was driven by a decrease in costs relating to non-underlying items from €13 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €8 million during the three months ended March 31, 2024. See “Summary—Summary Historical and Other Financial _Information—Key Financial Data.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Operating profit increased by €34 million, or 28.3%, from €120 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €154 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024. Alongside the gross profit drivers (as described above under “—Gross Profit”), operating profit also benefited from the significant reduction in non-underlying costs, mainly driven by reduced restructuring costs and costs relating to strategic initiatives. 70 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Net finance costs increased by €72 million, or 79.1% from €91 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €163 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024. This increase was primarily due to higher interest payments on the Senior Credit Facilities as a result of higher interest rates due to the increase in EURIBOR and similar benchmarks, a net foreign exchange loss of €22 million and due to the fact that for the three months ended March 31, 2023, we benefited from a capital gain of €12 million with respect to the repayment of Polish zloty and pound sterling denominated bank loans, with no corresponding capital gains benefit during the three months ended March 31, 2024.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Taxation increased by €41 million from €28 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €69 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024. The increase was mainly related to our improved operational result for the period, as well as the impact on non-recognized (deferred) tax assets relating to interest carry forward under the Dutch Fiscal EBITDA Rule.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: As a result of the foregoing factors, our net result decreased by €79 million, from a net profit of €1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to a loss of €78 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024.

See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information.” Europe_ Our net sales in Europe decreased by €34 million or 8.4% from €405 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €371 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024. For the three months ended March 31, 2024, our organic net sales in Europe declined by 9.1%. Our organic net sales decline reflects a negative pricing contribution of 7.5% and a negative volume/mix contribution of 1.6%, in each case, for the three months ended March 31, 2024. Our negative pricing contribution reflects targeted price reductions on certain SKUs in certain markets during the three months ended March 31, 2024. The negative volume/mix contribution in Europe showed an improving trend compared to each of the prior quarters of the year ended December 31, 2023, with some key markets in Europe including the Netherlands and Germany returning to volume growth following targeted price reductions initiated during the year ended December 31, 2023. Positive volume/mix contribution in the Netherlands was also supported by increased household penetration of plant-based butter under our BlueBand brand, following the launch of our “Skip The Cow” campaign. The United Kingdom delivered a stable volume performance with particularly strong performance in the Creams category. Volume growth in Austria was backed by our Plant Butter and Spreads and Plant Creams, with the volume growth of our Plant Butter also supported by the rollout of paper packaging under our Flora Plant brand. 69 ----- _Americas_ Our net sales in Americas decreased by €18 million or 5.5% from €325 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €307 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024. For the three months ended March 31, 2024, our organic net sales in the Americas declined by 6.2%. Our organic net sales decline reflects a negative pricing contribution of 3.7% and a negative volume/mix contribution of 2.5%, in each case, for the three months ended March 31, 2024. Our negative pricing contribution reflects targeted price reductions on certain SKUs in certain markets. The negative volume/mix contribution in the Americas was primarily due to some customer destocking in key markets in the Americas, including the United States, Canada and Mexico during the three months ended March 31, 2024 which impacted volumes through the quarter, but all three markets ended the period in volume growth. Volume growth in Colombia was mainly due to the growing market share of our Rama brand in the country. _AMEA_ Our net sales in AMEA decreased by €14 million or 12.8% from €109 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €95 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024. Foreign exchange rate drove a large part of the decline, with the Turkish lira depreciation as the main contributor, further strengthened by additional impacts from inscope changes. These in-scope changes principally reflected the sale of our West Africa business in April 2023. For the three months ended March 31, 2024, our organic net sales growth in AMEA was 5.1%. Our organic net sales growth in AMEA of 5.1% reflects a positive pricing contribution of 0.4% and a positive volume/mix contribution of 4.7%, in each case, for the three months ended March 31, 2024. Our positive pricing contribution reflects the continued strong inflationary environment in Turkey, offset by targeted price reductions on certain SKUs in other markets to address local competitive dynamics. The positive volume/mix contribution of 4.7% was led by Turkey reflecting volume growth across our Plant Spreads and our Plant Creams, as well as volume growth in Indonesia. Positive volume/mix contribution was also supported by steady performance from smaller, growth markets including Australia, Saudi Arabia and the Gulf region. Our foodservice business continues to perform strongly with a broad-based positive volume/mix contribution across key and nascent growth markets, with particularly strong performance in the creams category.

Subsubsection Text: _Net Sales_ Net sales decreased by €100 million, or 3.0%, from €3,375 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €3,275 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. For the year ended December 31, 2023, our organic net sales growth was 1.2%. As discussed above under “—Three months ended March 31, 2024 compared to the three months ended March _31, 2023,” our management believes that the drivers of our organic net sales growth/(decrease) which we commenced_ calculating beginning the year ended December 31, 2023 (and which are discussed below) were the key indicators as to the underlying performance of our business for the relevant year as compared to the prior period. For the periods under discussion, the difference between our organic net sales and reported net sales was primarily due to movements in foreign exchange, especially in the AMEA region, and the impact from the change in scope in the AMEA region as discussed below. Our organic net sales growth of 1.2% was primarily pricing-led, with a positive pricing contribution of 6.5%, partially offset by a negative volume/mix contribution of 5.3%, in each case, for the year ended December 31, 2023. Our positive pricing contribution reflects the annualized impact of previously implemented price increases in the first half of 2023, as well as limited price and promotional reductions on certain SKUs in certain markets during the second half of 71 ----- the year ended December 31, 2023. The negative volume/mix contribution was primarily due to the impact of the increase in our pricing, as well as certain product portfolio upgrade, rationalization and renovation actions and certain other selfdirected initiatives implemented by us during the year which mainly impacted our organic net sales growth in Europe. We implemented these initiatives so as to continue with our portfolio improvement and rationalization program to improve our product offering to customers and consumers and further optimize our operations. On an underlying basis, and excluding the impact of such product portfolio upgrade, rationalization and renovation actions and certain other selfdirected initiatives, our volume/mix contribution was a negative 2.6% for the year ended December 31, 2023. However, during the year ended December 31, 2023, our foodservice business contributed positively to our net sales. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information.” Europe_ Our net sales in Europe decreased by €62 million or 3.7% from €1,661 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €1,599 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. For the year ended December 31, 2023, our organic net sales in Europe declined by 3.4%. Our organic net sales decline reflects a positive pricing contribution of 6.0%, offset by a negative volume/mix contribution of 9.4%, in each case, for the year ended December 31, 2023. Our positive pricing contribution reflects the annualized impact of previously implemented price increases (from the second half of 2022) in the first half of 2023, as well as limited price reductions in certain markets, including the Netherlands, Germany and Poland in the second half of 2023. The decline in volume/mix contribution was primarily due to the strong competition from dairy players in key retail markets in Europe, including the Netherlands, Germany and Poland. In addition, the product portfolio upgrade, rationalization and renovation actions and other self-directed initiatives implemented by us during the year ended December 31, 2023, were predominantly weighted towards Europe, which negatively impacted our volume/mix performance in this region. During the year ended December 31, 2023, several key European markets delivered organic net sales growth, including the United Kingdom, Sweden, Belgium, Spain, Portugal, and Hungary. On an underlying basis, and excluding the impact of the product portfolio upgrade, rationalization, renovation and other self-directed initiatives, our volume/mix contribution in Europe was negative 4.7% for the year ended December 31, 2023. Overall, underlying volume/mix trends progressively improved across the year as strategic initiatives implemented by us took effect and a significant portion of the price increases implemented by us was accepted in the market. Our foodservice business, recorded a net sales growth in Europe led by key markets including Sweden, Poland, Germany, the United Kingdom and the Netherlands. _Americas_ Our net sales in Americas increased by €46 million or 3.6% from €1,273 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €1,319 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. For the year ended December 31, 2023, our organic net sales growth in the Americas was 6.0%. Our organic net sales growth in the Americas of 6.0% reflects a positive pricing contribution of 8.3%, partially offset by a negative volume/mix contribution of 2.3%, in each case, for the year ended December 31, 2023. Our positive pricing contribution reflects the annualized impact of previously implemented price increases (from the second half of 2022) in the first half of 2023, as well as limited price reductions in the second half of 2023 in certain markets, including Mexico. The negative volume/mix contribution was primarily due to the impact of the increase in our pricing in key retail markets in the Americas, including Canada and Mexico alongside some negative impact from our supply chain activities 72 ----- in the Americas region, partially offset by positive volume/mix contribution in Colombia and Brazil. In addition, the product portfolio upgrade, rationalization and renovation actions and other self-directed initiatives implemented by us during the year ended December 31, 2023, as discussed above, also negatively impacted our volume/mix performance in this region. On an underlying basis, and excluding the impact of the product portfolio upgrade, rationalization, renovation and other self-directed initiatives discussed above, our volume/mix contribution in the Americas was a negative 1.6% for the year ended December 31, 2023. In the United States, we recorded stable to growing volumes across all our key product categories. In particular, our brands Country Crock and Imperial both gained share in the butters and spreads market, while Violife further strengthened its market leadership position in the plant-based cheese market. Canada and Mexico both recorded volume growth in the second half of the year ended December 31, 2023. Elsewhere in LatAm, volume trends were more varied during the year ended December 31, 2023, with Brazil and Colombia recording volume growth. _AMEA_ Our net sales in AMEA decreased by €84 million or 19.0% from €441 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €357 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. Foreign exchange rate drove a large part of the decline, with the Turkish lira depreciation as the main contributor, further strengthened by additional impact from scope changes. These scope changes principally reflected the sale of our West Africa business in April 2023, alongside our business model changes in Turkey and, to a lesser extent, Japan. For the year ended December 31, 2023, our organic net sales growth in AMEA was 5.7%. Our organic net sales growth in AMEA of 5.7% was relatively evenly split across both pricing and positive volume/mix contribution, with a positive pricing contribution of 2.7% and a positive volume/mix contribution of 3.0%. Our positive pricing contribution reflects the annualized impact of previously implemented price increases (from the second half of 2022) in the first half of 2023, as well as limited price reductions in the second half of 2023 to address competitive dynamics in certain markets, such as Indonesia and Sri Lanka. The positive volume/mix contribution was led by Turkey and Indonesia, alongside volume growth in some of our smaller markets, such as Saudi Arabia and the Gulf region. Our foodservice business showed continued growth led by Indonesia, Saudi Arabia and the Gulf region, with strong performance in the creams category. On an underlying basis, and excluding the impact of the product portfolio upgrade, rationalization, renovation and other self-directed initiatives, our volume/mix contribution in AMEA was 3.5% for the year ended December 31, 2023. _Cost of Sales_ Cost of sales decreased by €199 million, or 8.9%, from €2,228 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €2,029 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. This decrease was primarily due to a decrease in the price of Plant Oils, during the year ended December 31, 2023, as compared to the historically high prices of such Plant Oils during the year ended December 31, 2022 and a negative volume/mix contribution of 5.3% for the year ended December 31, 2023. _Gross Profit_ Gross profit increased by €99 million, or 8.6%, from €1,147 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €1,246 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. On a constant currency basis, our gross profit increased by 10.6%, which is mainly attributable to the positive impact of the pricing initiatives implemented by us and savings pursuant to the value creation program, partially offset by continued inflation across both commodities (net of hedging) and other costs of sales. _Selling, General and Administrative Expenses_ Selling, general and administrative expenses decreased by €77 million, or 10.2%, from €753 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €676 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. The decrease was primarily due to a decrease in non-underlying costs during the year ended December 31, 2023, including a decrease in supply chain restructuring costs following the sale of our manufacturing facilities in Canada and the Netherlands in the year ended December 31, 2022, as well as a decrease in impairment costs, partially offset by an increase in advertising and promotion expenses and other overhead costs. Non-underlying costs are costs that relate to activities that are not considered to be part of our daily business operations, due to the nature, frequency and predictability of their occurrence, including, but not limited to, business transformation, corporate actions and strategic initiatives, restructuring costs and impairments. 73 ----- _Other Income_ During the year ended December 31, 2022, we sold two manufacturing sites, one in Canada and one in the Netherlands, as well as land in Greece. As a result hereof, we recognized a gain of €59 million as other income. No such other income was recognized during the year ended December 31, 2023. _Operating Profit_ Operating profit increased by €117 million, or 25.8%, from €453 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €570 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. Alongside the gross profit drivers (as described above under “— _Gross Profit”), operating profit also benefited from the reduction in non-underlying costs, mainly driven by a reduction_ in restructuring costs and lower impairments. _Net Finance Costs_ Net finance costs increased by €260 million, or 88.1% from €295 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €555 million for the year ended December 31, 2023 primarily due to an increase in our finance cost. Our finance costs increased by €232 million, or 65.9% from €352 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €584 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. This increase was primarily due to (i) the amendments to the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement during the year ended December 31, 2023, and pursuant to such amendments, we recognized an additional €28 million of transaction costs and a loss of €37 million of unamortized debt issuance costs, (ii) higher interest payments on the Senior Credit Facilities as a result of higher interest rates and (iii) a net foreign exchange gain of €44 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, as compared to a net foreign exchange loss of €16 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. _Income Tax Expense_ Taxation increased by €41 million, or 51.3%, from €80 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €121 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. This was mainly driven by improved operational results which led to an increase in current year income tax expense, as well as an increase in non-recognition of deferred tax assets relating to interest carry forward and foreign tax credits. _Net (Loss)/Profit_ As a result of the foregoing factors, we reported a net loss of €106 million for the year ended December 31, 2023, as compared to a net profit of €78 million for the year ended December 31, 2022.

Subsubsection Text: Net sales increased by €582 million, or 20.8%, from €2,793 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €3,375 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. For the year ended December 31, 2022, our constant currency net sales growth was 18.5%. Our constant currency net sales growth represents the change in net sales for the relevant period compared to the prior period, calculated on a constant currency basis. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information.” Our management believes for the periods under discussion, the drivers of our constant currency net sales growth (which are discussed below) were the key indicators as to the underlying performance of our business. For the periods under discussion, the difference between our constant currency net sales and reported net sales is due to movements in foreign exchange, in particular the appreciation of the U.S. dollar against the euro. Our constant currency net sales growth of 18.5% was primarily pricing-led, with a positive pricing contribution of 29.0%, partially offset by negative volume/mix contribution of 10.5%, in each case, for the year ended December 31, 2022. Our positive pricing contribution reflects (i) the impact of price increases we realized during the year ended December 31, 2022, which involved a number of pricing waves implemented by us between 2021 and the second quarter of 2022 (the last one being implemented in July 2022) and (ii) the impact of certain portfolio upgrade, rationalization and renovation actions and other self-directed initiatives implemented by us during the year ended December 31, 2022, whereby we removed certain unprofitable and low value-added products and replaced them with new product innovations. Negative volume/mix contribution was primarily due to (i) the impact on volume due to the increase in pricing, (ii) the impact on volume due to certain portfolio upgrade, rationalization and renovation actions referred to above, (iii) the impact of our net revenue management initiatives and (iv) the impact of price pack architecture actions; partially offset by the positive impact on volumes due to limited price reductions which we implemented during the year ended December 31, 2022. On an underlying basis, and excluding the impact of the product portfolio upgrade and transformation initiatives, our volume/mix contribution was negative at 6.5% for the year ended December 31, 2022. Set forth below is a breakdown of our reported net sales, reported net sales growth, constant currency net sales growth, pricing contribution, volume/mix contribution and underlying volume/mix contribution by operating segments, in each case, for the year ended December 31, 2022, which are discussed in further detail:
