See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information.” Europe_ Our net sales in Europe increased by €223 million or 15.5% from €1,438 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €1,661 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. For the year ended December 31, 2022, our constant currency net sales growth in Europe was 16.0%. Our constant currency net sales growth in Europe of 16.0% reflects a positive pricing contribution of 26.0%, partially offset by negative volume/mix contribution of 10.0%, in each case, for the year ended December 31, 2022. Our positive pricing contribution reflects the impact of price increases we implemented during the year ended December 31, 2022 and the year ended December 31, 2021, which were in response to the significant inflation experienced across our 75 ----- primary inputs. The negative volume/mix contribution was primarily due to the negative impact of the increase in our pricing in key retail markets in Europe, especially in the Netherlands and the United Kingdom, and volume reduction related to the product portfolio upgrade and transformation initiatives implemented by us during the year ended December 31, 2022. On an underlying basis, and excluding the impact of the product portfolio upgrade and transformation initiatives discussed above, our volume/mix contribution in Europe was a negative 5.2% for the year ended December 31, 2022. Our foodservice business recorded a strong net sales growth in Europe primarily due to growth in the United Kingdom, Spain and Poland driven by additional customer contracts entered into by us. _Americas_ Our net sales in Americas increased by €324 million or 34.1% from €949 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €1,273 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. For the year ended December 31, 2022, our constant currency net sales growth in the Americas was 20.2%. Our constant currency net sales growth in the Americas of 20.2% reflects a positive pricing contribution of 28.9%, partially offset by negative volume/mix contribution of 8.7%. Our positive pricing contribution reflects the impact of price increases we implemented during the year ended December 31, 2022 and the year ended December 31, 2021, which were in response to the significant inflation experienced across our primary inputs, particularly in the United States, Canada, Mexico and Brazil. The negative volume/mix contribution was primarily due to the impact of the increase in our pricing in key retail markets in the Americas, including the United States, Canada and Mexico. In addition, the product portfolio upgrade and transformation initiatives discussed above also negatively impacted our volume/mix performance in this region. On an underlying basis, and excluding the impact of the product portfolio upgrade and transformation initiatives discussed above, our volume/mix contribution in the Americas was a negative 8.5% for the year ended December 31, 2022. In the United States we continued to grow our share (based on value of sales) in the Butters and Spreads category, primarily due to the continued strong performance of our brand Country Crock, our renovated portfolio, relatively stable volumes and strong customer relationships. Across LatAm we experienced strong growth on a price-led basis, with continued momentum in key markets such as Mexico, Brazil and Central America through 2022. Our brand Violife consolidated its leadership position in the plant-based cheese category in the United States, gradually growing its share, driven by the continued expansion of distribution to our key nationwide customers. _AMEA_ Our net sales in AMEA increased by €35 million or 8.6% from €406 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €441 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. For the year ended December 31, 2022, our constant currency net sales growth in AMEA was 23.1%. Our constant currency net sales growth in AMEA of 23.1% reflects a positive pricing contribution of 39.7%, partially offset by negative volume/mix contribution of 16.6%. Our positive pricing contribution reflects the impact of price increases we implemented during the year ended December 31, 2022 and the year ended December 31, 2021, which were in response to the significant inflation experienced across our primary inputs. Positive pricing contribution across the region was driven primarily by Turkey, South and Central Asia and Australia and New Zealand. The negative volume/mix contribution was primarily due to the impact of the increase in our pricing, especially in Indonesia, and volume reduction related to the portfolio upgrade and transformation initiatives discussed above. On an underlying basis, and excluding the impact of product portfolio upgrade and transformation initiatives discussed above, our volume/mix contribution in AMEA was a negative 9.1% for the year ended December 31, 2022. Our foodservice business recorded a strong net sales growth for the year ended December 31, 2022 in AMEA and continued to see positive growth momentum and stabilized its performance in the region following the disruption caused due to the COVID-19 pandemic during the year ended December 31, 2021. _Cost of Sales_ Cost of sales increased by €432 million, or 24.1%, from €1,796 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €2,228 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was primarily driven by the significant increase in the price of Plant Oils, reaching historically high prices during the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase in cost of sales was partially offset by savings of €86 million during the year ended December 31, 2022, pursuant to the value creation program implemented by us. 76 ----- _Gross Profit_ Gross profit increased by €150 million, or 15.0%, from €997 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €1,147 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. On a constant currency basis, our gross profit increased by 12.4%, which is mainly attributable to the positive impact of the pricing initiatives implemented by us and savings pursuant to the value creation program, partially offset by continued inflation across both commodities (net of hedging) and other cost of sales. _Selling, General and Administrative Expenses_ Selling, general and administrative expenses increased by €44 million, or 6.2%, from €709 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €753 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was primarily due to an increase in advertising and promotion expenses and employee costs, partially offset by lower non-underlying costs during the year ended December 31, 2022 as compared to the year ended December 2021. Non-underlying costs are costs that relate to activities that are not considered to be part of our daily business operations, due to the nature, frequency and predictability of their occurrence, including, but not limited to, business transformation, corporate actions and strategic initiatives, restructuring costs and impairments. See “Summary—Summary Historical and Other Financial Information— _Key Financial Data” for details of the non-underlying costs incurred by us during the years ended December 31, 2021_ and 2022. _Other Income_ During the year ended December 31, 2022, we sold two manufacturing sites, one in Canada and one in the Netherlands, as well as land in Greece. As a result hereof, we recognized a gain of €59 million as other income. No such other income was recognized during the year ended December 31, 2021. _Operating Profit_ Operating profit increased by €165 million, or 57.3%, from €288 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €453 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. Alongside the gross profit drivers (as described above under “— _Gross Profit”), operating profit also benefited from optimization of our selling, general and administrative expenses, as_ well as a reduction in non-underlying costs mainly driven by a reduction in restructuring and business transformation costs. _Net Finance Costs_ Net finance costs decreased by €23 million, or 7.2%, from €318 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €295 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This decrease is primarily due to a net foreign exchange gain of €44 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, as compared to a net foreign exchange loss of €65 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, partially offset by higher interest payments on the Senior Credit Facilities during the year ended December 31, 2022, as a result of higher interest rates. _Income Tax Expense_ Taxation decreased by €81 million, or 50.3%, from €161 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €80 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. The decrease was primarily due to decreased non-recognition of deferred tax assets, which relates to interest carry forward, foreign tax credits and net operating losses. _Net Profit/(Loss)_ As a result of the foregoing factors, we reported a net profit of €78 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, as compared to a net loss of €191 million for the year ended December 31, 2021.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity describes our ability to generate sufficient cash flows to meet the cash requirements of our business operations, including working capital needs, debt service obligations, capital expenditures, contractual obligations and other commitments, as well as acquisitions. Our primary sources of liquidity are provided by our cash from operating activities, including our net negative working capital position, and our financings. Our principal liquidity requirements arise from the need to settle supplier payables and fund our ongoing operations. During the periods under review, the 77 ----- liquidity needs of the business were mainly funded from cash from operations (including our net negative working capital position) and borrowings under the Senior Term Facilities and the Revolving Credit Facility. Our business is cash generative and during the periods under review we benefited from a negative cash conversion cycle, driven by longer credit terms received on purchases from our suppliers compared to those offered to our customers. After the consummation of the Transactions, we will continue to have a substantial amount of indebtedness. As of March 31, 2024, on a pro forma basis, after giving effect to the Transactions, we would have outstanding €5,768 million (equivalent) in aggregate indebtedness (excluding the principal amount of lease liabilities recognized by us under IFRS 16 (Leases)), with an additional €567 million of borrowing capacity available under our Revolving Credit Facility. To meet these additional liquidity needs going forward, we expect our sources of liquidity will consist mainly of the following: - cash generated from our operating activities; - borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility; - issuances of debt securities; and - borrowings under other loan facilities. Although we believe that our expected cash flows from operations, together with available borrowings, will be adequate to meet our anticipated liquidity needs, working capital requirements and debt service obligations for the next twelve months, we cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operations or that future debt and equity financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due, including the Notes, or to fund all of our other projected liquidity needs. We believe that the potential risks to our liquidity include: - a reduction in operating cash flows due to a lowering of net income from our operations, which could be due to downturns in our performance or the industry as a whole; - increased commodity costs which we cannot pass onto customers; - exposure to increased interest rates in relation to our borrowings which bear interest at a variable rate, including our Senior Term Facilities and our Revolving Credit Facility; - changes in trade terms, consumer preferences or market conditions which might imperil our ability to maintain a net negative working capital position consistent with past practice; and - higher capital expenditure, such as due to higher than expected expenses incurred in connection with our product innovation and growth strategies. If our future cash flows from operations and other capital resources (including borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility) are insufficient to pay our obligations as they mature or to fund our liquidity needs, we may be forced to: - reduce or delay our business activities and capital expenditure; - sell assets; - obtain additional debt or equity capital; or - restructure or refinancing all or a portion of our debt, including the Notes, on or before maturity. We cannot assure you that we would be able to accomplish any of these alternatives on a timely basis or on satisfactory terms, if at all. In addition, the terms of our existing debt, including the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement, limit, and the terms of the Notes, will limit our ability to pursue any of these alternatives, as may the terms of any future debt.

Subsection Title: Cash and cash equivalents at the end of the period** **225** **221** **317** **189** **204
Subsubsection Text: Our working capital consists of the sum of our inventory, trade receivables, other current receivables, trade payables and other current liabilities. The Group benefits from a negative cash conversion cycle, driven by longer credit terms received on purchases from its suppliers compared to those offered to its customers. Particularly in Europe and North America, trade receivables are net of trade term rebates and trade payable days are significantly longer than inventory and receivables days. Historically, we have managed our trade payables on typically 90 to 120 day terms and managed our receivables on typically 30 day terms. We also offer additional discounts to customers in many markets for “prompt payment,” which is defined as payment in less than 30 days. Our negative cash conversion largely is a structural feature of the payment terms customarily available in the raw material and finished product markets in which we operate, and while there are some risks to our ability to maintain our working capital cycle on precisely these terms going forward this cycle is not expected to shift fundamentally in the future. This cycle is also a result of our operational efficiency with respect to our inventory management. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We are _subject to credit risk with respect to our customers and suppliers.”_ The change in working capital for the three months ended March 31, 2024, was an outflow of €114 million, compared to an outflow of €117 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023, driven by a combination of typical seasonal effects, deflationary effects on payables, alongside some timing impacts on receivables. The change in working capital for the year ended December 31, 2023 was an outflow of €71 million, compared to an inflow of €44 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. The outflow in 2023 was driven by a decrease in payables reflecting deflationary effects, the impact of commodity hedging, and, to a lesser extent, bonus impacts. The change in working capital for the year ended December 31, 2022 was an inflow of €44 million, compared to an inflow of €86 million for the year ended 31 December 2021. The lower inflow in 2022 was driven by a combination of higher inventories, reflecting the decision to carry higher safety stocks, and higher receivables, reflecting inflationary effects. The working capital inflow of €86 million for the year ended 2021 is as derived from our consolidated statement of cash flows, and consists of a sum of inventories (negative €18 million), trade receivables (€73 million), other receivables (€79 million), trade payables (€54 million) and other liabilities (negative €85 million), and, to align with the presentation adopted by us for periods subsequent to the year ended December 31, 2021, further considering the outflow for the increase in provisions for the year ended December 31, 2021 (€17 million).

Subsubsection Text: _ Consolidated cash flow data for the year ended December 31, 2022 is derived from the comparative statement of cash flow data in the consolidated financial statements of the Company as of and for the year ended December 31, 2023. See also note 1.7 (Adjustments For Comparative Purposes) of the consolidated financial statements of the Company as of and for the year ended December 31, 2023 included in this Offering Memorandum. Net cash flow from operating activities_ Net cash from operating activities increased by €40 million, from €32 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €72 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024, which was mainly driven by the increase in operating profit. Net cash from operating activities increased by €19 million, or 3.2%, from €588 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €607 million for the year ended December 31, 2023, which was mainly driven by the increase in operating profit during the period, partially offset by working capital effects and higher tax payments. Net cash from operating activities increased by €32 million, or 5.8%, from €556 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €588 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, which was mainly driven by the increase in operating profit during the period. _Net Cash Used in Investing Activities_ Net cash used in investing activities decreased by €6 million, or 33.3%, from €18 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €12 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024, which was mainly driven by interest income received by us, a deferred consideration of €1 million received in relation to the sale of our business in West Africa on March 31, 2023 and the absence of equity investments during the three months ended March 31, 2024 as compared to the three months ended March 31, 2023. Net cash used in investing activities increased by €48 million, or 60.0%, from €80 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €128 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. This increase was driven by (i) higher net capital expenditure as compared to the year ended December 31, 2022, where we benefited from the sale of two manufacturing sites (one in Canada and one in the Netherlands), as well as the sale of land in Greece, (ii) a payment of €57 million of deferred contingent consideration to Arivia related to the consideration associated with the acquisition of Arivia in January 2020 and (iii) share-based payments to Arivia employees through the cash settled equity incentive plan. This increase was partially offset by a refund of VAT in Indonesia of €33 million. Net cash used in investing activities increased by €12 million, or 17.6%, from €68 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €80 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was driven by a payment of €35 million of deferred contingent consideration to Arivia, related to the consideration associated with the acquisition of Arivia in January 2020. The increase was partially offset by a VAT refund in Mexico of €30 million (excluding interest) from a business acquisition, received during the year ended December 31, 2021. _Net Cash Used in Financing Activities_ Net cash used in financing activities increased by €133 million, from €42 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €175 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024, which is mainly driven by higher interest 79 ----- payments due to higher interest rates, repayments made by us and payment of certain refinancing fees, in each case, in relation to the Senior Term Facilities and/or the Revolving Credit Facility. Net cash used in financing activities decreased by €120 million, or 24.2%, from €496 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €376 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. This decrease was mainly due to higher net proceeds received by us under the Senior Term Facilities pursuant to a refinancing thereunder, which was partially offset by higher interest payments due to higher interest rates pursuant to refinancing and the payment of certain refinancing fees, in each case, in relation to the Senior Term Facilities. Net cash used in financing activities decreased by €150 million, or 23.2%, from €646 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €496 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This decrease was primarily driven by a lower repayment on the Revolving Credit Facility compared to the year ended December 31, 2021, as well as proceeds received from the settlement of foreign exchange derivatives.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Analysis of Certain Consolidated Balance Sheet Items
Subsubsection Text: Inventories are valued at the lower of weighted average cost and net realizable value. Cost comprises direct costs and, where appropriate, a proportion of attributable production overheads that have been incurred in bringing the inventories to their present location and condition. Net realizable value is the estimated selling price less all estimated costs of completion necessary to make the sale. Our inventories are comprised of (i) raw materials and consumables, (ii) work in progress, (iii) finished goods and goods for resale and (iv) engineering spare parts.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Analysis of Certain Consolidated Balance Sheet Items
Subsubsection Text: Our trade receivables principally comprise payments due from customers for the supply of our products. Concentrations of credit risk with respect to trade receivables are limited as our customer base is large and diverse on a global basis. As of December 31, 2023, we had over 2,590 customers across 56 subsidiaries with the top 50 customers 80 ----- accounting for approximately 48% of all the receivables outstanding. Not one of our individual customers had a concentration of more than 4% of the outstanding trade receivable balance. Trade and other receivables are recognized initially at fair value plus any directly attributable transaction costs and subsequently measured at amortized cost. The fair values of trade and other current receivables are not considered to be significantly different from their carrying values. We have a non-recourse factoring arrangement with a financial institution. As part of the arrangement, we transfer our eligible trade receivables to the financial institution and receive an initial part of the transferred receivables. The legal title and rights to the factored receivables have been passed to the financial institution, therefore the control of the factored receivables has been transferred. The transferred receivables are derecognized for the amount that is initially factored with the remaining amounts of the transferred receivables maintained on our balance sheet. The financial institution charges a fixed service fee and interest based on utilization of the facility which are included in finance costs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Analysis of Certain Consolidated Balance Sheet Items
Subsubsection Title: Trade Payables and Other Current Liabilities
Subsubsection Text: Trade payables comprise amounts due to creditors, principally for the supply of Plant Oils used in the manufacture of our products, as well as packaging and distribution costs. Trade payables and other current liabilities are recognized initially at fair value less any directly attributable transaction costs and subsequently measured at amortized cost. The fair values of trade payables and other current liabilities are not considered to be significantly different from their carrying values.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Following our acquisition by KKR in 2018 and our transformation as a separate business, during the periods presented, our capital expenditures have largely been devoted to the enhancement of production capacities across multiple regions. In the short to medium term, we do not expect significant capital expenditure needs, and expect to incur ordinary course maintenance capital expenditure and select investment capital expenditure to support certain key growth initiatives. Such capital expenditures would exclude any impact on our financial statements pursuant to recognition of right of use assets as lease liabilities under IFRS 16 (Leases).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In addition to our indebtedness, we have major contractual relationships with our customers and in respect of our supply chain. We enter into “joint business plans” with our major retailer customers which are year-long contractual frameworks governing the supply of products to such retailers and the participation in joint promotional and periodic discount activities with such major retailers. Precise volumes and prices of products supplied are not typically locked into these contracts in advance. With respect to our supply chain, we enter into cash-settled hedging arrangements with counterparties in the commodity markets to hedge pricing risks. We also enter into physical forwards and spot or nearspot supply contracts with a range of reputable, high-quality suppliers of Plant Oils and other essential inputs. We have a small number of long-term supply contracts with raw materials suppliers, typically in situations where a long-term contract helps such supplier mitigate start-up risks or ramp-up/ramp-down costs, thus improving the pricing terms available to us. Finally, we are party to collective bargaining arrangements in respect of certain of our manufacturing facilities. The maturity profile of the aggregate principal amount of our loans and borrowings as of March 31, 2024, as adjusted to give effect to the Transactions, is as below. The following tables excludes any future interest payment that we would be required to make.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Contingent liabilities are possible obligations that are not probable or not reliably measurable. They may arise in respect of litigation against Group companies, investigations by competition, regulatory or fiscal authorities and obligations arising under environmental legislations. In many markets in which we operate, there is a high degree of complexity involved in the local tax regimes, which could also result in contingent liabilities. Since 2022, Upfield US Inc. (“Upfield US”), a Group company, has been named as a party in a series of alleged putative class action lawsuits. For additional information, please see “Business—Litigation.” As of March 31, 2024, a material loss exposure in respect of these proceedings is not probable or reliably estimable.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Liquidity Risk, Credit Risk and Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity risk is the risk that the Group will face in meeting its obligations associated with its financial liabilities. The Group’s approach to managing liquidity is to ensure that it will have sufficient funds to meet its liabilities when due without incurring unacceptable costs. In doing this, management considers both normal and stressed conditions. A material and sustained shortfall in cash flow could undermine the Group’s credit rating, impair investor confidence and also restrict the Group’s ability to raise funds. We have various credit facilities including a Revolving Credit Facility with a consortium of banks, containing several financial covenants. As of March 31, 2024, €133 million, representing 19.0%, is withdrawn of the total €700 million Revolving Credit Facility. Compliance with financial covenants is reviewed regularly and they are reported to the lenders quarterly in line with the requirements under the facilities. This is based on cash delivery from the business, coupled with the proceeds from bond issuances and other sources of debt. This cash has been invested conservatively with low-risk counterparties at maturities of less than three months. Upon completion of the Transactions, we expect our financial liabilities at that time to comprise principally the Senior Secured Notes, the Senior Notes and the amounts drawn under the Revolving Credit Facility and the Senior Credit Facilities described above under “—Liquidity and Capital Resources.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Liquidity Risk, Credit Risk and Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk is the risk of financial loss to the Group if a customer or counterparty fails to meet its contractual obligations. We are exposed to credit risk from our operating activities (primarily trade receivables) and from our financing activities, including deposits with banks and financial institution and treasury instruments. Credit risk related to the use of treasury instruments is managed on a Group basis. This risk arises from transactions with financial institutions involving cash and cash equivalents, deposits and derivative financial instruments. We have not entered into credit default derivatives. To reduce this risk, we have concentrated our main activities with a number of counterparties which have secure credit ratings. Individual risk limits are set for each counterparty based on financial position, credit rating and past experience. Credit limits and concentration of exposures are actively monitored by our treasury department. Customer credit risk is managed by each business unit subject to the established policy, procedures and controls relating to customer credit risk management. Credit quality of a customer is assessed based on a credit rating scorecard and individual credit limits are defined in accordance with this assessment. Outstanding customer receivables are regularly monitored and any shipments to major customers are generally covered by letters of credit or other forms of credit insurance obtained from reputable banks and other financial institutions. As of December 31, 2023, we had over 2,590 customers across 56 subsidiaries with the top 50 customers accounting for approximately 48% of all the receivables outstanding. Not one of our individual customers had a concentration of more than 4% of the outstanding trade receivable balance. An impairment analysis is performed at each reporting date. The calculation reflects the probability-weighted outcome, the time value of money and reasonable and supportable information that is available at the reporting date about past events, current conditions and forecasts of future economic conditions. Generally, trade receivables are written off if past due for more than one year and are not subject to enforcement activity. The letters of credit and other forms of credit insurance are considered integral part of trade receivables and considered in the calculation of impairment. We evaluate the concentration of risk with respect to trade receivables as low, as our customers are located in several jurisdictions and industries and operate in largely independent markets.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Liquidity Risk, Credit Risk and Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: The objective of market risk management is to manage and control market risk exposures within acceptable parameters, while optimizing the return. The Group’s size and operations result in it being exposed to the following market risks that arise from its use of financial instruments: - Commodity price risk: the Group is exposed to the risk of changes in commodity prices in relation to its purchase of certain raw materials. The key commodities used by us are Plant Oils. We use commodity derivatives (future, over the counter and tradable forward contract contracts) to hedge against this risk. Our policy is to hedge the majority of the risk within the relevant pricing window. The extend of hedging is determined on an ongoing basis on a country and/or region basis, based on hedging volumes (open exposure) and the pricing horizon. The hedging ratio increases when the exposure is higher and the window 83 ----- is shorter. All commodity derivative contracts hedge future purchases of Plant Oils, packaging materials and utilities on a three to six months rolling basis and contracts are settled either in cash or by physical delivery. - Currency risk: the Group’s reporting currency is the euro. Our exposure to the risk of changes in foreign exchange rates relates to operating activities (sales and purchases), borrowings, cash and cash equivalents and derivatives against the functional currencies of the Group companies. The main currencies that give rise to currency risk are the U.S. dollar, pound sterling and the Polish zloty and the foreign denominated loans in these currencies. We are also subject to currency risk in relation to the translation of the net investments of our foreign operations into euros for inclusion in our consolidated financial statements. We manage foreign exchange exposures by transacting as much as possible in the currencies where the operations are situated. Remaining risks are managed within reasonable limits, mainly using forward foreign currency exchange contracts. The aim of our approach to management of currency risk is to minimize foreign currency risk with consideration of the cost to enter into hedge instruments. We do not hedge the currency risk in relation to our net investment in foreign subsidiaries. - Interest rate risk: the Group is exposed to market interest rate fluctuations on its floating rate debt. Increases in benchmark interest rates could increase the interest cost of floating-rate debt and increase the cost of future borrowings. Our ability to manage interest costs also has an impact on reported results. Our interest rate risk management approach aims for an optimal balance between fixed and floating-rate interest rate exposures on expected net debt. The objective of this approach is to minimize annual interest costs after tax and to reduce volatility. This is achieved either by issuing fixed or floating-rate long-term debt, or by modifying interest rate exposure through the use of interest rate derivatives, such as swaps, caps and collars. The above risks may affect the Group’s income and expenses, or the value of its financial instruments. The Group’s objective in managing market risk is to maintain this risk within acceptable parameters, while optimizing returns. Generally, the Group applies hedge accounting to manage the volatility in profit and loss arising from market risk.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Liquidity Risk, Credit Risk and Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: The main risks arising from our financial instruments are liquidity risk, credit risk and market risk as explained below. Our treasury department has overall responsibility for the establishment and oversight of our risk management framework. The treasury department’s activities are designed to: - protect the Group’s financial results and position from the financial risks discussed below; - maintain market risks within acceptable parameters, while optimizing returns; and - provide adequate and sufficient funding to the Group. For further information on the risks discussed below, please see note 19 of the consolidated financial statements of the Company as of and for the year ended December 31, 2023. 82 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Utilisation of tax losses and interest carry forwards: Deferred tax assets are recognized for loss carry forwards and interest carry forwards to the extent that it is probable that future taxable profit will be available against which the loss carry forwards and interest carry forwards can be utilized. In determining the recognition of deferred tax assets, the Group’s assessment of future taxable income, available taxable temporary differences, tax planning, applicable limitations on the use of tax loss carry forwards and interest carry forwards are factors taken into account. These factors are determined in consultation with external tax experts. If actual future taxable income is different than originally assessed, if tax planning fails to materialize, or if limitations on the use of tax loss carry forward apply, the recognition of deferred tax assets may have to be adjusted which may have an effect on the reported tax expense and net result.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Estimation of future rebates and other sales reductions: Sales are reduced with different type of sales reductions and rebates to customers. Where agreements span a financial period-end, estimations are required of projected net sales and judgement may also need to be applied to determine the rebate level earned as agreements may involve multiple tiers. Assumptions used in discounted cash flow estimates: Estimates of future business performance, cash generation, long term growth and discount rates are used in the assessment of impairment of assets at the balance sheet date. 84 ----- Uncertain tax positions: The Group operates in many countries and is subject to taxes in numerous jurisdictions. When there is uncertainty over income tax treatments, management is required to consider the effect of the uncertainty in determining taxable profit (tax loss), tax base, tax losses and tax credits and tax rates. The Group’s accounting policy for uncertain income tax treatments is consistent with the requirements in IFRIC 23 Uncertainty over Income Tax Treatments. The estimate of the potential outcome of any uncertain tax position is to a certain extent judgmental. The main judgmental area relates to the application of local tax laws which may be subject to different interpretations. 85 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The preparation of the consolidated financial statements requires management to make certain assumptions, estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities, as of the date of the consolidated financial statements and the reported amounts of net sales and expenses during the reporting period. Actual results may differ from those estimates. The estimates and underlying assumptions are reviewed on an ongoing basis. Revisions to accounting estimates are recognized in the period in which the estimate is revised if the revision affects only that period, or in the period of revision and the future periods if the revision affects both current and future periods. Additional information about our material accounting policy information can be found in the notes to our consolidated financial statements of the Company as of and for the year ended December 31, 2023, included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Unless otherwise indicated, the historical and other financial data presented in this Offering Memorandum have been derived from the (i) audited consolidated financial statements of the Company as of and for the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023 and (ii) the unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements of the Company as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2024, both included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. You should read the discussion below in conjunction with the sections entitled “Presentation of Financial and Other Information,” “Selected Historical Consolidated Financial and Other Information” and “Capitalization” as well as the consolidated financial statements and the accompanying notes included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. This discussion includes forward-looking statements, which, although based upon assumptions that we consider to be reasonable, are subject to risks and uncertainties which could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by the forward-looking statements. For a discussion of the risks and uncertainties which we face, see “Forward-Looking Statements” and “Risk Factors.” References in this Offering Memorandum, including the discussion below, to “we,” the “Group” or “Upfield” relate to the Company and its consolidated subsidiaries._

Since 2018, Upfield has expanded its strategic category focus and its core categories now cover Butters and Spreads, Creams, Liquids and Cheeses (since 2020) (for a detailed description of Upfield’s products, see “Business— _Products”). As a result, in 2022, Upfield’s TAM across its four core categories, including both dairy and non-dairy,_ equalled approximately €151 billion globally, an increase of 15 times compared to approximately €11 billion in 2017 where the category focus was predominantly on margarine. Upfield believes its existing geographic footprint and product portfolio provide significant opportunities to continue to grow its current TAM. The following chart provides an overview of Upfield’s total addressable global market in 2022, including both dairy and non-dairy, across its four core categories as well as retail and foodservice:

_Source: Industry Data Provider, May 2023._ Upfield believes that its current global footprint and renovated and innovative product portfolio provide a significant growth opportunity within its TAM. Within its TAM (which covers both dairy and non-dairy products), given the growing consumer preference and other trends expected to support the growth of plant-based diets in the backdrop of environmental, sustainability and health concerns, Upfield is well positioned to capitalize on future conversion to plantbased within its core categories, especially given its strong position globally and in the key markets in which it operates (see also “—Key Trends” and “Summary—Strengths and Strategies”). Currently, the penetration of plant-based products in the Butters, Creams and Cheeses categories is low, and estimated at less than 1%. For illustrative purposes, the table below sets out the potential values for the respective plant-based segments of these categories and liquids, assuming 5% 86 ----- and 16% plant-based penetration, with the 16% plant-based penetration being in line with the long-term development of plant-based milk. In addition to the plant-based spreads market which in 2022 equalled approximately €16 billion, there is a potential opportunity for Upfield within the Butters, Creams, Liquids and Cheeses categories of approximately €23 billion (based on an incremental €7 billion opportunity in the above categories when assuming a 5% plant-based penetration) or €38 billion (based on an incremental €22 billion opportunity in the above categories when assuming a 16% plant-based penetration).
_(EUR billions)_

_Source: Industry Data Providers and management estimates. All figures shown in the table are approximations and subject to rounding._ Upfield may also access a broader TAM by expanding into countries in which it currently has no presence (for a detailed description of its current markets, see “Business—Channels and Regions”) and by continuing to innovate and expand its portfolio, in particular Plant Cheeses to address more and more mainstream cheese consumers and formats (see also —“Accelerated Conversion to Plant-based Diets”).

Subsubsection Title: Sustainability in Focus: Benefits of Plant-Based Diets
Subsubsection Text: The way we produce and consume food has significant impacts on carbon emissions, land use and water use. The current global food system is unsustainable: If the diets of G20 nations were adopted worldwide by 2050, it is expected that we would require up to seven planets to support us. Furthermore, the global population is expected to grow by over two billion over the next 30 years while 9.2% of the global population faced hunger in 2022. There is acute focus by governments worldwide on prioritising food security and ensuring that significant increases in demand for food resources can be met. In addition, 38 million square kilometres, approximately 36% of habitable land globally, are currently used for livestock, despite meat and dairy overall representing a low proportion of our daily calorific intake, which thus represents a relatively inefficient use of space for a growing population. Plant-based crops feed more people while occupying less land. Plant-based food uses only 16% of global agricultural land, yet provides 83% of our calories; harnessing this efficiency would feed a 2050 world more sustainably. Plant-based dairy alternatives are the more sustainable option to meet increased food requirements as plant crops require less land, water and other resources than dairy cows. In particular, plant-based dairy alternatives result in significantly reduced GHG emissions and eliminate the methane emissions from animals (approximately 9% of global GHG emissions can be attributed to cattle). Compared to their dairy equivalents, Upfield’s (i) Plant Butters and Spreads contribute 70% less CO₂ emissions and need 66% less land and 50% less water, (ii) Plant Creams contribute 50% less CO₂ emissions and (iii) Plant Cheeses contribute 74% less CO₂ emissions and overall have less than half the climate footprint. Increasingly, consumers are seeking more environmentally friendly product choices because of heightened concern over the environment and climate change. Plant-based products contribute less CO₂ emissions, require fewer resources to produce and have a longer shelf life thereby reducing waste. This is a priority across generations, with 50% of consumers saying they restrict their dairy consumption. Furthermore, retailers named GHG emissions as the number 87 ----- one key ESG topic on which they evaluate their suppliers. More environmentally friendly packaging is also an increasingly key purchasing criteria, with consumers seeking to reduce their plastic usage through all-paper packaging solutions. In 2023, we successfully launched our paper tub packaging technology in Austria under our Flora Plant brand, with similar launches in the United Kingdom and the Netherlands in early 2024. Furthermore, Upfield has taken proactive steps in order to address consumer concerns regarding both health risks of palm oil and its historical association with deforestation. In response, it has created a patented palm oil-free technology and shifted its focus on offering alternatives to palm oil in select markets where consumer sentiment leans towards avoiding palm oil due to health concerns. Since 2019, Upfield has transitioned to sourcing certified (segregated and mass balance) palm oil, underscoring its commitment to sustainability and actively mitigating the impact of deforestation. In 2023, Upfield achieved an outstanding score of 8.5 (out of 10) on the RSPO’s Shared Responsibility Scorecard, placing Upfield in the top 4% of companies demonstrating sustainable leadership in palm oil sourcing. Upfield continuously explores novel recipes utilizing sustainable palm oil and alternative ingredients through its patented palm oil-free technology. See “Business—Procurement.”

Subsubsection Title: Health & Wellness in Focus: Benefits of Plant-based Diets
Subsubsection Text: Consumers have ever greater access to information on nutrition and are more actively considering the health profile of the products they eat and drink. There is increased focus on clean-label products with formulations and traceable natural ingredients, which 33% of EU consumers look for. The food industry, particularly in developed markets and with respect to unhealthier foods and high-fat, sweet and salty options, could also face a softer demand in the coming years because of obesity medicines decreasing appetite and reducing daily calorie intake, thereby driving consumers who are taking obesity medication to healthier options. Upfield’s products are focused on a limited number of natural ingredients: for example, Upfield’s Plant Butter only contains six to seven natural ingredients without the artificial ingredients historically used in the spreads industry. Within the dairy category in particular, consumers are increasingly focused on heart health and are, therefore, conscious of limiting their intake of trans fats and looking for low cholesterol products, including those which use natural plant sterols. Upfield’s products have natural ingredients (i.e., clean label and simple formulations with traceable ingredients) and are demonstrably healthier than their dairy equivalents, being cholesterol-free and trans-fat-free (for example, 100 grams of dairy butter has 3 grams of trans fat). Further, 95% of Upfield’s products beat the benchmark for saturated fats of dairy alternatives and Flora ProActiv is clinically proven to lower cholesterol by using plant sterols. Consumers are also more actively seeking out products which have incremental health benefits and fortified nutrition, such as added vitamins, calcium and healthy Omega 3 and 6 fatty acids. Upfield’s BlueBand contains vitamins and Omega 3 and 6, in addition to having the lowest saturated fat content (36%) in line with WHO recommendations. One portion of BlueBand contains 0.3g of Omega 3, which is equivalent to one portion of salmon, one glass of cow’s milk or three eggs. The above is not at the expense of taste, texture and affordability, which are still key purchasing criteria, as consumers look to buy healthier products with on-par performance at affordable price points. Due to the investment and innovation which Upfield has driven in its categories, Upfield’s Plant Butters and Spreads are, on average, approximately 40% cheaper and Upfield believes that they now have functional performance parity and almost taste parity with dairy equivalents. Specifically, eight out of ten consumers stated that Upfield’s Flora Salted Plant Butter tasted like dairy butter, while 92% said it baked the same, 83% said it cooked the same and 82% said it spread the same. In Poland, in 2023, Upfield was also honored that its new Rama Crema 15% product was recognized as the best new product in dairy creams and cream alternatives by leading trade magazine Handel. What is particularly inspiring is that Rama Crema 15% not only outperformed another plant-based cream but also two dairy options that made it to the final nominees. Upfield believes its Plant Creams have several health and environmental advantages over dairy creams, including a longer shelf life (reducing waste for customers and consumers), greater volume and stability in whipping, acid stable, heat stable and allergen free (where 100% plant-based). See also “Business—Products—Plant Creams.”

Convenience and availability are increasingly important as brands are expected to innovate to meet consumer need states and occasions, such as on-the-go and impulse, as well as the growing baking and cooking categories. This has also caused a shift in the distribution channels through which consumers purchase products, evidenced by the increasing prevalence of e-commerce. To this end, Upfield has developed relationships with various online retailers and e-commerce platforms, such as Ocado, Tesco, Amazon and Carrefour online, which represent a significant growth opportunity in the regions in which it operates, especially in Europe and the Americas. Upfield’s strong retail presence in major supermarkets and at retailers globally means its brands benefit from over 90% awareness across major markets. Furthermore, Upfield’s 88 ----- products are available in multiple formats to meet different consumption occasions and affordability criteria, including sachets, standard sizes and family sizes.

The above trends have historically driven and are expected to drive further conversion to plant-based diets in the future. Plant-based milk was the first category to benefit from an uplift in conversion, with the penetration of plant-based milk in retail markets for Western Europe, the United Kingdom and the United States growing from 5% in 2010 to 16% in 2022 (3.2 times compared to 2010) and being expected to grow to 22% in 2025 (4.4 times compared to 2010).

Upfield’s more sustainable plant-based product portfolio addresses concerns over the instability of the current global food system while being aligned with key consumer preferences for products which deliver on sustainability, are healthier and adapt to changing consumption habits (see also “Business—Environmental, Social, Governance (“ESG”)”).

_Market Positioning_ According to NielsenIQ measurement data, Upfield is a leading branded company in its focus markets, the United Kingdom (number one position) and Germany (number one position). The market trends in the creams category indicate: - In the United Kingdom, the creams category delivered approximately 2.0% per annum value growth from 2017 to 2022, largely driven by growth in baking and cooking, and is expected to grow at approximately 1.0% per annum in value from 2022 to 2027, with baking and cooking volumes relatively stable despite a mild decline in toppings due to increasing focus on health. - In Germany, the creams category delivered approximately 4.0% per annum value growth from 2017 to 2022, mainly driven by growth in baking and cooking, and is expected to grow at approximately 1.0% per annum in value from 2023 to 2027, benefiting from baking and cooking volume continuing to grow with toppings remaining broadly stable. _TAM_ In 2022, Upfield’s TAM for creams, across both dairy and non-dairy, equalled approximately €18 billion globally, of which €14 billion was from retail channels and €4 billion was from foodservice channels.

_TAM_ In 2022, Upfield’s TAM for liquids, across both dairy and non-dairy, equalled approximately €28 billion globally, of which €26 billion was from retail channels and €2 billion was from foodservice channels. 89 -----

_Market Positioning_ According to NielsenIQ measurement data, Upfield held the number one global market share in the plant cheeses category. Additionally, according to NielsenIQ measurement data, Upfield has leading positions across the largest plant cheeses markets globally, including the United States (number one position) and the United Kingdom (number one position). The market trends in the plant-based cheeses category indicate: - In the United States, the plant-based cheeses category delivered approximately 14.0% per annum value growth from 2017 to 2022, mainly driven by increasing adoption by dairy avoiders, and is expected to grow at approximately 14.0% per annum in value from 2022 to 2027, driven by increased conversion as a result of increasingly high product quality and category visibility. - In the United Kingdom, the plant-based cheeses category delivered approximately 15.0% per annum value growth from 2017 to 2022, driven by the adoption of vegan diets, and is expected to grow at approximately 15.0% per annum in value from 2022 to 2027, driven by increased conversion as a result of product quality and a widened breadth of applications. _TAM_ In 2022, Upfield’s TAM for cheeses, across both dairy and non-dairy, equalled approximately €61 billion globally, of which €32 billion was from retail channels and €29 billion was from foodservice channels.

_Market Positioning_ According to NielsenIQ measurement data, Upfield holds the number one global value market share in the butters and spreads category. Additionally, according to such NielsenIQ measurement data, Upfield holds leading positions across the largest butters and spreads markets globally, including strong positions in the United States, Germany and the United Kingdom. The market trends in the butters and spreads category indicate: - In the United States, the butters and spreads category delivered approximately 7.0% value growth per annum from 2017 to 2022 and is expected to grow at approximately 2.0% per annum in value from 2022 to 2027, with plant-based share stable at approximately 25% to 30%. - In the United Kingdom, the butters and spreads category delivered approximately 4% per annum value growth from 2017 to 2022 and is expected to grow at approximately 1% to 2% per annum in value from 2022 to 2027, underpinned by the increasingly popular baking and cooking categories. _TAM_ In 2022, Upfield’s TAM for butters and spreads, across both dairy and non-dairy, equalled approximately €44 billion globally, of which €30 billion was from retail channels and €14 billion was from foodservice channels.

Upfield addresses the market for its core categories through retail and foodservice channels (see also “Business— _Channels and Regions”). In 2022, Upfield’s TAM equalled €101 billion in retail and €50 billion in foodservice._ The current penetration of plant-based products within the foodservice market is slightly higher than in retail, benefitting from the same trends driving plant-based dairy alternatives overall in addition to certain distinct category growth drivers. Foodservice is a strong outlet to drive awareness about and the adoption of plant-based diets and products, driven by customer advocacy and the requirement for suppliers to have quality products meeting increasingly customized expectations, including frying, cooking and melting specifications, as well as taste and texture parity with dairy equivalents. In the retail market, Upfield anticipates significant growth in plant-based categories, particularly in creams and cheeses, outpacing traditional dairy products. Upfield observes accelerated growth across volumes of butters and spreads, compared to pre-COVID-19 levels. From 2022 to 2027, plant-based retail values are expected to grow 3.0% to 5.0% per annum overall, including plant-based cheeses and plant-based creams which are expected to grow 15% to 17% per annum and 19% to 21% per annum, respectively, while plant-based butter and spreads are expected to grow 2.0% to 3.0% per annum. In the foodservice market, plant-based categories are expected to out-grow the broader foodservice market: 15.0% to 20.0% overall per annum volume growth is expected for plant-based creams and plant-based cheeses in the midterm, tapering to 7.0% to 12.0% per annum in the long term, and plant-based butters and spreads are expected to grow approximately 3.0% to 5.0% per annum, driven by a strong customer pull for the functional benefits and price advantages. From 2022 to 2027, plant-based foodservice volumes are expected to grow 4.0% per annum overall, including plant-based creams which are expected to grow 12.0% per annum, while plant-based butters and spreads are expected to be flat. 90 -----

Following the acquisition of our business by KKR in 2018, we began a journey to separate, transform and reinvent our business, building on our existing strong foundations: a global platform with iconic power brands and worldclass knowledge. Our journey took more than four years, with the wholescale transformational part of our journey completed in 2022. To become an independent business, we focused on separating and stabilizing our business, simplifying, renovating and innovating our product portfolio, expanding into new product categories, investing in R&D through the opening of a new Food Science Centre, optimizing our supply chain, building an end-to-end globally scaled and digitally-enabled platform and building a new IT infrastructure. See “Business—History” for a detailed description of our transformation journey. Building on our existing strong foundations and as a result of the significant industrial, digital and cultural transformation undertaken since 2018, we believe we are well positioned to advance the future of food.

We are a global leader in plant-based food, established in 2018, as a purpose-driven company with a clear vision: “To make people healthier and happier with nutritious and delicious, natural, plant-based food that is good for you and good for our planet.” We develop, produce, distribute and market plant-based dairy alternative products in over 100 countries across four core categories: Butters and Spreads, Creams, Liquids and Cheeses. Backed by a rich heritage and a global scale, we are highly differentiated in the plant-based sector. Our reinvigorated iconic power brands reflect over 150 years of product expertise and brand heritage and are trusted by consumers globally. Our scale, culture and capabilities, including extensive food technology and innovation expertise, our community of dedicated “Upfielders,” consisting of our management team and employees, and our 14 manufacturing facilities across five continents, provide a strong value proposition for our customers and consumers, and ensure we are well positioned to advance the future of food. Our products are marketed under a family of historic and iconic brands with strong recognition in their target markets. Our products are made with natural and sustainably sourced ingredients. Our carefully selected ingredients come from a diversified supply chain to minimize risk and environmental impact and maximize taste, functionality, health, affordability and sustainability for our consumers. Our operations are diversified across three regions, namely Europe, the Americas and AMEA. We hold leadership positions in the global butter and spreads, and plant cheese segments, with leadership positions in creams in Germany and the United Kingdom, our key creams markets. We sell our products across these regions primarily through retail channels, such as supermarkets, hypermarkets, convenience stores and other outlets. In addition, through our professional foodservice channel, we sell our products to commercial outlets, such as quick service restaurants, bakeries, pizza and pasta outlets, hotels, catering and industrial kitchens, and to the social sector, such as educational institutions, workplaces and hospitals. During the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, our net sales were €2,793 million, €3,375 million and €3,275 million, respectively. During the same periods, our operating profit was €288 million, €453 million and €570 million, and our Normalized EBITDA was €666 million, €749 million and €831 million, respectively. During the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our net sales were €3,209 million, our operating profit was €604 million and Normalized EBITDA was €862 million.

Subsubsection Title: We are well positioned to advance the Future of Food in a large and growing TAM
Subsubsection Text: We believe that the future of food lies in tasty, high-quality, responsibly made, plant-based food. Transforming the food system by increasing the consumption of plant-based foods in our diets is the key to address the impact of what we eat on climate, nature and health. As a global leader in plant-based food, offering our products in four large and growing categories and selling into over 100 countries worldwide, we are well positioned to advance the future of food and to meet the growing shift in consumer preferences to plant-based eating. To inspire more people to eat plant-based alternatives, we focus on delivering tasty, high performing, healthy, sustainable and affordable products. We believe that there should be no compromise for consumers when they change to plant-based products as compared to dairy alternatives. 91 ----- We benefit from a senior management team with significant experience in the consumer-packaged goods industry. A majority of our current senior management team has been with us since our acquisition by KKR in 2018, and has been critical in our successful transformation. Under their leadership, we have separated, transformed and reinvented our business as a global leader in plant-based food and strongly positioned our business to drive conversion to plant-based alternatives. We believe that our senior management team has also been instrumental in developing a strong and motivated organization with a purpose- and performance-driven culture, which is carried by a passionate and engaged community of “Upfielders.” We believe that our community of “Upfielders” are aligned with our purpose, and are highly motivated to make an impact, deliver sustainable, purposeful long-term growth and advance the transition to a plant-based food future. Our ability to advance the future of food is further strengthened by our portfolio of Plant Butter and Spreads, Plant Creams, Liquids and Plant Cheeses products, sold through our reinvigorated and iconic brands, our global scale and manufacturing footprint, our food technology and innovation expertise which together provide a strong value proposition for our customers and consumers. We offer these plant-based products in our four core categories: Butters and Spreads, Creams, Liquids and Cheeses, which provide us access to a large and growing TAM (across both dairy and non-dairy) of approximately €151 billion as of 2022, which is 15 times larger than our TAM of approximately €11 billion in 2017 under our previous ownership (which was focused on plant-based spreads (margarines)). Our expansion into the Butter, Creams, Liquids and Cheeses categories, in addition to Spreads, resulted in an expansion of our TAM. While currently the penetration of plantbased products in the Butters, Creams and Cheeses categories is low, and estimated at less than 1%, there is a potential opportunity of approximately €23 billion (based on an incremental €7 billion opportunity in the above categories when assuming a 5% plant-based penetration) or €38 billion (based on an incremental €22 billion opportunity in the above categories when assuming a 16% plant-based penetration) (see also “Industry—Upfield’s TAM”). We believe that our global footprint and renovated and innovative product portfolio provide a significant growth opportunity in our TAM. Within our TAM (which covers both dairy and non-dairy products), given the growing consumer preference for plantbased diets in the backdrop of environmental, sustainability and health concerns, there is potential for increased rate of conversion to plant-based products, which we are well positioned to leverage, especially given our strong position globally and in the key markets in which we operate. For instance, according to NielsenIQ measurement data, within our Plant Butter and Spreads core category, which contributed 81% of our net sales for the year ended December 31, 2023, we are the largest producer globally in terms of market share and hold leading positions across some of the largest butter and spreads markets globally, including North America, Germany and the United Kingdom. In addition, according to NielsenIQ measurement data, we are the global leader in the plant cheese segment, and have leadership positions in creams in Germany and the United Kingdom, our key creams markets.

Subsubsection Title: A reinvigorated portfolio of brands reshaping the future of food
Subsubsection Text: With our portfolio of trusted brands we believe we can drive conversion to plant-based food and leverage our strong market positions going forward. Our brand platforms are led by our power brands, our most iconic brands, which have a long history and heritage. We believe that our power brands are deeply rooted and trusted by our consumers and customers across a number of our markets and have high brand awareness in their respective markets. These brands include, for example, Flora (launched in 1964), Country Crock (launched in 1954), Becel +ProActiv (Becel launched in 1962 and ProActiv launched in 2000), Rama (launched in 1924), BlueBand (launched in 1916) and Violife (acquired in 2020). In addition to our power brands, we also have a number of country or region specific brands with a strong local heritage and brand awareness, such as Lätta in Sweden, Stork in the United Kingdom and Tulipan in Spain. Following our acquisition by KKR, we have also reorganized and reinvigorated our brand portfolio since 2018. We refreshed our brands around our end-to-end brand platforms, so as to provide for better harmonization and efficiencies across our R&D and innovation pipeline, sales and marketing and supply chain activities. Our brand platforms are founded upon key prerequisites of taste and affordability, but each platform serves a distinct consumer need and is mapped against the key usage occasions and growth opportunities across our categories and markets. We also organize our brands across three different price tiers: “good,” (targeting price sensitive customers) “better” (targeting customers looking for additional product benefits at a more affordable price than a dairy alternative) and “best” (targeting customers seeking premium products with multiple features, such as lowering cholesterol). We assign our brands and products across these tiers which are each designed to meet distinct consumer needs and cater for certain price sensitivities, thereby catering to various social demographic needs. We believe that such categorization simplifies consumer decision-making and helps us strategically position each tier to appeal to a different array of consumers. 92 -----

We operate an end-to-end globally scaled and digitally-enabled platform, in which we have made significant investment in recent years, and through which we produce and sell our products to retail and foodservice partners in over 100 countries globally. We operate a global network of manufacturing facilities and regional cold chain distribution centers with capabilities to support growth. Our historic strong cash generation has enabled us to invest significantly in our global operations, ensuring we have the latest manufacturing innovations at our disposal. We own a total of 14 manufacturing facilities, comprising seven in Europe, four in the Americas and three in AMEA. These facilities produced approximately 91% of our total production volume for the year ended December 31, 2023. Our comprehensive manufacturing network with a globally scaled and digitally-enabled supply chain, is well positioned for future growth. Our end-to-end platform is supported by our general ERP system and our SAP4Hana ERP system, which enable us to make data-driven operational decisions. Our robust in-house manufacturing capabilities allow for complete control and flexibility in the manufacturing process, through which we can (i) maintain a closer level of control over our robust quality and safety standards, (ii) better establish and control cost savings, (iii) limit and control manufacturing disruptions, (iv) reduce our carbon footprint and (v) manage the manufacturing process more efficiently. Our products and customers further benefit from our internal centralized procurement function designed to leverage our purchasing expertise and maximize scale efficiencies across the regions where we operate. Our procurement function has a deep understanding of commodity cycles and risk management, and many years of experience in the oils market. See “Business—Procurement” for a detailed description of our procurement function.

Subsubsection Title: An industry leading R&D expertise delivering innovation and driving conversion to plant-based food
Subsubsection Text: Our strong innovation pipeline underpins our mission to revolutionize the plant-based ecosystem by delivering tastier, high-quality products with natural ingredients. That pipeline is driven by our investment in R&D, oils & fats and plant-based proteins amongst other enabling technologies, with food science at its core. We believe that we have an industry leading R&D expertise that enables us to produce new and innovative products using key ingredient know-how, technically sophisticated equipment and processes across our core categories and products. As an insights-driven organization we seek to continually enhance consumer experience with respect to taste, functionality, health and nutrition, sustainability and affordability by developing relevant product and packaging innovation. We continuously invest in food innovation and food technology expertise from our new state-of-the-art food science centre in Wageningen, the Netherlands (“Food Science Centre”), which we have developed with an investment capital of approximately €38 million. Our Food Science Centre focuses on plant-based food innovation and it aims to pioneer the development of plant-based foods, enabling technologies including oils and fats as well as proteins, and sustainable packaging solutions. Our team of more than 150 food scientists, food and packaging technologists and specialists focus on the development of plant-based foods and sustainable packaging solutions. We are also a leading filer of plant-based patents, and hold 656 patents and patent applications. In 2023, we applied for a further ten patents across our categories and core technologies. With our deep expertise in plant-based and natural ingredients and proprietary knowledge of plant-based food manufacturing, we have implemented a significant product portfolio overhaul since 2018, focused on taste, clean label and naturalness, where possible. For instance, we developed our first-generation Plant Butter product between 2018 and 2020, which we have since then further evolved, offering products we aim to achieve taste parity as compared to dairy butter. We have also developed new recipes and ingredients for our products, for example to provide consumers with palm oil-free options through our patented technology. In 2023, we successfully launched our paper tub packaging technology in Austria under our Flora Plant brand, with similar launches in the United Kingdom and the Netherlands in early 2024. Our R&D and innovation roadmap is centered on continuous improvement and innovation within our core categories, to attract more and more consumers and broaden the appeal of our products. Key areas of focus include further improving our Plant Cheese product range, in particular in cold applications to further improve our Plant Cheese offering and applying some of our developing technology to further improve our Plant Butters and Plant Creams products. In addition, we continue to develop our packaging technology to create sustainable packaging and achieve our goal to reduce the environmental impact of our packaging through reduced plastic usage and increased recyclability of our packaging. As well as innovating internally to achieve these goals, we partner with academia, established ingredients and packaging players, start-ups and scale-ups whose differentiated propositions we believe can complement our R&D capabilities and our ability to scale through our distribution channels, platform and growth levers. 93 -----

Subsubsection Title: Growth levers underpinned by a resilient, attractive financial profile with high cash generation
Subsubsection Text: Our growth levers are centered around driving conversion from dairy products to our plant-based products and involve: - Creating the best-ever products made by us: delivering tastier, high-quality products with natural ingredients in our four core categories, underpinned by a strong innovation pipeline; - Deploying our power brands: leveraging our iconic power brands, recognized and trusted across markets, with clear propositions; - Executing in multiple channels: reaching as many people as possible by executing well within our channels: retail and foodservice; and - Driving and leveraging our scale: leveraging our digitally enabled end-to-end platform and scale. Our transformation journey since 2018 has taken place against a turbulent and volatile backdrop of events including a global pandemic, associated supply chain challenges, commodity inflation and the ongoing cost-of-living crisis. However, during this period, by leveraging our growth levers, we have demonstrated a track record of stable financial performance, in particular delivered strong growth in organic net sales, gross profit and Normalized EBITDA. Between the year ended December 31, 2021 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our reported net sales increased at a CAGR of 6.4%, our gross profit increased at a CAGR of 11.4% and our Normalized EBITDA increased at a CAGR of 12.1%. We have also demonstrated strong cash generation, and generated a normalized free cash flow and normalized free cash conversion ratio of €702 million and 81.4%, respectively, in each case, for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. We believe this compares favorably with our peers and is supported by, among other things: - our flexible cost base, which allows for a sustainable gross margin. We have clear, consistent and wellestablished supply chain, and hedging policies with respect to our major inputs and foreign exchange exposures, which has allowed us to maintain strong levels of profitability in periods of fluctuations and under high inflationary conditions; - our sustained profitability, with a Normalized EBITDA margin of 23.8%, 22.2%, 25.4% and 26.9%, in the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, respectively, largely attributable to our flexible cost structure, our powerful brands, our revenue growth management capabilities and our track record of operational cost savings; - a favorable working capital position, as we benefit from a negative cash conversion cycle. This largely is a structural feature of the payment terms customarily available in the raw material and finished product markets in which we operate and our operational efficiency with respect to our inventory management; and - our comprehensive manufacturing network with a globally scaled and digitally-enabled supply chain and significant spare capacity. This allows for increased net sales volumes without incremental capital expenditure resulting in strong cash generation. Our strong cash generation and resulting Normalized EBITDA growth has helped us to progressively deleverage. For the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our historical leverage ratio was 8.4x, 7.2x, 6.5x and 6.5x, respectively. Our historical leverage ratio represents the ratio of our (i) net debt, which is defined as our financial liabilities gross of unamortized financing fees less cash and cash equivalents, excluding lease liabilities and derivative financial instruments to (ii) Normalized EBITDA.
