_Creating the best-ever products made by us: delivering tastier, high-quality products with natural ingredients in our four core categories, underpinned by a strong innovation pipeline_ Since 2018, we have reinvented our product portfolio, investing significant resources to create the best-ever products made by us, including by harmonizing and simplifying our ingredients list and moving towards fewer, natural and fully plant-based ingredients. We are focused on delivering our best-ever products that are designed to have the same or superior taste, versatility and performance (cooking, baking, and spreading) as dairy products. We believe that there should be no compromise for consumers when they change to a plant-based butter or spread, liquid, plant-based cream or plant-based cheese, as compared to dairy alternatives. For example, our Plant Butter is specifically formulated with the aim to match the performance and taste of dairy butter. Based on more than 50 taste profiles, we created a series of plant butters which we strive to taste and perform just like dairy butter and that match the specific taste preferences of different consumer profiles in key markets. Also, our know-how and expertise of natural ingredients has enabled us to simplify our Plant Butter to contain just six or seven natural ingredients (including certain Plant Oils, water, plant protein and, in some cases, salt) and enable consumers to swap it directly for dairy butter in any recipe. Consumers are also increasingly focused on clean label and naturalness, and 99% of all our ingredients by volume are natural in origin. We continue to invest in R&D to deliver products using recipes made from natural ingredients or products that are free from artificial colors, flavors and preservatives, and without compromising on food safety, quality and performance. In addition, as part of our commitment to be 100% plant-based by the end of 2030, we are continuously reviewing our use of dairy ingredients where there is no compromise in taste or performance. Aside from taste and performance, we focus on the nutritional benefits of our products, as well as their positive contribution to health. Health is a high priority for consumers and a key reason why people choose our products. In 2022, our team of nutritionists and product developers created the Upfield nutritional benchmarking program, based on what science tells us is required for each different product proposition and which introduced saturated fat and trans-fat targets for plant creams and plant cheeses. This helps us ensure that we meet nutritional targets in our products and are aligned with international dietary guidelines and regulations. Our plant-based products contain zero trans-fats and lower saturated fats compared to dairy alternatives. So, whether consumers are looking for a product to bake a cake, help lower their cholesterol or containing the nutrients to support a growing family, our products strive to provide a “no compromise” choice, that is better for consumers and better for the planet. _Deploying our power brands: leveraging our iconic power brands, recognized, trusted and loved over the world with clear propositions_ Our business traces its origin and heritage back over 150 years and, as a result, many of our reinvigorated iconic power brands, including BlueBand and Rama, have a brand heritage spanning over 100 years. Our power brands, including as an example, Flora, Country Crock, Becel +ProActiv, Rama, BlueBand and Violife, are trusted in their key markets globally and are at the heart of our future growth strategy and success. Our power brands are well-known and have a high brand awareness amongst consumers in our markets. They represent the platform from which we have successfully launched our product innovations and portfolio renovation. Through our power brands we engage with both loyal and new consumers, offering people a positive choice, both as a plant-based alternative to dairy and also for less competitive brands and private label. Based on independent brand research, many of our power brands are among the best-performing FMCG/packaged grocery brands across our key markets in terms of brand awareness. We believe that the high score of our power brands indicate that consumers are more likely to choose our brands over others, which is a strong indicator of increasing brand influence and share. To further support our power brands, we complemented the ongoing innovation across our portfolio with an increase in strategic advertising and promotion investment. For the year ended December 31, 2023, our advertising and promotion expenses amounted to €173 million (equalling 5.3% of our net sales for the year ended December 31, 2023 and an increase of 22.7% compared to the year ended December 31, 2022). For example, in 2023, we launched our “Skip the Cow” campaign aimed at informing and driving consumers towards more plant-based products. Our “Skip the Cow” campaign pushed the uptake of Flora Plant and has proved to be a valuable resource in boosting consumer awareness of our Plant Butter offering and also contributed to a strong positive consumer net sentiment of 86% towards our overall Flora brand. Furthermore, following the “Skip the Cow” campaign, Flora Plant Butter experienced growth in household penetration and share of segment in the United Kingdom. Following the success of the “Skip the Cow” campaign in the United Kingdom, we launched similar campaigns across European markets, such as Germany and Austria, and intend to also roll it out to other key markets such as the Netherlands, Poland or Spain, and also across other brands. To further leverage the 95 ----- strength of our brands, we have from time to time considered, and continue to consider and evaluate, modifications to our corporate branding and identity to more closely align with our key brands. _Executing in multiple channels: reaching as many people as possible through our channels: retail and foodservice_ We also differentiate ourselves through our retail and professional foodservice channels, which enable us to reach consumers directly through both industry channels. We sell our products to retail outlets, including to many of the world’s largest retailers, as well as to wholesalers. We also enhanced our e-commerce capabilities by developing relationships with various online retailers and e-commerce platforms, such as Ocado, Tesco, Amazon and Carrefour online, which have seen an increase in retail market share in recent years and which we believe represent a significant growth opportunity in the regions in which we operate, especially in Europe and the Americas. In addition, in emerging markets in which we operate across our regions, we have established a strong market channel based on deep relationships with well-known and reputable distributors. Through our foodservice channel, we also supply the professional channel, including restaurants, hotels and industrial kitchens. This multi-channel approach gives us access to a broad and diverse customer base, which enhances our position as a leader in many of our core categories. Because of our strong relationships with leading global and regional retailers, we operate as the supplier of choice and/or “category captain” for certain strategic retailers, providing in-depth knowledge and consumer insight for particular product categories to our retailer customers. Moreover, we believe there is considerable potential to introduce and expand our core product categories in the foodservice channel given our current portfolio’s appeal across high-end clients who lead and influence the menu adoption cycle to large quick-service restaurants, bakery chains and other national accounts where mass adoption occurs. Our growth strategy in foodservice is focused on selling value-added branded products with high-demand applications to commercial customers and driving customer acquisition through our chef-led sales approach (see also “—Sales and _Marketing”). Driving and leveraging our scale: leveraging our digitally enabled end-to-end platform and scale_ Through our end-to-end globally scaled and digitally-enabled platform we produce and sell our products to retail and foodservice partners in over 100 countries globally. Our global footprint, scale and expertise along the value chain allow us to leverage efficiencies through which we can derive significant advantages compared to other plant-based competitors and dairy players. Since 2018, we have demonstrated a track record in driving efficiencies for example by establishing product portfolio efficiencies (through the retirement of SKUs that are less profitable or of low productivity and the simplification of our recipes), procurement efficiencies (by sourcing most of our ingredients and packaging materials from global suppliers who can deliver locally), supply chain efficiencies (through our established local retail and distribution network) and by maintaining a continued focus on operational efficiencies in line with our value creation program. Establishing such efficiencies allows us to offer affordable products.

Our purpose is “to make people healthier and happier with nutritious and delicious, natural, plant-based food that is good for you and for our planet” and it shapes how we approach the sourcing of our ingredients, the development of our recipes, our relationships with retailers and how we communicate with consumers. We intend to continue fulfilling our purpose with our commitment and initiatives across our four pillars: (i) plant-based, (ii) healthier lives, (iii) happier people and (iv) better planet, which are at the heart of our business with tangible programs and milestones. _Plant-Based_ Actively helping the food transition and building a better, plant-based future is at the heart of what we do. Our plant-based commitment pillar seeks to help inspire and encourage consumers to switch from dairy to plant-based options. As we continue to improve our product portfolio, we aim to reach one billion consumers with our products by 2030. We believe we can achieve that goal by offering consumers a range of products that meet their needs, which also includes making sure our products taste great, perform well, and are made with simple, natural ingredients. We believe we are in a strong position to support the transition to a plant-based diet by offering tasty, affordable, nutritious and more sustainable products. From our Food Science Centre, we continuously invest in high performance product formulations and reformulations to keep up with consumer needs and trends. For example, in 2023, we launched the Violife cream cheese block in the United States which has been developed specifically to compete with leading dairy cream cheeses on the market, following a completely new formulation and format. To spread awareness around our plant-based products, we frequently launch retail consumer advertising campaigns with slogans aimed at informing and driving consumers and professionals towards more plant-based products. 96 ----- Other efforts to boost our brands’ and products’ visibility include, for example, sponsorship of sporting events and partnerships with celebrities and influencers. In addition, we are also working to support the industry moving forward in terms of plant-based innovation, which includes establishing standard parameters for plant-based products. For example, we are currently leading the development of a new ISO standard that we expect will specify technical definitions of, and criteria for, plant-based foods. We believe that this new ISO standard will help align the global food industry around a single terminology approach. _Healthier Lives_ The second pillar focuses on the nutritional benefits of our products as well as their positive contribution to health. Health is a high priority for consumers and we believe is a key reason why people choose our products. We aim for our products to outperform their dairy counterparts with respect to levels of saturated and trans-fats. We take a sciencebased approach to establishing criteria and targets for each product type we sell, considering who uses them, how frequently and in which applications. These targets are based on recognized external international standards and official dietary recommendations, including those from the World Health Organization. Moreover, we have set additional targets that ensure we can deliver the desired nutritional composition. These include considerations on how we can limit nutrients of concern and provide essential nutrients that target some of the greatest public health areas of concern, such as heart health and children’s growth and development. Our brands BlueBand and Becel +ProActiv are our global brands focused on positively impacting lives across the world by offering healthy, affordable and nutritious options. In 2023, approximately 30% of our net sales came from products providing health and nutrition benefits and that can be labelled as such, in compliance with regulation. Additionally, we believe the future of food lies in quality, responsibly made, plant-based foods. To realize this future and provide consumers with healthier options, we intend to continue implementing rigorous quality and safety standards at both our and third-party facilities, including for product design, formulation, raw material sourcing, packing, manufacturing, storage, transport, display, marketing, communication, sales and product disposal. Moreover, we intend to continue ensuring that our products are accessible to as many people as possible, which includes ensuring our products come in at affordable price points. In this regard we intend to maintain a portfolio of products designed for budgetary brackets across the market spectrum and which are more affordable than dairy alternatives, without compromising on quality. _Happier People_ We believe that people are happier when they are engaged and we actively promote a culture of active support. We are committed to our community of dedicated “Upfielders.” Our approach to employee engagement is driven by three core values: performance, care and passion. To nurture an engaged workforce, we complete an annual survey to gauge employee sentiment and opportunities for progress. In addition, diverse businesses are likely to be more successful and we are committed to creating a diverse and inclusive working environment. Across our supply chains, we are connected to thousands of farmers and plant-based entrepreneurs who grow our ingredients and chefs who create and prepare millions of meals every day. In support of farmers and plant-based entrepreneurs, we maintain several partnerships, enabling and encouraging them to improve agricultural practices and access to markets. In addition, we seek to reach as many chefs and food service professionals as possible to encourage the adoption of our products into their cooking, thereby engaging chefs in the plant-based revolution. We do this by, for example, hosting cooking workshops for chefs or participating in trade fairs where we can reach out and educate professionals on the advantages of plant-based cooking. _Better Planet_ With an environmental footprint significantly smaller than that of dairy products, our products can help consumers reduce their impact, and we ensure our operations do so as well. We are committed to responsibly sourcing ingredients, developing sustainable packaging and addressing our carbon emissions to enhance sustainability. Our better planet commitments include our environmental targets to address our material environmental impacts on the climate, on packaging and on responsible sourcing. For the year ended December 31, 2023, we committed to Science Based Target Initiative (“SBTi”) and have worked on redefining our targets in line with the newly published Forest, Land and Agriculture (“FLAG”) guidance to align with limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius above preindustrial levels. In this respect, we are making multiple efforts towards reducing our emissions and reducing environmental impact through waste and water management at our manufacturing facilities. In addition, we are committed to providing packaging that protects products and the planet. We delivered a milestone packaging achievement with the 97 ----- launch of the world’s first paper-based tub for plant-based butters and spreads, our Flora Plant paper tub at the end of 2023, starting our journey towards our target of reducing plastic across our portfolio by 80% by 2030 (compared to a 2020 baseline). In addition, we are committed to responsible and sustainable sourcing of our ingredients (including our Plant Oils) and packaging materials (including paper and pulp) and our “Responsible Sourcing Policy” and “Business Partner Code of Conduct” applies to all our suppliers. Where key ingredients are identified as potentially high risk, we maintain strong individual policies designed to address the potential risks inherent in these supply chains, particularly focussing on deforestation and exploitation. See also “Business— Environmental, Social, Governance (“ESG”).”

Our strategies are focused on the continued implementation of our growth levers to capture the key opportunities across our core categories and markets. Our clear mission and purpose forms the cornerstone of our strategy to deliver long term sustainable, profitable and purposeful growth by bringing tasty plant-based foods to people all over the world, and achieve our purpose “to make people healthier and happier with nutritious and delicious, natural, plant-based food that is good for you and for our planet.” 94 -----

Upfield was established in 2018, as a purpose-driven company with a clear vision: “To make people healthier and happier with nutritious and delicious, natural, plant-based food that is good for you and good for our planet.” While Upfield is a young company, our business traces its origin and heritage back over 150 years, when the Jurgens family bought the patent for Plant Spreads. Many of our iconic power brands have brand heritage spanning over 100 years and under its prior ownership, our business evolved into one of the earliest large-scale producers of dairy alternatives globally, focused on plant-based spreads. Following the acquisition of Upfield by KKR in 2018, we began a journey to separate, transform and reinvent the business, building on our existing strong foundations: a global platform with iconic power brands and world-class knowledge. Building on these foundations and as a result of the significant industrial, digital and cultural transformation undertaken since 2018, Upfield has established itself as a global leader in plant-based food, operating in multiple categories with a global end-to-end supply chain. At the outset, we formulated and adopted our Upfield manifesto, with a clear, purpose-driven vision and a datadriven mission to guide us as an independent company. During the last five years, we have invested over €1.6 billion to reinvent our business: by simplifying, renovating and innovating our existing product portfolio, expanding into new product categories and investing in our end-to-end supply chain while further investing and developing our IT system. In the initial separation and stabilization phase, we exited more than 600 transitional service agreements that were still in place from Upfield’s previous owner, built our fully digital, cloud-based Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) system and completed the complex separation from Unilever to become a fully independent business by June 2020. Prior to KKR’s ownership, Upfield’s business was largely focused on margarine. As a first step, we began innovating our margarine and spreads business by working towards clean label products and developing palm oil-free recipes. Gradually we shifted and expanded our category focus by developing and launching our Plant Butter offering, specifically formulated to aim to replicate the performance and taste of dairy butter. By 2019, we reprioritized our Creams and Liquids core categories and achieved volume growth in these categories. In January 2020, we expanded into the Cheese category following the acquisition of Arivia, a leading producer of plant-based cheese through Violife. Since 2018, we have undertaken a significant innovation and renovation program across our product portfolio, introducing natural, plant-based ingredients and harmonizing and rationalizing the number of SKUs and recipes to focus on fewer but better products. For example, we have upgraded and renovated a significant proportion of our product portfolio since 2018, with approximately 85% of our European spreads sales in 2022 being from products renovated or innovated since 2020, to retire SKUs which were less profitable or of low productivity, such that we operate with approximately 1,200 active SKUs as of the third quarter of 2023 (down from 2,600 SKUs in 2018), excluding Plant Cheeses. Furthermore, we restructured our portfolio of distinct recipes from over 340 distinct recipes for Plant Butter and Spreads in Europe in 2018 to focus on 18 chassis. We harmonized and aligned our brand portfolio into key end-to-end brand platforms which allows continued harmonization and efficiencies across our R&D and innovation pipeline and supply chain. Our innovation and food technology roadmap is led out of our Food Science Centre in Wageningen, the Netherlands, which opened its doors in 2022 following an investment of approximately €38 million. Our Food Science Centre leads our research and reformulation programs to continue simplifying our recipes, with an aim to deliver our bestever products from natural, plant-based ingredients which are better for consumers and better for the planet. As a result of the above factors, our TAM across our four core categories, i.e., Butters and Spreads, Creams, Liquids and Cheeses, has increased 15 times to approximately €151 billion in 2022 as compared to approximately €11 billion in 2017. Our expansion into the Butter, Creams, Liquids and Cheeses categories, in addition to Spreads, resulted in an expansion of our TAM. While currently the penetration of plant-based products in the Butters, Creams and Cheeses 98 ----- categories is low, and estimated at less than 1%, there is a potential opportunity of approximately €23 billion (based on an incremental €7 billion opportunity in the above categories when assuming a 5% plant-based penetration) or €38 billion (based on an incremental €22 billion opportunity in the above categories when assuming a 16% plant-based penetration) (see also “Industry—Upfield’s TAM”). We optimized our supply chain footprint, closing five of our own manufacturing facilities including in Nassakaude Rotterdam (the Netherlands), Rexdale (Canada) and Purfleet (the United Kingdom). At the same time, we reinvested and modernized our footprint of 14 owned manufacturing facilities to support our growth objectives across our core categories. In addition, we introduced a value creation program, which focusses on making our business more efficient from an operational perspective and in particular through supply chain areas including, amongst others, procurement, manufacturing and portfolio simplification. Since the implementation of this program in 2018, we have realized approximately €415 million of costs savings in aggregate, with €90 million of cost savings achieved in 2023 alone. Our journey since 2018 has taken place against a turbulent and volatile backdrop of events including a global pandemic, associated supply chain challenges, commodity inflation and a cost-of-living crisis. Our transformation since 2018 was enabled by a purpose and performance-driven culture, which is carried by a passionate and engaged community of approximately 4,800 “Upfielders”, consisting of our management team and employees. Our community of “Upfielders” are aligned with our purpose, and are highly motivated to make an impact, deliver sustainable, purposeful long-term growth and advance the transition to a plant-based food future.

Our brands are organized across end-to-end brand platforms which are founded upon key prerequisites of taste and affordability, but each serves a distinct consumer need and is mapped against the key usage occasions and growth opportunities across our categories and markets. Organizing our brands in this way also allows for continued and ongoing harmonization and efficiencies across our R&D and innovation pipeline, sales and marketing and supply chain activities with respect to our brands and products. Our brand platforms are led by our power brands, our most iconic brands, which have a long history and heritage. We believe that our power brands are deeply rooted and trusted by our consumers and customers across a number of our markets and have high brand awareness in their respective markets. These brands include, for example, Flora (launched in 1964 with a strong presence in the United Kingdom and increasingly other European markets), Country Crock (launched in 1954 and present today in the United States), Becel +ProActiv (Becel launched in 1962 and ProActiv launched in 2000 with a strong presence in European markets and Canada), Rama (launched in 1924 with a strong presence in Germany), BlueBand (launched in 1916 and present today in the Netherlands, Indonesia and other markets within AMEA) and Violife (which is a leading plant-based cheese brand globally, with an especially strong presence in the United States and the United Kingdom, which are the leading plant-based cheese markets), acquired in 2020. Our power brands accounted for the majority of our total net sales for the year ended December 31, 2023. In addition to our power brands, we have a number of country or region specific brands with a strong local heritage and brand awareness. Such local brands include for example, Lätta, a leading plant-based spreads brand in Sweden, Tulipan, a popular brand of over 70 years in Spain, under which we offer Plant Butter and Spreads without any palm oil, and Stork, which was launched more than 100 years ago and which has become a leading baking brand in the United Kingdom. Our brands and products are positioned across the price ladder in their markets with affordability being a key focus. We organize our brands across three tiers: “good,” “better” and “best.” Each tier is strategically designed to meet distinct consumer needs and certain price sensitivities, thereby catering to a wider audience. We believe that the “good,” “better” and “best” pricing strategy simplifies consumer decision-making and strategically position each tier to appeal to different segments. Brands that sit in the “good” tier target price-sensitive consumers in their respective markets with a plant-based spread product and includes brands such as Imperial (the United States, Mexico), Rama (Germany), Stork 99 ----- (the United Kingdom), Delma (Poland and Hungary) and Lätta (Sweden). The “better” tier offers a broader product offering and are therefore positioned at a slightly higher price point, attracting consumers who are looking for additional product benefits but still affordable compared to the dairy alternative. Brands such as Country Crock (the United States), Flora (the United Kingdom), Becel (Netherlands, Canada) and BlueBand (Indonesia, Netherlands) fall within the “better” pricing tier. The “best” tier contains brands which offer a premium product for consumers, with multiple features and in some cases health benefits, such as Becel +ProActiv which contains plant sterols which are clinically proven to lower cholesterol. Brands such as Becel +ProActiv, Violife as well as some plant butter offerings in certain markets fall within the “best” pricing tier. On average, our Plant Butter and Spreads cost 40% less compared to dairy alternatives.

We are a leading producer of plant-based butter and spreads. Our Plant Butter and Spreads are made from Plant Oils, water, salt and protein and are suitable for key usage occasions including baking, cooking and spreading. For the year ended December 31, 2023, our Plant Butter and Spreads represented 81% of our net sales. Our Plant Butter is specifically formulated with the aim to match the performance and taste of dairy butter. It contains six to seven natural ingredients including Plant Oils, plant-based proteins, natural flavourings, water and, in some cases, salt. Our Plant Butter comes in a wrapper like dairy butter, which allows it to more effectively target the baking and cooking occasion. Our Plant Spreads have been largely reformulated since 2018, introducing natural, plant-based ingredients and harmonizing and rationalizing the number of SKUs and recipes to focus on fewer but better products. Our Plant Spreads contain fat levels between approximately 20% to 75% depending on format and usage occasion. Whereas our Plant Butter is specifically designed with the aim of replicating dairy butter in terms of both taste and functionality for baking, cooking and spreading applications, our variety of plant spreads are more focused on specific usage occasions. For example, depending on fat levels, our Plant Spreads may be most suitable for baking, cooking or spreading. Our Plant Butter and Spreads cover a wide range of categories based on storage temperature, including (i) chilled products, (ii) ambient products, which are solid at room temperature and (iii) tropical ambient products (for Plant Spreads), which remain solid at the higher temperatures typically experienced in tropical climates. Our Plant Butter and Spreads are also available in multiple formats suitable for a variety of occasions, including wrappers and tubs for spreading, cooking and baking purposes, sachets for spreading and topping, as well as large format tubs and portion packs for the foodservice industry. Our Plant Butter and Spreads have several health and environmental advantages over dairy butter. One of their benefits includes the higher Omega 3 and 6 fatty acid concentrations and zero trans-fat and lower saturated fat content per serving. Additionally, the production of plant butter and spreads requires fewer resources and have a significantly lower overall carbon footprint than dairy butter and other comparable dairy products. Our Plant Butter and Spreads product lifecycle contributes approximately 70% less CO₂ emissions, need approximately 66% less land and need approximately 50% less water than dairy equivalents.

Our Plant Creams are alternatives to traditional dairy creams and can be used in the same way, for example, for cooking, baking or topping. For the year ended December 31, 2023, our Plant Creams represented 8% of our net sales. Our Plant Creams are made from Plant Oils, combined with proteins, emulsifiers and stabilizers. Some of our cream products which are not 100% plant-based contain buttermilk and we intend to transition towards a 100% plantbased portfolio by 2030. Our creams portfolio currently includes cooking creams, double/whipping creams and sour creams, and are packaged in a variety of formats including pots, bottles, pouches, tetra packs and pallecons for both our retail and foodservice channels. Our Plant Creams have several health and environmental advantages over dairy creams, including a longer shelf life (reducing waste for customers and consumers), greater volume and stability in whipping, acid stable, heat stable and allergen free (where 100% plant-based). Our Plant Creams also have a product lifecycle which requires fewer resources and a lower overall carbon footprint, contributing approximately 50% less CO₂ emissions compared to dairy creams.

Our liquids portfolio comprises culinary liquids, namely plant-based liquid margarines and sprays, which are typically used for cooking and baking including for sautéing, frying, baking, grilling or as a topping. For the year ended December 31, 2023, our Liquids represented 4% of our net sales. Our Liquids are derived from Plant Oils and are available in both bottle and spray formats. 100 ----- Our Liquids contain all of the cooking benefits of dairy butter but without the commonly associated issue of spattering. Our offering also contains zero trans-fats per serving.

Our Plant Cheeses are alternatives to traditional dairy cheeses and can be used in the same way as dairy cheese. For the year ended December 31, 2023, our Plant Cheeses represented 5% of our net sales. Our Plant Cheeses are typically made from Plant Oils combined with starch and plant proteins and partially fortified with Vitamin B12. Our Plant Cheeses portfolio covers a variety of styles, flavors, formats across hard, soft and spreadable cheese including slices, blocks, grated, creamy and in a variety of flavors such as cheddar, gouda, mozzarella and smoked. Our Plant Cheeses have several health and environmental advantages over dairy cheeses, including being free of allergens (including dairy, casein and lactose), cholesterol free and with zero trans-fats. Plant-based cheeses also have a production lifecycle which requires fewer resources and a lower overall carbon footprint, contributing approximately 74% less CO₂ emissions compared to dairy cheeses.

We are focused on four core categories: Butters and Spreads, Creams, Liquids and Cheeses. For the year ended December 31, 2023, our Plant Butter and Spreads, Plant Creams, Liquids and Plant Cheeses represented 81%, 8%, 4% and 5% of our net sales, respectively. Sales outside of our core categories represented 2% of our net sales for the year ended December 31, 2023. We compete against dairy and other plant-based offerings within these categories through our plant-based products. These products are marketed through our portfolio of brands, comprising our power brands and other local brands which cover a range of categories and price points across our markets.

The Europe region comprises our operations in continental Europe, Scandinavia and the United Kingdom and Ireland, and we have a sales presence in 39 European countries. For the year ended December 31, 2023, our operations in Europe accounted for €1,599 million of net sales, representing 48.8% of our total net sales for the same period.

Our operations span three regions, namely Europe, the Americas and AMEA. We sell our products across those regions primarily through retail channels, such as supermarkets, hypermarkets, convenience stores and other outlets. In addition, in emerging markets in which we operate across our regions, we have established a strong market channel based on deep relationships with well-known and reputable distributors. We additionally operate a foodservice channel, which sells products to commercial outlets, such as quick service restaurants, bakeries, pizza and pasta outlets, hotels, catering and industrial kitchens and to the social sector, such as educational institutions, workplaces and hospitals. Retail sales represented 89% of our total net sales for the year ended December 31, 2023. Our foodservice channel represented 11% of our total net sales for the year ended December 31, 2023. In the retail channel, we operate as the supplier of choice and/or “category captain” for certain strategic retailers, providing in-depth knowledge and consumer insight for particular product categories to our retailer customers. As is typical in the food industry, we do not have long-term contractual commitments with our key customers. Instead, we enter into bespoke joint business plans with customers, which usually encompass pricing, trade terms, support for new innovation, assortment, distribution and shelf space. In some markets, the agreements also include promotional activity for the year, although in most markets it is still possible to change promotional activity and pricing during the year. We have also developed relationships with various online retailers and e-commerce platforms, such as Ocado, Tesco, Amazon and Carrefour online, which have seen an increase in retail market share in recent years and which we believe represent a significant growth opportunity in the regions in which we operate, especially in Europe and the Americas. Our foodservice business operates in 76 countries across Europe, the Americas and AMEA. Approximately 44% of our foodservice net sales come from the United Kingdom, Indonesia, Germany, Sweden and Mexico. Given this market concentration, we believe there is significant room to expand our foodservice geographical footprint. Moreover, we believe there is considerable potential in the foodservice channel for our core product categories given our current product portfolio, and in particular its appeal across the foodservice value pyramid and the menu adoption cycle. Our growth strategy in foodservice is focused on selling value-add branded products with high-demand applications to commercial customers and driving customer acquisition through our chef-led sales approach (see also “—Sales and Marketing”).

Subsubsection Text: The Americas region comprises our operations in the United States, Canada and LatAm, and we are present in 20 countries in the Americas. For the year ended December 31, 2023, our operations in the Americas accounted for €1,319 million of net sales, representing 40.3% of our total net sales for the same period.

Subsection Title: For the year ended Our three largest markets by net sales are:** **December 31, 2023
Subsubsection Text: The AMEA region comprises our operations in Africa, the Middle East and Asia, and we are present in 47 AMEA countries. For the year ended December 31, 2023, our operations in AMEA accounted for €357 million of net sales, representing 10.9% of our total net sales for the same period.

Subsection Title: For the year ended Our three largest markets by net sales are:** **December 31, 2023

These operations are underpinned by our strong brand and product portfolio and longstanding relationships with leading retailers across Europe. We have simplified our operations in Europe since 2018, moving from 12 clusters to 4, namely the Northern cluster (the United Kingdom, Ireland, the Nordics and the Baltics), the South-west cluster (Belgium, Netherlands, France, Spain and Portugal), the Central and Eastern cluster (Poland, Ukraine, Eastern Europe, Greece and Cyprus) and DACHIT cluster (Germany, Austria, Switzerland and Italy). According to NielsenIQ measurement data, we hold leading positions in the retail butter and spreads segment in many of our European markets, the retail creams segment in Germany and the United Kingdom and a leading position in the retail plant cheese segment in the United Kingdom. _(% of total net (€ in millions)_ _sales Americas)_ United States .............................................................................................. 842 63.8% Canada ....................................................................................................... 178 13.5% Mexico ....................................................................................................... 159 12.0% The North America region (the United States and Canada) is predominantly a direct market with mainly retail (modern trade) customers. LatAm, in contrast, is predominantly served through distributors because of its geography and customer fragmentation, including the prevalence of traditional trade customers throughout the region. Mexico is the largest market within LatAm, and is evenly split between distributor (traditional trade) customers and retail (modern trade) customers. Our operations are underpinned by our strong brand portfolio and longstanding relationships with leading retailers and well-known and reputable distributors across the Americas. According to NielsenIQ measurement data, we hold the leading position in the retail butter and spreads segment in North America and a number one position in the retail plant cheese segment in the United States. _(% of total net (€ in millions)_ _sales AMEA)_ Indonesia .................................................................................................... 78 21.9% Turkey ........................................................................................................ 73 20.5% Australia ..................................................................................................... 56 15.6% The AMEA region is predominantly a distributor-led market and there has been a significant consolidation of our distributor base since 2019, especially in Indonesia and Pakistan. Our operations are underpinned by our strong brand portfolio and longstanding relationships with well-known and reputable distributors across AMEA. Our AMEA business is organized into six main clusters, namely, (i) Indonesia, (ii) South East and Far East Asia, (iii) South Asia, (iv) Turkey 102 ----- and Central Asia, (v) the Middle East and North Africa (MENA), (vi) Africa and (vii) Australia, New Zealand and the Pacific Islands. According to NielsenIQ measurement data, we hold leading positions in the retail butter and spreads segment in our two key markets, Indonesia and Turkey. These leading positions are supported by our high degree of brand awareness and strong relationships with reputable distributors.

We are a global leader in plant-based food. While there are other local and regional producers of plant-based products, we are strongly positioned in the market of plant butter and spreads, plant creams and plant cheeses. See “Industry.” Our plant-based products face competition from alternative products such as dairy butter, cooking oils, traditional dairy creams and animal-based cheeses and sweet spreads amongst others. The competitive dynamics in our industry are, in particular, driven by changing consumer trends, demands and preferences. These include dietary, health and environmental concerns and trends, such as increasing awareness of different nutritional aspects of foods and the health effects and sourcing practices relating to specific ingredients, an increasing preference for dairy-free, vegan and organic food ingredients, trends towards eating and baking outside of home and concerns regarding public health consequences associated with obesity and increasing awareness of the environmental and social effects of production (in particular those related to palm oil, which is a key ingredient in many products across our portfolio). See also “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of _Operations—Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Changes in Food Trends and Consumer Preferences” and_ “Industry—Key Trends” for a description of changes in food trends and consumer preferences affecting our business.

We aim to solidify and enhance our market-leading brand awareness and increase penetration of plant-based food in our core categories by leveraging our brand heritage and our products’ ability to meet key consumer purchasing criteria with respect to taste, functionality, health and nutrition, sustainability and affordability. By building and supporting our brands, we believe we can educate and inspire consumers to move to plant-based foods. Over the years, we have introduced millions of consumers to our plant-based products. For example, in 2023, we reached an additional 55 million consumers based on household penetration data by country and product sales (bringing us to approximately 261 million consumers reached as of December 31, 2023), which is a significant contribution to our goal of “inspiring the shift” and reaching one billion people with our plant-based products by 2030. Our sales teams are organized by region and local market, with overall strategic guidance and direction provided at a global level in line with our overall corporate strategy. Regional sales teams are responsible for regional sales and promotional strategy, and alongside local teams plan the end-to-end sales process and activities across sales planning, sales execution and sales promotion activities. Local teams manage day-to-day operations and execution in both retail and foodservice channels and manage customer relationships and, where relevant, distributor relationships. Our marketing function is led by dedicated marketing teams in each region and lead markets, with overall strategic guidance and communications support provided at a central level in line with our overall corporate strategy. The regional marketing leads are responsible for developing the overall marketing and strategy and work closely with our markets units, sales, supply chain and R&D teams to support sales and operational planning, and execute our overall marketing strategy in line with our overall objectives. This includes engaging with customers on promotional displays and merchandising, as well as planning key marketing and promotional campaigns and providing key consumer insights and intelligence across the business. This is supported by our interactive data visualization Power BI platform and key consumer and market insight data from brand experts engaged by us, amongst other initiatives. Through targeted campaigns and consumer engagement, we work to increase public knowledge of how our products can contribute to healthier, more sustainable diets. This year, we have continued to develop new and innovative marketing campaigns like “Skip the Cow” and the #MakeItPlant campaign to drive consumers, chefs and foodservice providers to choose more plant-based options. Our “Skip the Cow” campaign, initially under the Flora brand, was meant to inspire the shift to plant-based products and promote the benefits of our Plant Butter which has approximately 75% less climate impact in terms of CO₂ emissions than dairy butter. Since the launch of the campaign at the beginning of 2023, sales volumes of Flora Plant Butter have increased by more than 59% in the United Kingdom for the year ended December 31, 2023 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2022. Furthermore, Flora Plant Butter experienced growth in household penetration and share of segment in the United Kingdom. Our “Skip the Cow” campaign has pushed the uptake of Flora Plant and has proved to be a valuable resource in boosting consumer awareness and positive net sentiment (86%) towards our Flora brand. Following the success of the “Skip the Cow” campaign in the United Kingdom, 103 ----- we launched similar campaigns across European markets, such as Germany and Austria, and have started to also roll it out to other key markets such as the Netherlands, Poland or Spain, and also across other brands.

_Certain of the estimates and other information set forth in this section have been derived from external sources, including third-party industry data providers, as well as a report Upfield commissioned by an international consulting company (collectively, the “Industry Data Providers” and, each individually, an “Industry Data Provider”). Unless otherwise stated, industry data in this Offering Memorandum from Industry Data Providers was sourced at various points in time and reflects the data available at such point in time and does not reflect further updates after it was sourced. Industry surveys, publications and forecasts generally state that the information contained therein has been obtained from sources believed to be reliable, but that the accuracy and completeness of such information is not guaranteed. See “Industry and Market Data.” The estimates and forward-looking statements in this section are not guarantees of future performance and actual events and circumstances could differ materially from current expectations. Numerous factors could cause or contribute to such differences. See “Risk Factors” and “Forward-Looking Statements.”_

In November 2023, we entered into a strategic partnership with Heura Foods, a Spanish plant-based start-up that produces sustainable and nutritious plant-based meat products, taking a minority stake in the company. We are partnering with Heura Foods to develop food technology and collaborate on product definition, production, and distribution. This partnership aims to create superior products via disruptive technology, bringing together Heura Foods’ cutting-edge technologies and our expertise and innovation as regards plant-based food products. 104 -----

In February 2022, we entered into a strategic partnership with Change Foods, a California-based company pioneering the development of a unique precision fermentation process, thereby securing a minority stake in the Change Foods business. Their process creates nature-identical dairy casein proteins, which is the fundamental building block of all dairy cheeses.

In November 2022, we also entered into a strategic partnership with Alfred’s FoodTech Ltd, an Israeli food-tech company, taking a minority stake. Alfred’s has an innovative process and technology and, as part of our collaboration, we will explore working together with the aim of improving the taste, functionality and nutritional profile of our Plant Cheeses.

We acquired a minority stake, through investments since 2022, in Alternative Foods, a UK-based plant-based egg alternative producer and leading vegan bakery, which markets its products under the OGGS® brand. We are working together with the OGGS® team to expand the plant-based egg substitute market, and create allergen-free products that deliver on taste, nutrition and sustainability.

We believe we are a key player in the food technology ecosystem, partnering across the full system from academia and start-ups to scale-ups and suppliers. These strategic partnerships offer differentiated propositions which complement our R&D capabilities and our ability to scale through our distribution channels, and allow us to grow our position in the professional food sector.

Our procurement function sits within our global supply chain function and is led by our Chief Procurement Officer. We operate a predominantly centralized procurement function designed to leverage our purchasing expertise and maximize scale efficiencies across the regions where we operate. Our procurement function has a deep understanding of commodity cycles and risk management, and many years of experience in the oils market. Sourcing strategy, commodities risk management, hedging and procurement value creation are designed and managed by the central procurement team, which is also responsible for the sourcing of Plant Oils. Regional procurement teams are responsible for sourcing of other inputs and materials and supplier management. We source most of our food ingredients and packaging materials from global suppliers who can deliver locally, and our supply chain is aligned with our geographic footprint, enabling us to optimize our supply arrangements and minimize logistics costs. We have developed strong, long-standing relationships with our major suppliers of key raw materials, many of which have been in place for over a decade. The principal ingredient in our Plant Butter and Spreads, Plant Creams, Liquids and Plant Cheeses are refined Plant Oils (such as rapeseed oil (approximately 33% of our total Plant Oils volume and of which the majority is sourced from Europe), soybean oil (approximately 17% of our total Plant Oils volume and of which the majority is sourced from North America), sunflower oil (approximately 5% of our total Plant Oils volume and which we entirely source from Europe), palm oil, palm kernel oil, derivatives and fractions (approximately 36% of our total Plant Oils volume and of which the majority is sourced from Indonesia and Malaysia) and coconut oil (approximately 6% of our total Plant Oils volume and of which the majority is sourced from the Philippines)), in each case, for the year ended December 31, 2023. Additional primary materials used in our production process include other ingredients and packaging materials. Our risk management mechanisms include the use of physical stocks. futures, forward contracts, derivatives and other financial hedging transactions to provide certainty and insulate the business from short term price volatility across a majority of its input commodities, with initiatives underway to expand the scope of such measures to cover packaging material costs as well. In addition, we are committed to responsible and sustainable sourcing of all our ingredients and our Responsible Sourcing Policy, Human Rights Policy and Business Partner Code of Conduct applies to all our suppliers. Our target is to be 100% deforestation free and conversion free by 2025. Since October 2019, all of the palm oil directly purchased by us is certified (segregated and mass balance), which means that our supply chain has been assessed against strict criteria set-out by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO). In 2023, we achieved a score of 8.5 (out of 10) on the RSPO’s Shared Responsibility Scorecard, placing us in the top 4% of companies demonstrating sustainable leadership in palm oil sourcing. Beyond sourcing certified (segregated and mass balance) palm oil, we partner with independent experts like Earthworm and use satellite technology to monitor our supply chains. This satellite technology enables us to monitor the sources of the palm oil we purchase, which in turn allows us to address deforestation risks with our supply chain partners. We continue to innovate and create new recipes both with sustainable palm and alternatives to palm oil, namely through our patented palm oil-free technology. We have also taken significant steps in increasing the transparency of our coconut oil supply chain. After joining the Sustainable Coconut Charter in January 2022, we ran a supplier assessment and policy 105 ----- review. By the end of 2022, 100% of our coconut oil suppliers agreed with our policy and started to share their countrylevel traceability with us, which gives us the visibility to ensure sustainability throughout our supply chains. Furthermore, we continue to maintain our policy commitments for certified paper sourcing (Financial Services Compensation Scheme (“FSC”)/Programme for Endorsement of Forest Certification “PEFC”) and ensuring soybean oil is sourced in compliance with the Amazon Soy Moratorium Agreement. For the year ended December 31, 2023, materials, which include Plant Oils, other ingredients, flavors, finished goods from third-party manufacturers and packaging materials, represented 67% of our total cost of sales.

We own a total of 14 manufacturing facilities, of which 13 are operated by us, comprising seven manufacturing facilities in Europe, four manufacturing facilities in the Americas and three manufacturing facilities in AMEA (see table below). The Tultitlán, Mexico facility is currently owned by us and operated by Unilever, with the operational transition from Unilever to us in progress. These facilities produced approximately 91% of our total production volume for the year ended December 31, 2023. In addition, we have strategic relationships with select third-party manufacturers, which produced approximately 9% of our total production volume for the year ended December 31, 2023. Our relationships with third-party manufacturers are predominantly focused in AMEA and LatAm and where markets are more fragmented and/or where there is a greater distance to our own manufacturing facilities. For example, we have a long-term strategic contract with GrainCorp, who is the only manufacturer of our products sold within Australia and New Zealand. We believe that our global network of manufacturing facilities provides us with exceptional outreach to local markets while maintaining quality and efficiency through scale. The following table sets out the key attributes of our manufacturing facilities during the year ended December 31, 2023.

(2) Tultitlán, Mexico facility is currently owned by us and operated by Unilever, with the operational transition from Unilever to us in progress. Our manufacturing facilities are focused on in-house manufacturing of a wide range of our product offering along with multiple packaging options. We have invested significantly in our supply chain and manufacturing facilities since 2018 including in new capacity and capabilities for the production of plant butter and spreads and plant cheeses, maintenance, consolidation and value creation improvements. Although capacity differs by product category and facility as a result of this investment, we have significant spare capacity available through our network to accommodate future growth in our core product categories, including planned expansion in the private label and foodservice segments, as well as to respond to seasonal fluctuations. For the year ended December 31, 2023, production costs, which also include labor, electricity, gas, depreciation and other related costs represented 12% of our total cost of sales.

We operate an asset-light distribution model that carefully manages our outbound supply chain and allocates products manufactured in our manufacturing facilities to our distribution centers (primary distribution) and subsequently to our retailers and foodservice customers (secondary distribution). We have a global cold chain logistics network 106 ----- comprising 37 distribution centers, of which three are owned by us, which is broadly aligned with our manufacturing footprint in the regions in which we operate. We outsource the operation of the majority of these distribution centers to third-party logistics partners, with the exception of our centers in Helsingborg (Sweden), Pratau (Germany) and Corlu (Turkey), which we operate ourselves given their strategic location, capabilities and expertise. For the year ended December 31, 2023, logistics costs, which include transportation, warehousing and other logistics costs, represented 15% of our total cost of sales.

As of December 31, 2023, we had approximately 4,800 employees across the world. We believe that our employees are critical to our success. To nurture an engaged workforce, we complete an annual survey to gauge employee sentiment and opportunities for progress. For the year ended December 31, 2023, our overall employee engagement score was 7.8 (as compared to 7.5 in 2022), bringing us with four points of the top quartile of consumer companies and our employee net promoter score (eNPS), which seeks to measure employee satisfaction, was 33 (as compared to 25 in 2022). Our goal is to reach an employee engagement score of more than 8.1 by 2030. We offer comprehensive training for employees throughout the business, equipping them with the skills they need to develop and grow, and helping them realize their aspirations. For instance, we recently launched the Upside program, a leadership development program for our employees. We also launched “Come As You Are” workshops to inspire respectful, inclusive behaviors and greater understanding of diversity, equity and inclusion among our leadership team. We plan to undertake similar sessions for our manufacturing facility-based workforce in 2024.

The first pillar of our ESG strategy, plant-based, is dedicated to inspiring more people to eat plant-based food. Our role is to ensure that, through our brands, we offer a range of options that meet consumer needs. This includes seeking to ensure that our products taste great, perform well, are better for consumers and are made with simple and natural ingredients. We aim to reach one billion people with our products by 2030. For the year ended December 31, 2023, we estimate that we reached approximately 261 million consumers, based on household penetration data by country and product sales, with our plant-based products, an increase of 55 million compared to the year ended December 31, 2022. In addition, we want to deliver a 100% plant-based product portfolio by 2030. Whilst we are already over 99% dairy-free, dairy ingredients have the highest carbon impact of the ingredients in our portfolio and make a disproportionate contribution to our total carbon footprint. As such, we have continued to invest in research and reformulation programs that have cut dairy ingredients by 1.5 kiloton since 2022. Another one of our commitments is to have an all-natural ingredients product portfolio by 2030. We want to create recipes with natural ingredients, with simple, clean labels. Currently, 99% of our ingredients are natural and during 2023, we have continued our investments in R&D to simplify our recipes and aim to deliver the best-ever products created by us, with natural ingredients. In addition, in recent periods, a key focus area has been to transition artificial colors and artificial flavors to natural ones. In addition to advancing our own efforts, we are working to support the industry forward in terms of plant-based innovation, which includes establishing standard parameters for what plant-based means. We are currently leading the 107 ----- development of a new ISO standard that will specify technical definitions of, and criteria for, plant-based foods. We believe that this new ISO standard will help align the global food industry around a single terminology approach.

The second pillar of our ESG strategy focuses on the nutritional benefits of our products as well as their positive contribution to health. Health is a high priority for consumers and a key reason why people choose our products. For the year ended December 31, 2023, approximately 30% of our net sales came from products that provide health and nutrition benefits and can be labelled as such in compliance with regulations. This includes products with lower saturated fat and no trans-fat per serving and plant sterols for heart health, the addition of vitamins, calcium, Omega 3 and 6 and lower calorie options, which support functional health. We take a science-based approach to establishing criteria and targets for each product type we sell, considering who uses them, how frequently and in which applications. In 2023, we continued to expand our nutritional benchmarking program, following its launch in 2022, based on what science tells us is required for each different product proposition and which introduced saturated fat and trans-fat targets for plant creams and plant cheeses. As a result, over 91% of our sold volume met or exceeded our benchmarks for the year ended December 31, 2023. These targets are based on recognized external international standards and official dietary recommendations, including those from the World Health Organization. We have set additional targets that ensure we can deliver the desired nutritional composition. These include considerations for how we can limit nutrients of concern and provide essential nutrients that target some of the critical public health areas of concern, including heart health and children’s growth and development. We believe the future of food lies in quality, responsibly made, plant-based foods. To realize that future, we need to ensure our products are accessible to as many people as possible, which includes ensuring our products come in at affordable price points. Globally, our Plant Butter and Spreads remain significantly more affordable than their dairy counterparts. This is true compared to private label dairy butter and even more so compared to branded dairy butter. In the United States, our Imperial brand offers a strong value-for-money proposition for value-seeking consumers. One of our commitments is to maintain such affordability, especially for consumers in lower socio-economic groups. Additionally, we seek to positively impact people’s lives, including by educating children on nutrition and by enabling heart health and improving functional health. For example, under our brand BlueBand we implemented a program “Sarapan Berisi BlueBand” (“Nutritious Breakfast with BlueBand”) for children across Indonesia in 2023. The goal of this program was to inspire families to prioritize healthy breakfasts by demonstrating the connection between good nutrition, particularly Omega 3 and 6 intake, enhanced school performance and greater success throughout life. Our brand Becel +ProActiv has always championed heart health and is clinically proven to lower blood cholesterol. During 2023, we launched several marketing campaigns to heighten brand awareness and encourage consumers to commence actions to ensure heart health later on. In Brazil, our Não Deixe Para Depois (“Don’t Leave It for Later”) campaign, which featured an engaging video about Becel +ProActiv, reached approximately 37 million people in 2023. Also, we expanded our market penetration in 2023, launching Becel +ProActiv in Saudi Arabia and therewith enabling more people to access heart-healthier choices.

Our third ESG pillar is based on our belief that people are happier when they are engaged and so we actively promote a culture of active support. In addition to our employees, we are committed to supporting our wider community of stakeholders, including our suppliers and farmers. To nurture an engaged workforce, we complete an annual survey to gauge employee sentiment and opportunities for progress. See also “—Employees.” In 2021, we set the target of a 50/50 gender split by 2030, with a focus on managers and above. For the year ended December 31, 2023, we achieved approximately 43% women representation at management level and 38% across the entire workforce. In addition, in 2022, we began developing the “Women in Finance and IT” program to level gender representation in finance and IT, which aims to advance female finance and IT professionals through bespoke training, peer-to-peer support, expert guidance and mindfulness tools. While the program was still in its first year, for the year ended December 31, 2023, female representation reached 45% (up from 44% in 2022) in our finance functions and 33% (up from 28% in 2022) in IT functions. In addition, we want to support our communities through employee volunteering. For the year ended December 31, 2023, we reached 5,646 hours of employee volunteering, an increase of 18% compared to the year ended December 31, 2022. We are committed to reach 15,000 hours of employee volunteering annually. 108 ----- Across our supply chains, we are connected to thousands of farmers and plant-based entrepreneurs who grow our ingredients and chefs who create and prepare millions of meals every day. In support of farmers and plant-based entrepreneurs, we maintain several partnerships, enabling and encouraging them to improve agricultural practices and access to markets. For example, to reduce emissions and support sustainable farming practices, we have teamed up with Regrow Ag, an agricultural technology company. By using their technology, we can analyse the environmental impacts of our North American soy, canola and sunflower supply chains. This allows us to develop an increasingly accurate and meaningful emissions reduction strategy and identify opportunities to implement regenerative agriculture practices in our supply chains, directing investments to farmers to support emissions reductions and climate resilience. This, in turn, will drive progress towards our wider Science Based Target initiative (“SBTi”) commitment while increasing our ability to source sustainable, responsible, plant-based ingredients (see also “—Better Planet”). In addition, we seek to reach as many chefs and food service professionals as possible to encourage the adoption of our products into their cooking, thereby engaging chefs in the plant-based revolution. For example, in May 2023, our MENA (Middle East and North Africa) team hosted a cooking workshop in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia whereby a number of local chefs came together to learn about our brands and how they can be incorporated into recipes. The workshop also served as a platform to launch new products to the Saudi Arabian market, including Violife cheeses and Rama cream.

The goal guiding our fourth ESG pillar is “to pioneer food,” that is, we want to be on the forefront of creating food that is better for the planet by showcasing the benefit of plant-based products while reducing our carbon footprint. Our better planet commitments include our environmental targets to address our material environmental impacts on the climate, on packaging and on responsible sourcing. For the year ended December 31, 2023, we committed to SBTi and have worked on redefining our targets in line with the newly published Forest, Land and Agriculture (“FLAG”) guidance to align with limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels. We also made progress on the reduction of our Scope 1 emissions (i.e., direct emissions owned or controlled by a company) and Scope 2 emissions (i.e., indirect emissions associated with the purchase of electricity, steam, heat, or cooling). For the year ended December 31, 2023, the carbon impact of our manufacturing facilities, representing the majority of our Scope 1 and 2 emissions, was reduced by 16.7%, in absolute emissions, through the implementation of our decarbonization plan focused on improving energy efficiency and shifting to lower-carbon and renewable energy sources. One example of our decarbonization plan is the installation of a modern steam boiler room in our Polish (Katowice) manufacturing facility in 2023, helping us to move away from coal-fired steam as a fuel source in our manufacturing process. By upgrading the Polish (Katowice) manufacturing facility plant boiler, we expect to reduce our emissions by approximately 6,800 tonnes annually. Our Scope 3 emissions (i.e., emissions not covered by Scope 1 and 2 emissions, created by a company’s value chain) plan focuses on the biggest drivers of our footprint, namely ingredients, packaging and logistics. We have made progress across Scope 3 emissions in our supply chain, driven by reformulation, dairy elimination, recycled packaging increases and changes in the mix of our portfolio, delivering a 13% reduction in absolute emissions in the year. For the year ended December 31, 2023, over 62% of our carbon footprint came from ingredients. Dairy, for example, which accounts for just less than 1% of our ingredients, represented over 5% of our carbon impact, making removing it from our portfolio an important step towards reducing our emissions. Since 2020, we have reduced dairy-related carbon emissions, including methane, by over 43% as we have continued to develop more plant-based recipes. Beside emissions, we are reducing environmental impact through waste and water management at our manufacturing facilities. For example, our manufacturing facility in Drama, Greece, is reducing environmental impact through a new wastewater treatment plant that will ensure manufacturing facility outflow is safe and clean. The facility has been designed for high operational efficiency, reducing the chemicals and energy needed to treat wastewater. It will also reduce the volume of sludge created as a by-product by up to 95% while ensuring any effluent continues to meet relevant environmental standards. In addition, we are targeting a 100% zero waste to landfill by 2030. For the year ended December 31, 2023, 85%, or 11, of our manufacturing facilities achieved zero waste to landfill, with an absolute reduction of 11.9% and over 150% increase in reused waste versus 2022. Moreover, we are committed to providing packaging that protects our products and the planet. Wherever we incorporate paper-based materials into packaging, we look to do so responsibly in line with our responsible sourcing of paper and pulp policy. We maintain high levels of recyclability for our packaging format and have continued to increase our recycled content. For the year ended December 31, 2023, 93% of our packaging is recyclable, reusable or compostable. Our packaging goals are intended to reduce environmental impact without compromising quality and performance. In 2023, we successfully launched our paper tub packaging technology in Austria under our Flora Plant brand, with similar launches in the United Kingdom and the Netherlands in early 2024. This innovation marks the beginning of our transition to a paper solution across our portfolio, furthering our aim to reduce plastic content by 80% by 2030. Initially launched in Austria with Flora Plant, we expect further scaling of our paper solution, aiming to replace up to two billion plastic tubs by 2030, avoiding more than 25,000 tons of plastic waste per year. In addition, we are 109 ----- committed to introduce carbon labelling to 500 million packs of our Plant Butter and Creams by the end of 2025. Between 2021 and 2023, we achieved over 817 million carbon labels, significantly exceeding our target. In addition, we are committed to responsible and sustainable sourcing of all our ingredients and our Responsible Sourcing Policy, Human Rights Policy and Business Partner Code of Conduct applies to all our suppliers. Where key ingredients are identified as potentially high risk, we maintain strong individual policies designed to address the potential risks inherent in these supply chains, particularly focussing on deforestation and exploitation. One area of particular focus is palm oil, and all our palm oil is certified (segregated and mass balance) by the RSPO. Beyond certification, we continue to use satellite monitoring and have robust grievance management processes to proactively address issues in palm oil supply chains. We are also enhancing our efforts in other areas, including building a more sustainable coconut oil supply chain. We are a member of the Sustainable Coconut Partnership, an organization dedicated to making the coconut sector more resilient and responsible. Additionally, from 2024 onwards, we will begin sourcing Rainforest Alliance-certified coconut oil. For the year ended December 31, 2023, 100% of our palm oil and soybean oil were sustainably sourced with RSPO certification for our palm oil and 100% of our paper and pulp supply was sustainably sourced with a 100% PEFC or FSC certification.

Sustainability is at the heart of Upfield and is central to our purpose, our products and our end-to-end supply chain. We have made substantial investments to reach some of the industry’s highest levels of sustainable sourcing, including our sustainable palm oil practices. As a leader in plant-based foods, we are driven by our purpose to transform the global food system in partnership with our customers, suppliers, and stakeholders across our value chain. Our ESG strategy was developed to address our material impacts and opportunities, recognizing the need for rapid action to collectively address the challenges of the climate crisis, nature loss, population growth, and human health by enabling the transition to a sustainable food system. In 2023, we continued to implement our strategy and put our purpose “to make people healthier and happier with nutritious and delicious, natural, plant-based food that is good for you and good for our planet” into action to deliver positive impact across our four pillars: (i) plant-based, (ii) healthier lives, (iii) happier people and (iv) better planet. For each pillar of our ESG strategy, we have defined an overarching goal, supported by a series of commitments through which we track progress.

Our employees’ safety is our foremost priority in line with our “goal zero” vision to achieve zero serious workplace safety incidents. Furthermore, we believe that the health and safety of agency workers, engineering contractors, service providers and all those who visit our manufacturing facilities or offices is also paramount. We have established a strong culture that goes beyond legal compliance, maintaining occupational health and safety management system requirements that apply to every manufacturing facility and office. These requirements are outlined in our framework standards on occupational health & safety policy. To support implementation thereof, we developed a training module called WorkSafe for office-based employees. The module is designed to help them identify and prevent potential hazards, and to respond appropriately to any safety-related situations. In 2023, we also introduced our life-saving rules policy, which comprises six rules that apply across our business to prevent fatal or permanently disabling injuries. We also introduced the “courage to care” program to build a culture that encourages employees, contractors and visitors to care by reporting safety issues. As a result of such programs, three of our manufacturing facilities (Piraeus, Greece; Cikarang, Indonesia; and Nairobi, Kenya) had zero workplace accidents over the last three years.

Maintaining adequate brand protection is of significant importance to our business as we rely on our brands to implement our business strategy. We have an extensive trademark portfolio with approximately 3,303 trademarks across all of our regions. We also hold 656 patents and patent applications, with 19 new patents filed between 2018 and 2023 (with ten patent applications filed in 2023 alone) and 11 new patent families filed since 2018 across our Plant Butter and Spreads, Plant Creams and Plant Cheeses (relating to plant proteins as well as Plant Oils and fats). In addition, we hold 81 design registrations and 810 domain names spread across our regions. Our intellectual property is managed centrally, and we work closely with a third party agency in respect of filings, renewals, recordings and the prosecution and enforcement of intellectual property matters internationally.

We carry insurance that we believe to be common in our industry and sufficient to cover the principal risks of damage to our business. We maintain, where appropriate, insurance with respect to liability of our directors and officers, property damage, business interruption, cold storage facilities, public liability, products liability, product recall, damage to vehicles, personal accident, travel, employer liability and worker safety and compensation. We undertake periodic risk reviews to assess whether our insurance is in line with our business risks and whether the developments in insurance policies are reflective of the changes in our business.

From time to time, in the ordinary course of business, we are subject to litigation. Except as set forth in this Offering Memorandum, there were no proceedings ongoing, pending or to our knowledge, threatened, that are expected to have a material adverse impact on the Group as a whole. Since 2022, Upfield US Inc. (“Upfield US”), a Group company, has been named as a defendant in or threatened with alleged putative class action lawsuits. The claims generally allege that Upfield US has engaged in misleading labelling and advertising of its products and violated various state consumer fraud and deceptive business practice acts. 110 ----- The plaintiffs seek to certify classes of individuals who have purchased the named products in certain states within the United States. While several of these actions have been dismissed based on a motion to dismiss filed by Upfield US, other actions are pending. 111 -----
